events.title: Alice's Boredom and the Curious White Rabbit
detailed_summary: Alice expresses boredom while sitting beside her sister, finding the sister's book uninteresting due to its lack of pictures or dialogue.
She contemplates whether making a daisy chain is worth the effort in the heat, feeling drowsy.
A White Rabbit with pink eyes unexpectedly runs past her.
Alice initially doesn't find the Rabbit itself remarkable, nor does she immediately question hearing it talk to itself about being late.
Her curiosity is ignited when the Rabbit pulls a watch from its waistcoat pocket, an unprecedented sight for Alice.
Driven by intense curiosity about a rabbit possessing such items, she chases it across the field.
She arrives just in time to see the Rabbit disappear into a large rabbit hole.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, “and what is the use of a book,” thought Alice “without pictures or conversations?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.

events.text_segment:
Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, “and what is the use of a book,” thought Alice “without pictures or conversations?”
So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.
There was nothing so very remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so very much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself, “Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!” (when she thought it over afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural); but when the Rabbit actually took a watch out of its waistcoat-pocket, and looked at it, and then hurried on, Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it, and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge.
In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.

events.title: The Fall Down the Rabbit Hole
detailed_summary: The rabbit hole initially resembles a straight tunnel before abruptly turning downwards.
Alice begins falling down what seems like a very deep well, too quickly to stop herself.
The fall is either extremely long or very slow, allowing her ample time to observe her surroundings and ponder her situation.
She attempts to see the bottom but finds it too dark.
Looking sideways, she notices the well walls are lined with cupboards and bookshelves, interspersed with maps and pictures.
She takes a jar labeled "ORANGE MARMALADE" from a shelf as she descends.
To her disappointment, the jar is empty.
Concerned about potentially harming someone below, she carefully places the empty jar into another cupboard she passes during her fall.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labelled “ORANGE MARMALADE”, but to her great disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody underneath, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.

events.text_segment:
The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well.
Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well, and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs. She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labelled “ORANGE MARMALADE”, but to her great disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody underneath, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well. Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next. First, she tried to peep into the well to see if she was getting near the bottom yet, but it was so dark that all she could see was her own face as white as a ghost, with the brightness of the moon behind it, getting larger and larger as she went on. She looked up at the sky and found that she was now in the part of the world where the map of the sea is always drawn, and the pictures of ships and sea-serpents were floating by her on the walls. She took a jar that was marked "ORANGE MARMALADE" from a shelf as she passed; but to her great disappointment it was empty: she sat down and began to cry. "Come, there's no use in crying like that!" said Alice to herself, rather sharply. "I advise you to leave off." So she did, and dried her eyes, and looked up. As she looked up, she noticed another cupboard passing by, and, as she was very careful not to hit anything, she gently put the empty jar back into it, and said to herself, "Which is just as well, because if I had hit someone, it would have been very unpleasant for them."

And with that thought, she gave a little sigh and continued her climb, hoping she would soon reach the top and find out where she was. She called back, 'Yes, I'm here!' and then she heard a great deal of noise and confusion, and the next moment she found herself sitting on the floor of her own room, with her cat, Dinah, purring in her lap. events.title: Alice's Musings During the Long Fall
detailed_summary: Alice reflects internally that after such a significant fall, mundane tumbles like falling downstairs will seem trivial.
She imagines how brave her family will perceive her, thinking she wouldn't even mention falling off a house.
The descent continues relentlessly, making Alice wonder if it will ever end.
She speaks aloud, estimating she must have fallen about four thousand miles, approaching the Earth's center, recalling lessons from school.

Despite no audience, she considers it good practice to recite her knowledge, though she then puzzles over her Latitude and Longitude, admitting to herself she doesn't know what they mean but likes the sound of the words.
She speculates about falling entirely through the Earth and emerging among people who walk upside down, misremembering the term as "Antipathies".
She feels glad no one heard her mistake and considers asking the inhabitants the name of their country, practicing a curtsy mid-air.
She decides against asking to avoid appearing ignorant, hoping the location will be written somewhere.
With nothing else to do, she thinks about her cat, Dinah, hoping her family remembers Dinah's milk.
She wishes Dinah were with her, pondering if Dinah could catch bats in the air, questioning if cats eat bats.
Alice grows sleepy, repeating the questions "Do cats eat bats?" and "Do bats eat cats?" in a drowsy state.
She starts dreaming she's with Dinah, asking her about eating bats.
Her fall abruptly ends as she lands with a thump on a pile of sticks and leaves.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Well!” thought Alice to herself, “after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She felt that she was dozing off, and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah, and saying to her very earnestly, “Now, Dinah, tell me the truth: did you ever eat a bat?” when suddenly, thump! thump! down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves, and the fall was over.

events.text_segment:
“Well!” thought Alice to herself, “after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they’ll all think me at home! Why, I wouldn’t say anything about it, even if I fell off the top of the house!” (Which was very likely true.)
Down, down, down. Would the fall never come to an end? “I wonder how many miles I’ve fallen by this time?” she said aloud. “I must be getting somewhere near the centre of the earth. Let me see: that would be four thousand miles down, I think—” (for, you see, Alice had learnt several things of this sort in her lessons in the schoolroom, and though this was not a very good opportunity for showing off her knowledge, as there was no one to listen to her, still it was good practice to say it over) “—yes, that’s about the right distance—but then I wonder what Latitude or Longitude I’ve got to?” (Alice had no idea what Latitude was, or Longitude either, but thought they were nice grand words to say.)
Presently she began again. “I wonder if I shall fall right through the earth! How funny it’ll seem to come out among the people that walk with their heads downward! The Antipathies, I think—” (she was rather glad there was no one listening, this time, as it didn’t sound at all the right word) “—but I shall have to ask them what the name of the country is, you know. Please, Ma’am, is this New Zealand or Australia?” (and she tried to curtsey as she spoke—fancy curtseying as you’re falling through the air! Do you think you could manage it?) “And what an ignorant little girl she’ll think me for asking! No, it’ll never do to ask: perhaps I shall see it written up somewhere.”
Down, down, down. There was nothing else to do, so Alice soon began talking again. “Dinah’ll miss me very much to-night, I should think!” (Dinah was the cat.) “I hope they’ll remember her saucer of milk at tea-time. Dinah my dear! I wish you were down here with me! There are no mice in the air, I’m afraid, but you might catch a bat, and that’s very like a mouse, you know. But do cats eat bats, I wonder?” And here Alice began to get rather sleepy, and went on saying to herself, in a dreamy sort of way, “Do cats eat bats? Do cats eat bats?” and sometimes, “Do bats eat cats?” for, you see, as she couldn’t answer either question, it didn’t much matter which way she put it. She felt that she was dozing off, and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah, and saying to her very earnestly, “Now, Dinah, tell me the truth: did you ever eat a bat?” when suddenly, thump! thump! down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves, and the fall was over.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Well!” thought Alice to herself, “after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they’ll think me at home! Come up, here’s little Alice, who has been to the end of the world, and never cried at all!”

But then she tried to fancy herself talking in the fashion of the people in books:—“I mean what I say,” Alice began, very seriously, to a large sort of bat that was hanging up in the air in front of her. “I say what I mean.” The bat made no reply whatever: it just gave a lazy sort of flutter in the air, and was gone.

“Come, now, I open my eyes and see what’s to happen next,” thought Alice, “for I’m quite tired of falling as it is!” But she found out that she had only to keep on falling to make a longer fall; and so she went on, and still the room kept floating up to her as she went down. “I wonder if I shall fall right through the earth!” thought poor Alice; and she tried to fancy herself going on like that for ever and ever; but I daresay she would have got tired by that time.

Just then her foot dipped into something软, and in another moment down she came with a thump, down, down, OR ever she had time to think about it, upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves.

Alice opened her eyes. For some minutes she didn’t even know where she was, and lay perfectly still on the soft bed of leaves. Then she sat up and looked around her. The first thing she noticed was that, if possible, the forest seemed to be even darker and more mysterious than before. She was just going to get up and try to find her way out, when she heard a voice close by her, in a very gentle tone, saying, “What a curious child you are! What is it you want to do now?”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Well!” thought Alice to herself, “after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs! How brave they’ll all think me at home! Why, I wouldn’t say it to Mother for the world, but I’ve actually fallen off the top of the house! At least, I hope I did.”

But then she suddenly found that her feet were getting firmly planted on the ground, and that she was no longer falling. “I’ve got to be in the right place now,” she said, “and I hope it’s a house with plenty of rooms and nice people in them.”

She looked around and found herself in a long, low hall, with a red carpet running down the middle and a line of doors on either side. “Ah! This is like the passage in the fairy tales,” she said, “where you have to choose the right door to get to the magic garden. I wonder which one it is.”

She tried the first door on the left, but it was locked. The second one was also locked, and so was the third. “This is getting annoying,” she muttered. “I wish I had a key.”

Just then, a small voice behind her said, “You do have a key, you know.”

Alice turned around and saw a tiny creature, no taller than her knee, with a long tail and a pair of round, black eyes. “Who are you?” she asked.

“I’m a mouse,” said the creature. “And I’ve just been reading a very interesting book about the history of the world. It’s quite dry, I must say, but it’s very informative.”

“Then you must be very clever,” said Alice.

“I try to be,” said the mouse. “But I’m afraid I’m not very good at it. I get distracted very easily. I was just reading about the fall of the Roman Empire when I heard you talking about falling down stairs.”

“Oh, that’s just a figure of speech,” said Alice. “I didn’t really fall down stairs. I fell down a rabbit hole.”

The mouse looked at her with a mixture of surprise and curiosity. “A rabbit hole? That’s quite unusual. I’ve never heard of anyone falling down a rabbit hole before. What happened then?”

“Well,” said Alice, “I followed a white rabbit in a waistcoat and ended up here.”

The mouse’s eyes widened. “A white rabbit in a waistcoat? That’s not a rabbit at all! That’s a time traveler! I’ve read about them in my book. They’re very peculiar creatures. They move about in time and space, and they can take you anywhere.”

Alice looked at the mouse in amazement. “You mean I’ve been taken to another world?”

“I’m afraid so,” said the mouse. “But don’t worry. I’m sure it’s a very interesting place. I’ve heard it’s full of strange creatures and even stranger rules.”

Alice looked around the hall again, and for the first time, she felt a little nervous. “I hope it’s not too strange,” she said. “I’d like to go home soon.”

The mouse gave her a sympathetic look. “I understand. But sometimes, the most interesting places are the ones that seem the strangest at first. Just keep an open mind, and you’ll find your way.”

Alice nodded, feeling a little more confident. “Thank you,” she said. “I’ll try to remember that.”

And with that, she turned back to the line of doors, ready to explore the wonders of Wonderland.

events.title: Landing and the Hall of Locked Doors
detailed_summary: Alice discovers she is uninjured by the fall and quickly jumps to her feet.
She looks up but sees only darkness.
Ahead, she sees another long passage and spots the White Rabbit hurrying along it.
Feeling urgent, Alice chases after the Rabbit swiftly.
She hears the Rabbit exclaim about the late hour as it disappears around a corner.
Alice follows closely, turns the corner, but finds the Rabbit gone.
She finds herself in a lengthy, low hall illuminated by lamps hanging from the ceiling.
The hall is surrounded by doors, all of which are locked.
Alice tries every door along both sides of the hall without success.
She walks dejectedly down the middle of the hall, wondering about her escape.

events.text_segment:
Alice was not a bit hurt, and she jumped up on to her feet in a moment: she looked up, but it was all dark overhead; before her was another long passage, and the White Rabbit was still in sight, hurrying down it. There was not a moment to be lost: away went Alice like the wind, and was just in time to hear it say, as it turned a corner, “Oh my ears and whiskers, how late it’s getting!” She was close behind it when she turned the corner, but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen: she found herself in a long, low hall, which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof.
There were doors all round the hall, but they were all locked; and when Alice had been all the way down one side and up the other, trying every door, she walked sadly down the middle, wondering how she was ever to get out again.

She went on a little further, and found to her great delight that there were many little doors all round the hall, about fifteen inches high: she tried them all, one after another, but they were all locked. 'I shall never get out,' said Alice in a melancholy voice, sitting down on the floor. 'I shall be tied up here for ever, unless I can find a key to this door.'

events.title: The Golden Key and the Tiny Door to the Garden
detailed_summary: Alice discovers a small, three-legged table made entirely of glass.
On the table, she finds only a tiny golden key.
She initially hopes the key will open one of the hall doors.
She realizes the key is too small or the locks are too large; it doesn't fit any of the main doors.
Continuing her exploration, she finds a low curtain she hadn't seen before.
Behind the curtain is a very small door, about fifteen inches high.
She tries the golden key in the lock of the small door and finds, delightedly, that it fits.
Alice opens the tiny door, revealing a small passage leading to a beautiful garden.
She longs to enter the garden with its bright flowers and fountains.
She finds she cannot fit even her head through the doorway.
Alice laments that even if her head fit, it would be useless without her shoulders.
She wishes she could collapse like a telescope, musing that recent strange events make almost anything seem possible.

events.text_segment:
Suddenly she came upon a little three-legged table, all made of solid glass; there was nothing on it except a tiny golden key, and Alice’s first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall; but, alas! either the locks were too large, or the key was too small, but at any rate it would not open any of them. However, on the second time round, she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before, and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high: she tried the little golden key in the lock, and to her great delight it fitted!
Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage, not much larger than a rat-hole: she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw. How she longed to get out of that dark hall, and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains, but she could not even get her head through the doorway; “and even if my head would go through,” thought poor Alice, “it would be of very little use without my shoulders. Oh, how I wish I could shut up like a telescope! I think I could, if I only knew how to begin.” For, you see, so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately, that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible.

She crept along, and at last she came to a small door, and on the other side of it was a garden full of flowers and butterflies, and Alice longed to be there.

events.title: Discovery of the "DRINK ME" Bottle
detailed_summary: Deciding waiting by the small door is pointless, Alice returns to the glass table.
She hopes to find another key or perhaps instructions for shrinking.
She finds a small bottle on the table, noting it wasn't there previously.
A paper label on the bottle's neck clearly reads "DRINK ME".
Alice, recalling cautionary tales about dangers like poison, decides to be careful.
She resolves to check the bottle for a 'poison' label first, remembering safety rules learned about avoiding harm.
Finding no 'poison' mark, Alice decides to taste the contents.
The liquid has a delightful mixed flavour (cherry-tart, custard, pineapple, roast turkey, toffee, hot buttered toast).
Finding it very pleasant, she quickly drinks the entire bottle.

events.text_segment:
There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door, so she went back to the table, half hoping she might find another key on it, or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes: this time she found a little bottle on it, (“which certainly was not here before,” said Alice,) and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label, with the words “DRINK ME,” beautifully printed on it in large letters.
It was all very well to say “Drink me,” but the wise little Alice was not going to do that in a hurry. “No, I’ll look first,” she said, “and see whether it’s marked ‘poison’ or not”; for she had read several nice little histories about children who had got burnt, and eaten up by wild beasts and other unpleasant things, all because they would not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them: such as, that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long; and that if you cut your finger very deeply with a knife, it usually bleeds; and she had never forgotten that, if you drink much from a bottle marked “poison,” it is almost certain to disagree with you, sooner or later.
However, this bottle was not marked “poison,” so Alice ventured to taste it, and finding it very nice, (it had, in fact, a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast,) she very soon finished it off.

There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door, so she went back to the table, half hoping she might find another key on it, or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes: this time she found a little bottle on it, (“which certainly was not here before,” said Alice,) and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label, with the words “DRINK ME,” beautifully printed on it in large letters.

It was all very well to say “Drink me,” but the question is whether this “I” had not been changed so much lately that she would not like them in that form? However, it was nearly full: she drew a deep breath and drank it all at once.

It took a long time to go down—“like a whole bottle of pepper-water,” thought Alice—but at last it had gone, and she was a tiny little person.

events.title: Shrinking and the Problem of the Forgotten Key
detailed_summary: Alice experiences a strange sensation and realizes she must be shrinking like a telescope.
She confirms she has indeed shrunk, now measuring only ten inches tall.
Her mood lifts as she realizes she is now the correct size to enter the garden through the little door.
She prudently waits a few moments to see if she will shrink further.
A slight nervousness creeps in as she considers the possibility of shrinking away completely, like a candle flame.
She tries to imagine what a snuffed-out candle flame looks like but cannot recall.
After a short wait with no further change, she decides to proceed into the garden immediately.
Upon reaching the door, she realizes with dismay that she left the golden key on the glass table.
Returning to the table, she finds she is now too small to reach the key.
She can see the key clearly through the glass table-top but cannot climb the slippery legs.
Exhausted and frustrated by her failed attempts, Alice sits down and begins to cry.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What a curious feeling!” said Alice; “I must be shutting up like a telescope.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: After a while, finding that nothing more happened, she decided on going into the garden at once; but, alas for poor Alice! when she got to the door, she found she had forgotten the little golden key, and when she went back to the table for it, she found she could not possibly reach it: she could see it quite plainly through the glass, and she tried her best to climb up one of the legs of the table, but it was too slippery; and when she had tired herself out with trying, the poor little thing sat down and cried.

events.text_segment:
“What a curious feeling!” said Alice; “I must be shutting up like a telescope.”
And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden. First, however, she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further: she felt a little nervous about this; “for it might end, you know,” said Alice to herself, “in my going out altogether, like a candle. I wonder what I should be like then?” And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out, for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing.
After a while, finding that nothing more happened, she decided on going into the garden at once; but, alas for poor Alice! when she got to the door, she found she had forgotten the little golden key, and when she went back to the table for it, she found she could not possibly reach it: she could see it quite plainly through the glass, and she tried her best to climb up one of the legs of the table, but it was too slippery; and when she had tired herself out with trying, the poor little thing sat down and cried.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
What a curious feeling!” said Alice; “I must be shutting up like a telescope.”

And so she was: she was now only ten inches high, and her foot, which had a little while ago been pressed against her chest, was now hanging down, and she could look over it at her own shoes and stockings, and see if they were tidy: about this, she need not trouble herself, for she had not had time to change them since her change of size.

As she was peering down from it, along came her foot again, and she was just in time to catch it as it was going to come down and crush her. "What a pity!” she said, “I was just beginning to grow a little fatter, and I do so hate shrinking!”

She waited a little, half expecting to shrink away altogether, like a candle; but she soon found out that was not the case. She had not grown any taller, but she had grown a little fatter, and she was quite content to stay as she was.

She looked at the little door again, and thought how nice it would be to get through it, and see what was on the other side. She had a good many thoughts of this kind, and she was just beginning to imagine how she would manage it, when she suddenly remembered that she had left the golden key on the glass table. She ran back to it, but found that she was now too small to reach it: she could see it quite plainly through the glass, but she could not climb up the legs of the table, which were quite smooth and slippery.

She sat down and began to cry. "Oh, what a pity!” she said, “I was just beginning to get through the door, and now I can’t even get the key!"

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“What a curious feeling!” said Alice; “I must be shutting up like a telescope.”

And so she was, for her body was gradually shrinking, and she was now only about the size of a little doll. She looked up at the ceiling, which now seemed miles above her head, and the furniture, which had once seemed so large, now looked like tiny toys. “I wonder if I shall shrink no more?” she thought. “I can’t go on shrinking like this forever.”

Just then, she noticed a small bottle on the table, and on the label it said, “DRINK ME.”

Alice hesitated for a moment, then, remembering how often strange things had happened in Wonderland, she took a deep breath and drank the contents of the bottle. In a moment, she began to grow again, and soon she was her usual size.

“Phew!” she said, wiping her forehead. “That was a close call. I was beginning to feel quite cramped.”

She looked around the room, which now seemed just as it had before, and smiled to herself. “Well, at least I’m back to normal size again. I wonder what other surprises Wonderland has in store for me?”

events.title: Self-Reproach and the "EAT ME" Cake
detailed_summary: Alice sternly tells herself to stop crying, reflecting on her habit of giving herself good advice but rarely following it.
She recalls sometimes scolding herself severely, even to the point of tears, and remembers once trying to punish herself for cheating in a solitary game of croquet.
She acknowledges her fondness for pretending to be two separate people.
She thinks sadly that now, being so small, there isn't enough of her left to even convincingly pretend to be one person.
Her attention is caught by a small glass box under the table.
Inside the box, she finds a tiny cake with "EAT ME" marked on it in currants.
Alice decides to eat the cake, reasoning that if it makes her grow larger, she can reach the key, and if it makes her smaller, she can slip under the door.
Either outcome will allow her entry to the garden, so she doesn't mind which way it works.
She takes a small bite and anxiously wonders which effect it will have, placing her hand on her head to feel for growth.
She is surprised to find her size remains unchanged.
She reflects that while staying the same size after eating cake is normal, she has become so accustomed to extraordinary events that normalcy now seems dull.
Resolving to see it through, Alice proceeds to eat the entire cake.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Come, there’s no use in crying like that!” said Alice to herself, rather sharply; “I advise you to leave off this minute!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So she set to work, and very soon finished off the cake.

events.text_segment:
“Come, there’s no use in crying like that!” said Alice to herself, rather sharply; “I advise you to leave off this minute!” She generally gave herself very good advice, (though she very seldom followed it), and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes; and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself, for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people. “But it’s no use now,” thought poor Alice, “to pretend to be two people! Why, there’s hardly enough of me left to make one respectable person!”
Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table: she opened it, and found in it a very small cake, on which the words “EAT ME” were beautifully marked in currants. “Well, I’ll eat it,” said Alice, “and if it makes me grow larger, I can reach the key; and if it makes me grow smaller, I can creep under the door; so either way I’ll get into the garden, and I don’t care which happens!”
She ate a little bit, and said anxiously to herself, “Which way? Which way?”, holding her hand on the top of her head to feel which way it was growing, and she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size: to be sure, this generally happens when one eats cake, but Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-the-way things to happen, that it seemed quite dull and stupid for life to go on in the common way.
So she set to work, and very soon finished off the cake.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Come, there’s no use in crying like that!” said Alice to herself, rather sharply; “I advise you to leave off this minute!” She usually gave herself very good advice (though she very seldom followed it), and she always spoke to herself in a business-like manner, as if she were a second person. “Come, now!” she said, “let me see—You know I can’t reach the key: how is it that I managed to shrink so much in the first place? And how am I to get out again?” And she began to cry again, in a great fury, for she was very much frightened as well as very angry with herself.

She tried to scold herself, but it only made her cry the more. “I’m a very bad child,” she said, “and I deserve punishment!” And she went on crying, and rubbing her eyes with her fists, until she began to see double, and the room looked quite different from what it had done before. “I wish I hadn’t been so careless,” she said, “and eaten that cake without looking at it first. I remember now, I was playing croquet with the Queen of Hearts, and I cheated, and she said I was a very bad child, and I cried so much that I made a puddle on the grass.”

She stopped crying for a moment, and looked about her. “I wish I could be two people,” she said, “then one could comfort the other.” But she soon gave up that idea, for she thought it would be very lonely to be only one person, and she had never been able to pretend very well. “I wish I were a little girl again,” she said, “then I could pretend to be two people, and one could be kind to the other.”

But she was so small now that she could not even pretend to be one person, and that made her feel very sad. She looked under the table, and there was a little glass box, with a lid on it. She opened it, and found a tiny cake inside, with “EAT ME” marked on it in currants. “Well, I might as well try it,” she said, “for I can’t get any smaller than I am now, and if it makes me grow larger, I can reach the key, and if it makes me smaller, I can slip under the door. Either way, I shall get into the garden, and that is what I want.”

So she took a little bite, and anxiously wondered which way it would work, and put her hand on her head to feel if she was growing. But she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size. “Well!” she said, “that is very strange. I thought I should either grow larger or smaller, but I remain just the same. I suppose it is because I have been so used to strange things happening that I have got to expect the ordinary to be strange.”

And with that, she resolved to see it through, and she ate the whole cake, and it tasted very nice.

Come, there’s no use in crying like that!” said Alice to herself, rather sharply; “I advise you to leave off this minute!” She usually gave herself very good advice (though she very seldom followed it), and she always spoke to herself in a business-like manner, as if she were a second person. “Come, now!” she said, “let me see—You know I can’t reach the key: how is it that I managed to shrink so much in the first place? And how am I to get out again?” And she began to cry again, in a great fury, for she was very much frightened as well as very angry with herself.

She tried to scold herself, but it only made her cry the more. “I’m a very bad child,” she said, “and I deserve punishment!” And she went on crying, and rubbing her eyes with her fists, until she began to see double, and the room looked quite different from what it had done before. “I wish I hadn’t been so careless,” she said, “and eaten that cake without looking at it first. I remember now, I was playing croquet with the Queen of Hearts, and I cheated, and she said I was a very bad child, and I cried so much that I made a puddle on the grass.”

All at once she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and looking up, she saw a White Rabbit with pink eyes running wildly about his waistcoat, and muttering to himself, “Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be too late!” Alice was so much surprised that for a moment she forgot to cry. She stared at the Rabbit, who was still muttering and running about, and then she suddenly remembered that she was in the middle of a forest, and that she had no idea how she had got there. “I must be dreaming,” she thought, “or else I am mad. But I don’t feel mad. I feel quite sensible.” She got up and followed the Rabbit, who was now running in a straight line, and she followed as fast as she could. The Rabbit ran into a large rabbit hole, and Alice, not knowing what else to do, followed him. She found that she was in a long passage, and at the end of it was a small door, which was locked. She looked around and found a key on a table, and with it she unlocked the door. But when she opened it, she found that she was too small to get through. She looked around again and found a bottle on the table with a label that read, “Drink me.” She hesitated for a moment, but then she took a sip, and immediately she began to grow taller. She grew and grew until she was just the right size to fit through the door. She stepped through and found herself in a beautiful garden, where everything was in perfect order and the flowers were talking to each other. She was very happy to be there, and she decided to explore the garden and see what wonders it held.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER II. The Pool of Tears

events.title: Alice's Telescopic Growth and Plans for Her Feet
detailed_summary: Alice exclaims in surprise at her rapid growth, comparing her elongating body to a telescope and momentarily forgetting proper grammar.
She addresses her feet, which appear incredibly distant, bidding them farewell.
She ponders who will now manage the task of putting on their shoes and stockings, concluding she will be too far away to handle it herself.
Alice decides she must treat her feet kindly to ensure they walk where she wants, devising a plan to send them a new pair of boots every Christmas.
She considers the logistics, thinking they must be sent by carrier and finding the idea of sending presents to one's own feet amusing.
She imagines the peculiar address format required for such a delivery.
Alice abruptly recognizes the absurdity of her thoughts, chiding herself for talking nonsense.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Curiouser and curiouser!” cried Alice (she was so much surprised, that for the moment she quite forgot how to speak good English); “now I’m opening out like the largest telescope that ever was! Good-bye, feet!” (for when she looked down at her feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off).
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Oh dear, what nonsense I’m talking!”

events.text_segment:
“Curiouser and curiouser!” cried Alice (she was so much surprised, that for the moment she quite forgot how to speak good English); “now I’m opening out like the largest telescope that ever was! Good-bye, feet!” (for when she looked down at her feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off). “Oh, my poor little feet, I wonder who will put on your shoes and stockings for you now, dears? I’m sure I shan’t be able! I shall be a great deal too far off to trouble myself about you: you must manage the best way you can;—but I must be kind to them,” thought Alice, “or perhaps they won’t walk the way I want to go! Let me see: I’ll give them a new pair of boots every Christmas.”
And she went on planning to herself how she would manage it. “They must go by the carrier,” she thought; “and how funny it’ll seem, sending presents to one’s own feet! And how odd the directions will look!
Alice’s Right Foot, Esq.,
Hearthrug,
near the Fender,
(with Alice’s love).
Oh dear, what nonsense I’m talking!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: "Curiouser and curiouser!" cried Alice (she was so much surprised, that for the moment she quite forgot how to speak good English); "now I'm opening out like the largest telescope that ever was! Good-bye, feet!" (for when she looked down at her feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off). "Who is to put on my shoes and stockings?" she thought to herself, and, just as she said the words, her neck began to shrink, till she was little enough to get on with her shoes and stockings at once again. "Well!" thought Alice, "I've often seen a cat without a grin, but a grin without a cat! It's the most curious thing I ever saw in all my life!" Just then her foot, which was nearly out of the window, caught the eye of a little creature, who was peeping into the room. "What an extraordinary little figure!" thought the creature. "It has, in some ways, a more natural appearance than a real baby." The creature was a mouse, and it was so much frightened that it ran away immediately. "Now I'm opening out like the largest telescope that ever was!" cried Alice again. "I wish I could shut up like a telescope: this last bit of me is too much for me." She folded herself up as well as she could, and was just in time to avoid being carried off by a large pigeon, who had mistaken her for a balloon, and was going to carry her into the air. "I'm a poor little thing," she said in a trembling voice, "but I can explain every thing!" The pigeon looked at her rather suspiciously, and said, "Can you clean the platters?" "I've a very little way of doing things," said Alice, "but I'm not at all sure I know the right way. I'm afraid I should have to clean them with soap and water." "That's exactly what I thought you'd say," said the pigeon. "You're a little bird, I'm sure." "I'm a little girl," said Alice, very earnestly. "Well, then," said the pigeon, "you're a little serpent, I suppose." "I'm not a little serpent," said Alice, "and that's certainly the worst thing I can call myself." "A little fish, then?" said the pigeon. "I'm not a little fish," said Alice. "A little tea-pot?" "I'm not a little tea-pot," said Alice, "but I know very well I'm not a little serpent or a little fish or a little tea-pot." "Well, then you're a little—" the pigeon began. "A little what?" said Alice, who was beginning to be quite tired of the conversation. "A little—" the pigeon repeated, and was going to say something more, but Alice gave a sudden leap up, and was gone before it could finish the word. She found herself sitting on the bank of a broad, slow river, with a great forest all round her. The trees were all of a peculiar kind, and the leaves were of the most brilliant green. "I wonder if I've been changed in the night?" thought Alice. "I can't remember things as I used to. I'm afraid I've begun to grow up." She looked down at her hands and feet, and was rather surprised to find that she had grown so tall. "I'm getting so large," she said, "that I shall be out of the room in a minute. I shall have to get behind the door, I suppose." She crept quietly behind the door, and peeped out. The room was quite empty, except for a large mirror that stood in one corner. "I wonder if I've been changed in the night?" thought Alice again. "I can't remember things as I used to. I'm afraid I've begun to grow up." events.title: Reaching Giant Size and Crying a Pool of Tears
detailed_summary: Alice's head hits the ceiling, confirming she has grown excessively tall (over nine feet).
She immediately picks up the golden key and rushes to the garden door.
Realizing she is far too large to fit, she lies down and manages only to peek into the garden with one eye.
Feeling utterly hopeless about entering the garden, she sits down and starts crying again.
Alice admonishes herself for crying, thinking a large girl like her should be ashamed.
Despite her self-reproach, her weeping continues uncontrollably, resulting in a substantial pool of tears forming around her, deep enough to reach halfway down the hall.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Just then her head struck against the roof of the hall: in fact she was now more than nine feet high, and she at once took up the little golden key and hurried off to the garden door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But she went on all the same, shedding gallons of tears, until there was a large pool all round her, about four inches deep and reaching half down the hall.

events.text_segment:
Just then her head struck against the roof of the hall: in fact she was now more than nine feet high, and she at once took up the little golden key and hurried off to the garden door.
Poor Alice! It was as much as she could do, lying down on one side, to look through into the garden with one eye; but to get through was more hopeless than ever: she sat down and began to cry again.
“You ought to be ashamed of yourself,” said Alice, “a great girl like you,” (she might well say this), “to go on crying in this way! Stop this moment, I tell you!” But she went on all the same, shedding gallons of tears, until there was a large pool all round her, about four inches deep and reaching half down the hall.

events.title: The White Rabbit's Hasty Return and Flight
detailed_summary: Hearing approaching footsteps, Alice quickly dries her tears to see who it is.
The White Rabbit reappears, well-dressed and carrying white kid gloves and a large fan.
He hurries along, muttering anxiously about the Duchess and the consequences of being late.
Alice feels desperate enough to seek help from anyone, including the Rabbit.
As the Rabbit draws near, she addresses him in a quiet, timid voice.
The Rabbit reacts with extreme fright, dropping his gloves and fan.
He immediately bolts away into the darkness at top speed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After a time she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The Rabbit started violently, dropped the white kid gloves and the fan, and skurried away into the darkness as hard as he could go.

events.text_segment: After a time she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming. It was the White Rabbit returning, splendidly dressed, with a pair of white kid gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other: he came trotting along in a great hurry, muttering to himself as he came, “Oh! the Duchess, the Duchess! Oh! won’t she be savage if I’ve kept her waiting!” Alice felt so desperate that she was ready to ask help of any one; so, when the Rabbit came near her, she began, in a low, timid voice, “If you please, sir—” The Rabbit started violently, dropped the white kid gloves and the fan, and skurried away into the darkness as hard as he could go.

After a time she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming. It was the White Rabbit returning, and looking anxiously about as he did so, sometimes pausing to listen, and sometimes to look down at his watch, and once or twice shouting, "Oh, my ears and whiskers, how late it’s getting!" He was well-dressed, with a waistcoat and a pocket-handkerchief, and he carried a pair of white kid gloves in one hand, and a large fan in the other: you might have taken him for a coachman.

Alice felt so desperate that she was ready to ask help of anyone; so, when the Rabbit next paused in his journey, she ran up to him, and said in a timid voice, "Please, sir, speak to me! Do tell me, please, which way I must go from here?"

The Rabbit started violently, dropped the white kid gloves and the fan, and scurried away into the darkness as hard as he could go.

events.title: Alice's Identity Crisis and Failed Recitations
detailed_summary: Alice picks up the fan and gloves left behind by the Rabbit.
Feeling the heat of the hall, she fans herself while reflecting aloud.
She remarks on the strangeness of the current day compared to the normality of the previous one.
She questions if she underwent a transformation overnight, recalling feeling slightly different upon waking.
Pondering her identity becomes a central puzzle: "Who in the world am I?"
She considers other girls her age, Ada and Mabel, trying to discern if she has been swapped with one of them.
She dismisses being Ada due to differing hairstyles and Mabel due to perceived differences in knowledge, yet remains puzzled about her own identity.
To test herself, she tries reciting multiplication facts but gets them consistently wrong.
She attempts geography, misidentifying capital cities, which reinforces her fear of having become Mabel.
She tries reciting a familiar poem, "How doth the little busy bee," but her voice sounds strange, and the words emerge as a poem about a crocodile.
Certain these aren't the correct words, Alice's eyes fill with tears again as she concludes she must be Mabel.
She anticipates a future life as Mabel, with a small house, few toys, and many lessons.
She firmly decides that if she is indeed Mabel, she will refuse to leave her current location.
She imagines people calling down to her and plans to demand they identify her first before she considers returning.
Overcome with emotion, she cries out suddenly, expressing her deep weariness of being alone and wishing someone would appear.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Alice took up the fan and gloves, and, as the hall was very hot, she kept fanning herself all the time she went on talking: “Dear, dear! How queer everything is to-day!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I am so very tired of being all alone here!”

events.text_segment:
Alice took up the fan and gloves, and, as the hall was very hot, she kept fanning herself all the time she went on talking: “Dear, dear! How queer everything is to-day! And yesterday things went on just as usual. I wonder if I’ve been changed in the night? Let me think: was I the same when I got up this morning? I almost think I can remember feeling a little different. But if I’m not the same, the next question is, Who in the world am I? Ah, that’s the great puzzle!” And she began thinking over all the children she knew that were of the same age as herself, to see if she could have been changed for any of them.
“I’m sure I’m not Ada,” she said, “for her hair goes in such long ringlets, and mine doesn’t go in ringlets at all; and I’m sure I can’t be Mabel, for I know all sorts of things, and she, oh! she knows such a very little! Besides, she’s she, and I’m I, and—oh dear, how puzzling it all is! I’ll try if I know all the things I used to know. Let me see: four times five is twelve, and four times six is thirteen, and four times seven is—oh dear! I shall never get to twenty at that rate! However, the Multiplication Table doesn’t signify: let’s try Geography. London is the capital of Paris, and Paris is the capital of Rome, and Rome—no, that’s all wrong, I’m certain! I must have been changed for Mabel! I’ll try and say ‘How doth the little—’” and she crossed her hands on her lap as if she were saying lessons, and began to repeat it, but her voice sounded hoarse and strange, and the words did not come the same as they used to do:—
“How doth the little crocodile
    Improve his shining tail,
And pour the waters of the Nile
    On every golden scale!

“How cheerfully he seems to grin,
    How neatly spread his claws,
And welcome little fishes in
    With gently smiling jaws!”
“I’m sure those are not the right words,” said poor Alice, and her eyes filled with tears again as she went on, “I must be Mabel after all, and I shall have to go and live in that poky little house, and have next to no toys to play with, and oh! ever so many lessons to learn! No, I’ve made up my mind about it; if I’m Mabel, I’ll stay down here! It’ll be no use their putting their heads down and saying ‘Come up again, dear!’ I shall only look up and say ‘Who am I then? Tell me that first, and then, if I like being that person, I’ll come up: if not, I’ll stay down here till I’m somebody else’—but, oh dear!” cried Alice, with a sudden burst of tears, “I do wish they would put their heads down! I am so very tired of being all alone here!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Alice took up the fan and gloves, and, as the hall was very hot, she kept fanning herself all the time she went on talking: “Dear, dear! How queer everything is to-day! I do wish I had somebody here like Mamma! Or else I’d like to be Mamma, at least, and have a little conversation with myself—when I can’t get rid of this ridiculous grin.’ (She had noticed with some confusion that the grin remained on her face when she made no attempt to smile, and she was just going to try and remove it when the Rabbit came in.)

“I wonder if I’ve changed in the night?” she thought; and she jumped up and down in a great fright, trying to find out. “I’m afraid I may have been changed for Mabel! I’m afraid I may have been changed for Mabel! She’s older than I am—we were always told not to quarrel—and she always has such a good temper!”

A sudden thought struck her. “But I’m the right size for Ada,” she said aloud. “Let me look and see. Oh, Mabel is older than Ada!” (Alice thought she could remember feeling a little different this morning, but she could not exactly make out what the difference was. “I’m not going to fetch up like this for the rest of my life, at any rate,” she said, with a deep sigh.)

“Who in the world am I?” thought poor Alice. “I can’t tell. I’m a great deal too confused to find out.”

She sat down on the floor, and began to cry again. “Oh, what a long day it has been!” she said. “I wonder if I’ve been changed for Mabel? I’m afraid I have. I don’t think I’ve ever been this tall before. I’m afraid I’ve been changed for Mabel!”

She tried to recite a multiplication table, but it came out wrong. “Four times five is twelve,” she said, “and four times six is thirteen, and four times seven is—oh dear, I shall never get to twenty at that rate!”

She tried geography. “London is the capital of England,” she said, “and Paris is the capital of France, and Rome is the capital of Italy, and Vienna is the capital of Austria, and—”

She paused. “I don’t believe I’m Mabel,” she said. “I’m afraid I’m not. I don’t think I’ve ever been in Austria. I don’t believe I’m Mabel at all. I’m afraid I’m Ada.”

She tried to recite a poem. “How doth the little busy bee,” she began, “explore the fields of blooming flowers—” but the words came out wrong. “How doth the little crocodile,” she said, “improve his shining tail?”

She stopped again. “I don’t believe I’m Ada,” she said. “I don’t think I’ve ever been in a field of flowers. I don’t believe I’m Ada at all. I’m afraid I’m Mabel.”

She sat down again and began to cry. “I wish I had somebody here to talk to!” she said. “I’m tired of being alone. I wish I had somebody to talk to!”

She cried so hard that she began to sob, and the tears came faster and faster, until they formed a little pool all round her, and she was sitting in the middle of it, like a little island.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Alice took up the fan and gloves, and, as the hall was very hot, she kept fanning herself all the time she went on talking: “Dear, dear! How queer everything is to-day! I do wish I had not gone into that looking-glass room—I shall never get out again, I fancy. Oh, I wish I could have this moment fixed!” (But she had not a camera, and she was not quite sure how to fix a moment, so she gave it up.)

As she said this, she came upon a neat little house, about the size of a doll's house: the roof was only a few inches high, and the windows were mere slits in the walls. There was a little door, about a foot high: she tried it, but of course it was locked.

“Then I shall have to find some way of getting in,” said Alice, and she sat down on the ground before the door, and began to cry.

She had not cried for nearly an hour, and she felt very tired of crying by this time. However, she went on with it a little longer, and then dried her eyes. “When I get to my home,” she said to herself, “I shall have a good cry, and then I shall be all right again.”

She went on talking to herself, for she was afraid of being alone in the hall. “I wonder if I shall fall right through the earth! How funny it'll seem, going down and down like this! I wonder if I shall meet with a person larger than myself at the other end of the world!”

She was still talking thus, when she heard a little pattering of feet in the hall, and she jumped up in a great fright. It was only a mouse, running away from something, or perhaps from nothing. Alice called out as loud as she could, “Halloo! Come back again!” but the mouse did not hear her, or perhaps it was too frightened to stop.

Alice sat down again, and began to cry all over again. “I wish I hadn’t been such a bad child!” she said to herself, and she began to cry again more bitterly than before.

Just then her eye fell upon a little bottle, about the size of a decanter, and with two small corks in it, which was lying under the table. “Only mark this bottle,” said Alice, “‘DRINK ME,’ and the label is half-erased!”

Alice uncorked it, and tried a little drop with her finger to see if it was nice: it had a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart, custard, and a little of salt, and then she drank some more, and then she drank the whole of it, and then she began to grow smaller and smaller, till she was not much more than three inches high!

“Now I shall be too small to get out at all,” she said in a sorrowful tone, and she began to cry again. But she soon checked herself, for she heard a voice outside the door, and she knew it must be the voice of the Queen of Hearts, for it was very shrill and commanding. “Off with her head!” it said. “Off with her head!”

Alice was so frightened that she could not even cry, and she crept behind the door, hoping to escape notice. But the door opened, and in came the Queen, with a great train of soldiers, all shouting, “Off with her head! Off with her head!”

Alice was so small that she could not run away, and she was very much afraid of being beheaded. But just then she remembered the little bottle, and she took a little more of the liquid, and began to grow larger and larger, till she was quite a large girl again, and the Queen and her soldiers were all very much surprised.

events.title: Shrinking Rapidly While Holding the Fan
detailed_summary: While lamenting her solitude, Alice looks at her hands and is surprised to find she is wearing one of the White Rabbit's small gloves.
She immediately infers that she must be shrinking again.
Standing up, she goes to the table to gauge her height against it.
She estimates herself to be only about two feet tall and realizes she is continuing to shrink quickly.
She quickly deduces that the fan she holds is causing the shrinking effect.
Reacting instantly, she drops the fan, narrowly preventing herself from shrinking completely out of existence.

events.title: Narrow Escape, Renewed Frustration, and Falling into the Pool of Tears
detailed_summary: Alice expresses a mix of fear and relief after barely escaping obliteration by shrinking.
Happy to still be present, she resolves to try entering the garden once more and runs to the small door.
She discovers, to her dismay, that the door is closed again and the vital golden key rests inaccessible on the glass table.
Alice feels the situation has deteriorated further, noting she's never been this small before and calling the circumstances 'too bad'.
As she voices her frustration, her foot slips.
She plunges into salt water, finding herself submerged up to her chin.
Initially, she thinks she has fallen into the sea and recalls seaside holidays, imagining she could return home via railway.
She soon corrects herself, realizing she is swimming in the pool formed from her own tears wept when she was giant-sized.
Alice regrets her excessive crying, speculating she might now be punished by drowning in her tears.
She reflects that such an event would be peculiar, but then again, the entire day has been strange.

And I declare it’s too bad, that it is!”

events.text_segment:
“That was a narrow escape!” said Alice, a good deal frightened at the sudden change, but very glad to find herself still in existence; “and now for the garden!” and she ran with all speed back to the little door: but, alas! the little door was shut again, and the little golden key was lying on the glass table as before, “and things are worse than ever,” thought the poor child, “for I never was so small as this before, never! And I declare it’s too bad, that it is!”
As she said these words her foot slipped, and in another moment, splash! she was up to her chin in salt water. Her first idea was that she had somehow fallen into the sea, “and in that case I can go back by railway,” she said to herself. (Alice had been to the seaside once in her life, and had come to the general conclusion, that wherever you go to on the English coast you find a number of bathing machines in the sea, some children digging in the sand with wooden spades, then a row of lodging houses, and behind them a railway station.) However, she soon made out that she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when she was nine feet high.
“I wish I hadn’t cried so much!” said Alice, as she swam about, trying to find her way out. “I shall be punished for it now, I suppose, by being drowned in my own tears! That will be a queer thing, to be sure! However, everything is queer to-day.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
That was a narrow escape!” said Alice, a good deal frightened at the sudden change, but very glad to find herself still in existence; “and now for the garden!” and she ran with all speed back to the little door: but, alas! the little door was shut again, and the little golden key was lying on the glass table as before, “and things are worse than ever,” thought the poor child, “for I never was so small as this before, never! And I declare it’s too bad, that it is!”

She sat down, and began to cry again, feeling certain that she might sit there for days, and never get out again: “unless,” thought she, “some of the things in the garden have the key on them, and know how to open the door—it would be too much nonsense otherwise.” But she could not even reach the key, so small had she grown: she might as well try to open the door with a thimble, or to turn it into a doorknob with a needle.

She began to cry again, and as she cried, she left a great pool of water on the floor, about her. After a time she heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming. But all she could see, was that many small bitter drops of water (for she had been crying again, the size of the drops made all the difference) were splashing about in the pool of tears, making quite a rough sea of it.

After a while she heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming. But all she could see, was that many small bitter drops of water (for she had been crying again, the size of the drops made all the difference) were splashing about in the pool of tears, making quite a rough sea of it.

There was nothing so very remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so very much out of the way to hear the sea in the distance. “I wish I had some bread and butter with me,” she said, “but I’ve come down in such a hurry, I haven’t had time to dress properly.”

Then she suddenly felt a violent inclination to sneeze, and she did sneeze, and at the same moment a large wave of water came rolling over her, and she was carried off her feet, and down, down, down, into the pool of tears.

I’m out at last!”

events.title: Awkward Conversation and Repeatedly Offending the Mouse
detailed_summary: While swimming, Alice hears nearby splashing.
Initially suspecting a large animal like a walrus, she remembers her current small size and identifies the creature as a mouse, also fallen into the pool.
She contemplates speaking to the Mouse, figuring that in such an unusual environment, talking animals might be possible.
She addresses the Mouse formally, using a Latin grammar structure to ask for directions out of the pool.
The Mouse observes her curiously, perhaps winking, but remains silent.
Alice hypothesizes the Mouse might be French and unfamiliar with English.
She tries French, uttering the first sentence from her lesson book, inadvertently asking about her cat.
The Mouse reacts with a sudden leap and visible fright.
Alice hastily apologizes, realizing her blunder about mice and cats.
The Mouse retorts sharply, questioning if Alice would appreciate cats if she were a mouse.
Attempting to soothe the Mouse, Alice nonetheless begins praising her own cat, Dinah, mentioning her quiet nature and skill at catching mice before realizing her mistake mid-praise.
Apologizing again as the Mouse shows clear signs of offense, bristling all over.
The Mouse passionately declares its family's hatred for cats ('nasty, low, vulgar things!') and forbids Alice from mentioning them again.
Alice quickly agrees and attempts to change the subject by asking if the Mouse likes dogs.
Receiving no answer, she eagerly describes a neighbor's terrier, detailing its tricks, value, and proficiency in killing rats, once more realizing ('oh dear!') she has likely caused offense.
The Mouse abruptly swims away from Alice at high speed, visibly agitated and disturbing the water.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Just then she heard something splashing about in the pool a little way off, and she swam nearer to make out what it was: at first she thought it must be a walrus or hippopotamus, but then she remembered how small she was now, and she soon made out that it was only a mouse that had slipped in like herself.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: For the Mouse was swimming away from her as hard as it could go, and making quite a commotion in the pool as it went.

events.text_segment:
Just then she heard something splashing about in the pool a little way off, and she swam nearer to make out what it was: at first she thought it must be a walrus or hippopotamus, but then she remembered how small she was now, and she soon made out that it was only a mouse that had slipped in like herself.
“Would it be of any use, now,” thought Alice, “to speak to this mouse? Everything is so out-of-the-way down here, that I should think very likely it can talk: at any rate, there’s no harm in trying.” So she began: “O Mouse, do you know the way out of this pool? I am very tired of swimming about here, O Mouse!” (Alice thought this must be the right way of speaking to a mouse: she had never done such a thing before, but she remembered having seen in her brother’s Latin Grammar, “A mouse—of a mouse—to a mouse—a mouse—O mouse!”) The Mouse looked at her rather inquisitively, and seemed to her to wink with one of its little eyes, but it said nothing.
“Perhaps it doesn’t understand English,” thought Alice; “I daresay it’s a French mouse, come over with William the Conqueror.” (For, with all her knowledge of history, Alice had no very clear notion how long ago anything had happened.) So she began again: “Où est ma chatte?” which was the first sentence in her French lesson-book. The Mouse gave a sudden leap out of the water, and seemed to quiver all over with fright. “Oh, I beg your pardon!” cried Alice hastily, afraid that she had hurt the poor animal’s feelings. “I quite forgot you didn’t like cats.”
“Not like cats!” cried the Mouse, in a shrill, passionate voice. “Would you like cats if you were me?”
“Well, perhaps not,” said Alice in a soothing tone: “don’t be angry about it. And yet I wish I could show you our cat Dinah: I think you’d take a fancy to cats if you could only see her. She is such a dear quiet thing,” Alice went on, half to herself, as she swam lazily about in the pool, “and she sits purring so nicely by the fire, licking her paws and washing her face—and she is such a nice soft thing to nurse—and she’s such a capital one for catching mice—oh, I beg your pardon!” cried Alice again, for this time the Mouse was bristling all over, and she felt certain it must be really offended. “We won’t talk about her any more if you’d rather not.”
“We indeed!” cried the Mouse, who was trembling down to the end of his tail. “As if I would talk on such a subject! Our family always hated cats: nasty, low, vulgar things! Don’t let me hear the name again!”
“I won’t indeed!” said Alice, in a great hurry to change the subject of conversation. “Are you—are you fond—of—of dogs?” The Mouse did not answer, so Alice went on eagerly: “There is such a nice little dog near our house I should like to show you! A little bright-eyed terrier, you know, with oh, such long curly brown hair! And it’ll fetch things when you throw them, and it’ll sit up and beg for its dinner, and all sorts of things—I can’t remember half of them—and it belongs to a farmer, you know, and he says it’s so useful, it’s worth a hundred pounds! He says it kills all the rats and—oh dear!” cried Alice in a sorrowful tone, “I’m afraid I’ve offended it again!” For the Mouse was swimming away from her as hard as it could go, and making quite a commotion in the pool as it went.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Just then she heard something splashing about in the pool a little way off, and she swam nearer to make out what it was: at first she thought it must be a walrus or hippopotamus, but then she remembered how small she was now, and she soon made out that it was only a mouse that had slipped in like herself. "I wish I could talk to it," said Alice, "but I'm afraid it won't understand me." As she said this, she came suddenly upon a large fan that lay floating on the water, and, with an impulsive gesture, she seized it and began to fan herself with it. The mouse, which had been quietly swimming in a circle, gave a loud shriek and nearly swam out of the pool in alarm. "I beg your pardon," cried Alice hastily, "I didn't mean to frighten you. I was only fanning myself, for I was getting quite warm." The mouse, after a moment's hesitation, replied in a trembling voice, "I hope you don't mind my asking, but are you a friend of the Duchess?" "I don't even know who the Duchess is," said Alice, "but I should be very glad to be her friend if she would like to have me." The mouse seemed much relieved at this answer, and began to swim more calmly. "I live in a house just beyond the tulgey wood," it said, "and I'm always very careful to keep out of the way of the Duchess, for she's a most terrible cross old thing. I once had the misfortune to be invited to one of her tea parties, and I can assure you it was the most disagreeable experience of my life. The cook was a very bad-tempered creature, and the baby was quite out of control. I believe it was a pig, or something of that sort." "A baby?" said Alice, with a puzzled look. "Yes, a baby," replied the mouse, "though I must say it looked more like a pig than a baby. It was dressed in a sort of frilled apron, and it kept squealing and kicking its legs about in the most alarming manner. I was quite frightened, and I made my escape as soon as I could." "I'm very sorry to hear that," said Alice, "but I don't think I've ever met the Duchess. I came here by accident, you see, and I've been wandering about ever since. I was once a great deal larger, but now I'm quite small, and I'm not at all sure what I'm going to do next." The mouse looked at her with a mixture of curiosity and sympathy. "You're in a very strange place," it said, "and I can quite understand how bewildered you must feel. But don't worry, I'm sure things will turn out all right in the end. I'm always telling myself that, and it usually helps a little." "That's very kind of you," said Alice, "and I'm very grateful for your company. I was beginning to feel quite lonely in this pool. I wonder if you'd like to come up to the bank with me? I think I can manage to get out now, and I'd be very glad to have a friend to talk to." The mouse looked doubtful. "I'm not sure about that," it said, "for I'm not at all certain that it's safe to be seen on the bank. The Duchess might be about, and I really don't want to run the risk of being invited to another tea party." "Then I'll go alone," said Alice, "and I'll come back for you as soon as I can. I promise I won't be long." The mouse gave a little sigh and nodded its head. "Very well," it said, "but please be careful, and don't mention me to the Duchess if you meet her. I've had quite enough of her for one lifetime." "I won't," said Alice, "and I hope we'll meet again soon. Good-bye!" And with that, she swam to the edge of the pool and climbed out, leaving the mouse to continue its quiet swimming in the water below.

events.title: Reconciliation with the Mouse and Exodus to Shore
detailed_summary: Alice calls out gently to the fleeing Mouse, using an endearing term.
She invites it back, promising to avoid discussing cats or dogs if they are subjects the Mouse dislikes.
The Mouse hears her, halts, turns, and slowly swims back.
Its face looks pale, which Alice interprets as a sign of strong emotion (passion or anger).
In a low, trembling voice, the Mouse proposes they reach the shore first.
It promises to then relate its personal history, which will explain its hatred of cats and dogs.
The narrative notes the pool has become crowded with other birds and animals (Duck, Dodo, Lory, Eaglet, etc.) that have also fallen in, making departure timely.
Alice assumes leadership, and the entire assembled group begins swimming towards the shore.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So she called softly after it, “Mouse dear! Do come back again, and we won’t talk about cats or dogs either, if you don’t like them!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Alice led the way, and the whole party swam to the shore.

events.text_segment:
So she called softly after it, “Mouse dear! Do come back again, and we won’t talk about cats or dogs either, if you don’t like them!” When the Mouse heard this, it turned round and swam slowly back to her: its face was quite pale (with passion, Alice thought), and it said in a low trembling voice, “Let us get to the shore, and then I’ll tell you my history, and you’ll understand why it is I hate cats and dogs.”
It was high time to go, for the pool was getting quite crowded with the birds and animals that had fallen into it: there were a Duck and a Dodo, a Lory and an Eaglet, and several other curious creatures. Alice led the way, and the whole party swam to the shore.

```text
So she called softly after it, “Mouse dear! Do come back again, and we won’t talk about cats or dogs either, if you don’t like them!” 

The Mouse paused mid-swim, its tiny whiskers twitching as it turned its head toward Alice. For a moment, it seemed uncertain, its eyes wide with something between fear and curiosity. Then, with a slow, deliberate motion, it began to swim back, its movements cautious and deliberate. 

As it neared, Alice noticed how pale the Mouse’s face had become, its fur slightly matted from the water. “I am not angry,” the Mouse said in a hushed, trembling voice, “but I would rather reach the shore before we speak further. There is much to tell, and I would not have it overheard.” 

Alice nodded, understanding the Mouse’s unspoken urgency. Around them, the pool had grown crowded with other curious creatures—Duck paddling awkwardly in circles, Dodo flapping its wings in confusion, Lory and Eaglet bobbing up and down in the water like two small, feathered corks. 

“Then lead the way,” Alice said gently, and with that, the Mouse set off toward the shore, the rest of the group following in a slow, determined procession.
```

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: So she called softly after it, “Mouse dear! Do come back again, and we won’t talk about cats or dogs either, if you don’t like them!” But the Mouse only shook its tail and walked a little quicker. Alice was very much frightened at first, for she thought it had come to bite her or push her into the river. But she soon made up her mind that it was only a timid sort of mouse, and she began to talk to it in a gentle voice. “You see, I’m not the sort of girl who bites,” she said, “and I’m sure you’re not the sort of mouse who bites, are you?” The Mouse looked at her in a puzzled sort of way, and then walked on a little faster still.
