events.title: A Wet Gathering and a Dry History Lesson
detailed_summary: A peculiar group comprising birds with wet feathers and animals with soaked fur, including Alice, gathers on the bank, all uncomfortable and cross.
The immediate concern is how to get dry, leading to a discussion where Alice finds herself naturally interacting with the creatures as if she'd known them forever.
Alice engages in a lengthy argument with a Lory regarding age and experience, which ends unsatisfactorily when the Lory refuses to disclose its age.
The Mouse, appearing as a figure of authority, commands everyone to sit in a circle and listen, promising a method to dry them quickly.
Alice focuses on the Mouse, concerned about getting dry to avoid illness.
The Mouse clears its throat importantly and begins reciting what it claims is the 'driest thing' it knows - a factual account of William the Conqueror and early English history.
The Lory interrupts with a shiver ('Ugh!'), prompting a polite but frowning inquiry from the Mouse.
The Lory quickly denies having spoken.
The Mouse resumes its recitation, detailing historical figures like Edwin, Morcar, and Stigand.
The Duck interrupts, asking what 'it' refers to when the Mouse mentions the archbishop finding 'it' advisable.
The Mouse dismissively answers 'it', assuming the meaning is obvious.
The Duck counters that when it finds something ('it'), it's usually a frog or worm, pressing the question of what the archbishop found.
Ignoring the Duck, the Mouse hurries on with the history lesson, mentioning William's initially moderate conduct.
The Mouse pauses to ask Alice how she is progressing with getting dry.
Alice responds sadly that she remains just as wet, confirming the history lesson's ineffectiveness as a drying method.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They were indeed a queer-looking party that assembled on the bank—the birds with draggled feathers, the animals with their fur clinging close to them, and all dripping wet, cross, and uncomfortable.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “As wet as ever,” said Alice in a melancholy tone: “it doesn’t seem to dry me at all.”

events.text_segment:
They were indeed a queer-looking party that assembled on the bank—the birds with draggled feathers, the animals with their fur clinging close to them, and all dripping wet, cross, and uncomfortable.
The first question of course was, how to get dry again: they had a consultation about this, and after a few minutes it seemed quite natural to Alice to find herself talking familiarly with them, as if she had known them all her life. Indeed, she had quite a long argument with the Lory, who at last turned sulky, and would only say, “I am older than you, and must know better;” and this Alice would not allow without knowing how old it was, and, as the Lory positively refused to tell its age, there was no more to be said.
At last the Mouse, who seemed to be a person of authority among them, called out, “Sit down, all of you, and listen to me! I’ll soon make you dry enough!” They all sat down at once, in a large ring, with the Mouse in the middle. Alice kept her eyes anxiously fixed on it, for she felt sure she would catch a bad cold if she did not get dry very soon.
“Ahem!” said the Mouse with an important air, “are you all ready? This is the driest thing I know. Silence all round, if you please! ‘William the Conqueror, whose cause was favoured by the pope, was soon submitted to by the English, who wanted leaders, and had been of late much accustomed to usurpation and conquest. Edwin and Morcar, the earls of Mercia and Northumbria—’”
“Ugh!” said the Lory, with a shiver.
“I beg your pardon!” said the Mouse, frowning, but very politely: “Did you speak?”
“Not I!” said the Lory hastily.
“I thought you did,” said the Mouse. “—I proceed. ‘Edwin and Morcar, the earls of Mercia and Northumbria, declared for him: and even Stigand, the patriotic archbishop of Canterbury, found it advisable—’”
“Found what?” said the Duck.
“Found it,” the Mouse replied rather crossly: “of course you know what ‘it’ means.”
“I know what ‘it’ means well enough, when I find a thing,” said the Duck: “it’s generally a frog or a worm. The question is, what did the archbishop find?”
The Mouse did not notice this question, but hurriedly went on, “‘—found it advisable to go with Edgar Atheling to meet William and offer him the crown. William’s conduct at first was moderate. But the insolence of his Normans—’ How are you getting on now, my dear?” it continued, turning to Alice as it spoke.
“As wet as ever,” said Alice in a melancholy tone: “it doesn’t seem to dry me at all.”

events.title: The Dodo Proposes a Caucus-Race
detailed_summary: Hearing Alice's lack of progress, the Dodo stands solemnly and formally proposes adjourning the meeting to pursue more effective drying methods.
An Eaglet interrupts, demanding the Dodo use simpler language ('Speak English!'), claiming ignorance of the long words and doubting the Dodo's own understanding, causing some birds to titter.
The Dodo, sounding offended, clarifies its suggestion: the best way to get dry is to have a Caucus-race.
Alice inquires about the nature of a Caucus-race, not out of deep curiosity but because the Dodo paused expectantly and no one else spoke.
The Dodo explains that the most effective way to understand a Caucus-race is to actually do it.
The narrator adds a parenthetical note, promising to explain the Dodo's method for organizing the race later.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “In that case,” said the Dodo solemnly, rising to its feet, “I move that the meeting adjourn, for the immediate adoption of more energetic remedies—”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: (And, as you might like to try the thing yourself, some winter day, I will tell you how the Dodo managed it.)

events.text_segment:
“In that case,” said the Dodo solemnly, rising to its feet, “I move that the meeting adjourn, for the immediate adoption of more energetic remedies—”
“Speak English!” said the Eaglet. “I don’t know the meaning of half those long words, and, what’s more, I don’t believe you do either!” And the Eaglet bent down its head to hide a smile: some of the other birds tittered audibly.
“What I was going to say,” said the Dodo in an offended tone, “was, that the best thing to get us dry would be a Caucus-race.”
“What is a Caucus-race?” said Alice; not that she wanted much to know, but the Dodo had paused as if it thought that somebody ought to speak, and no one else seemed inclined to say anything.
“Why,” said the Dodo, “the best way to explain it is to do it.” (And, as you might like to try the thing yourself, some winter day, I will tell you how the Dodo managed it.)

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"In that case," said the Dodo solemnly, rising to its feet, "I move that the meeting adjourn, for the immediate adoption of more energetic remedies—"

"Speak English!" said the Eaglet. "I don't know what you mean by 'energetic remedies.'"

"I meant, of course," said the Dodo, a little annoyed, "that the best way to get dry is to have a Caucus-race."

"What's a Caucus-race?" said Alice; not that she wanted much to know, but the Dodo had paused as if it expected her to speak.

"The best way to explain it," said the Dodo, "is to do it."

(And, as you might suppose, it was as much as they could do to get hold of the Dodo before it had found out half of them, and wrapped itself up in its own tail in a minute or two.)

events.title: The Chaotic Caucus-Race and Universal Prizes
detailed_summary: The Dodo sets up the race by drawing a roughly circular course and placing the participants haphazardly around it.
There is no formal start; participants begin and stop running whenever they wish, making the race's conclusion unclear.
After approximately half an hour, by which time everyone has dried off, the Dodo abruptly announces the end of the race.
The participants gather around the Dodo, eagerly asking who the winner is.
The Dodo requires significant time for thought, striking a contemplative pose, while the others wait silently.
Finally, the Dodo declares that everyone has won and, consequently, all must receive prizes.
A chorus of voices asks who will provide these prizes.
The Dodo points to Alice, designating her as the prize-giver.
Confused but prompted by the expectant crowd calling for 'Prizes!', Alice impulsively checks her pocket.
She finds a box of comfits (unharmed by the water) and distributes them, ensuring each participant receives exactly one.
The Mouse observes that Alice herself should receive a prize.
The Dodo agrees gravely and asks Alice what else she has in her pocket.
Alice sadly reveals she only has a thimble.
The Dodo instructs her to hand it over.
The group crowds around Alice again as the Dodo formally presents the thimble back to her as a prize, making a short, solemn speech of presentation, followed by cheers.
Alice perceives the entire event as ridiculous but refrains from laughing due to the serious demeanor of the others; unable to think of a response, she bows solemnly and accepts the thimble.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, (“the exact shape doesn’t matter,” it said,) and then all the party were placed along the course, here and there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Alice thought the whole thing very absurd, but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh; and, as she could not think of anything to say, she simply bowed, and took the thimble, looking as solemn as she could.

events.text_segment:
First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, (“the exact shape doesn’t matter,” it said,) and then all the party were placed along the course, here and there. There was no “One, two, three, and away,” but they began running when they liked, and left off when they liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over. However, when they had been running half an hour or so, and were quite dry again, the Dodo suddenly called out “The race is over!” and they all crowded round it, panting, and asking, “But who has won?”
This question the Dodo could not answer without a great deal of thought, and it sat for a long time with one finger pressed upon its forehead (the position in which you usually see Shakespeare, in the pictures of him), while the rest waited in silence. At last the Dodo said, “Everybody has won, and all must have prizes.”
“But who is to give the prizes?” quite a chorus of voices asked.
“Why, she, of course,” said the Dodo, pointing to Alice with one finger; and the whole party at once crowded round her, calling out in a confused way, “Prizes! Prizes!”
Alice had no idea what to do, and in despair she put her hand in her pocket, and pulled out a box of comfits, (luckily the salt water had not got into it), and handed them round as prizes. There was exactly one a-piece, all round.
“But she must have a prize herself, you know,” said the Mouse.
“Of course,” the Dodo replied very gravely. “What else have you got in your pocket?” he went on, turning to Alice.
“Only a thimble,” said Alice sadly.
“Hand it over here,” said the Dodo.
Then they all crowded round her once more, while the Dodo solemnly presented the thimble, saying “We beg your acceptance of this elegant thimble;” and, when it had finished this short speech, they all cheered.
Alice thought the whole thing very absurd, but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh; and, as she could not think of anything to say, she simply bowed, and took the thimble, looking as solemn as she could.

events.title: The Mouse's Sad Tale and Offense Taken
detailed_summary: The distribution and consumption of the comfits lead to some minor chaos, with larger birds complaining about the taste and smaller ones choking.
Once the comfits are finished, the group settles back into a ring and requests another story from the Mouse.
Alice specifically asks the Mouse to recount its history and explain its dislike for 'C and D,' whispering the letters cautiously.
The Mouse sighs and declares its tale to be 'long and sad'.

Alice, observing the Mouse's physical tail, misunderstands the word 'tale' and wonders aloud why its tail would be called sad, continuing to puzzle over this literal interpretation as the Mouse speaks.
The Mouse begins reciting a story presented visually as a winding tail, about a character named Fury attempting to prosecute a mouse without judge or jury, ultimately condemning it to death.
The Mouse interrupts its story to accuse Alice sternly of not paying attention and asks what she is thinking about.
Alice humbly apologizes, guessing the Mouse had reached the 'fifth bend,' referring to the shape of the tale/tail.
The Mouse reacts angrily, denying it had reached a 'bend,' seemingly interpreting Alice's word as 'knot'.
Alice, ever helpful, misunderstands the Mouse's anger and offers to help 'undo' the perceived knot.
The Mouse declares it will do no such thing, stating Alice is insulting it with nonsense, and begins to walk away.
Alice pleads that she didn't intend to offend, remarking on the Mouse's sensitivity.
The Mouse merely growls in response.
Alice and the others call after it, asking it to return and finish the story, but the Mouse ignores them, shaking its head and walking away faster.
Once the Mouse is gone, the Lory expresses regret, and an old Crab starts to lecture its daughter.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “What a pity it wouldn’t stay!” sighed the Lory, as soon as it was quite out of sight; and an old Crab took the opportunity of saying to her daughter “Ah, my dear!

events.text_segment:
The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back. However, it was over at last, and they sat down again in a ring, and begged the Mouse to tell them something more.
“You promised to tell me your history, you know,” said Alice, “and why it is you hate—C and D,” she added in a whisper, half afraid that it would be offended again.
“Mine is a long and a sad tale!” said the Mouse, turning to Alice, and sighing.
“It is a long tail, certainly,” said Alice, looking down with wonder at the Mouse’s tail; “but why do you call it sad?” And she kept on puzzling about it while the Mouse was speaking, so that her idea of the tale was something like this:—
 “Fury said to a
         mouse, That he
        met in the
       house,
     ‘Let us
      both go to
       law: I will
        prosecute
         you.—Come,
           I’ll take no
           denial; We
          must have a
        trial: For
      really this
     morning I’ve
    nothing
    to do.’
      Said the
      mouse to the
       cur, ‘Such
        a trial,
         dear sir,
            With
          no jury
        or judge,
       would be
      wasting
      our
      breath.’
        ‘I’ll be
        judge, I’ll
         be jury,’
             Said
         cunning
          old Fury:
          ‘I’ll
          try the
            whole
            cause,
              and
           condemn
           you
          to
           death.’”
“You are not attending!” said the Mouse to Alice severely. “What are you thinking of?”
“I beg your pardon,” said Alice very humbly: “you had got to the fifth bend, I think?”
“I had not!” cried the Mouse, sharply and very angrily.
“A knot!” said Alice, always ready to make herself useful, and looking anxiously about her. “Oh, do let me help to undo it!”
“I shall do nothing of the sort,” said the Mouse, getting up and walking away. “You insult me by talking such nonsense!”
“I didn’t mean it!” pleaded poor Alice. “But you’re so easily offended, you know!”
The Mouse only growled in reply.
“Please come back and finish your story!” Alice called after it; and the others all joined in chorus, “Yes, please do!” but the Mouse only shook its head impatiently, and walked a little quicker.
“What a pity it wouldn’t stay!” sighed the Lory, as soon as it was quite out of sight; and an old Crab took the opportunity of saying to her daughter “Ah, my dear!

The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back.

When the confusion had a little subsided, the Mouse, who had been very quiet, suddenly spoke out in an anxious tone: 'O, name of a song, I am forgetting my name! I shall be too late!' (It was really a mouse, and not a rat, as some of the others had said.)

'What was that?' said Alice, in a timid voice, for she was not a bit used to being so suddenly spoken to.

'Why, you might call it a song,' said the Mouse, 'if you liked it. It's a long and sad tale!'

'But I'm a very good listener,' said Alice, 'and I'm a good guesser. I can guess the name of a song in a minute.'

'Well, then, guess!' said the Mouse, in a rather offended tone.

'I can't guess songs,' said Alice, 'but I can guess names. What is your name, please?'

'I haven't got one,' said the Mouse, 'it's always a question of knowing the right person. I'm the March Hare's cousin, and the Dormouse is my second cousin, on my mother's side.'

'But your name, please,' said Alice, 'your real name.'

'I haven't got one,' said the Mouse, 'and I don't want to have one. I'm a mouse, and that's enough for me.'

'But I want to know your name,' said Alice, 'and I want to hear your tale.'

'Well, then, you can't,' said the Mouse, 'because it's too long and too sad. But if you insist, I'll tell you a little bit of it.'

'Oh, do!' said Alice, 'I'm very fond of sad tales.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back. Alice laughed heartily at the scene, but she soon found herself in a bit of a pickle. As the comfits were eaten, the ground beneath the birds began to shift and shimmer, and before long, they were all standing on a patchwork quilt of colors and patterns that seemed to change with every blink of the eye. The large birds, now even more disgruntled, began to argue about whose comfits were the most colorful, while the small ones fluttered about in circles, trying to catch the bits of candy that had fallen to the ground. Alice, ever the curious one, bent down to pick up a particularly shiny piece, only to find that it had grown into a full-sized plum by the time she straightened up. “Well, I never!” she exclaimed, holding it up for all to see. The birds, now thoroughly distracted, began to peck at the plum, and in doing so, they caused the quilt beneath them to ripple and fold like a great wave. Alice, not wanting to be left behind, took a bite of the plum herself. Instantly, she began to grow, and grow, and grow, until her head was nearly touching the sky. “Oh dear, oh dear, I shall be too tall to see the birds at all!” she cried, and with a quick glance around, she spotted a tiny bottle labeled 'Drink Me' resting on a nearby mushroom. Without hesitation, she uncorked it and took a large swig. In a blink, she was shrinking again, and soon she was no taller than a mouse. The birds, now much larger than she was, looked down at her with a mixture of surprise and amusement. “Well, well, what do we have here?” one of them cawed. “A tiny Alice, indeed!” they all chirped in unison, and with that, the feast was forgotten, and a new game began.

events.title: Alice's Cat Dinah Scares the Party Away
detailed_summary: The old Crab's attempt to teach her daughter a lesson about temper is immediately rebuffed by the young Crab telling her mother to be quiet.
Alice interjects loudly, wishing her cat Dinah were present, certain Dinah could retrieve the departed Mouse.
The Lory politely inquires about Dinah's identity.
Alice eagerly explains that Dinah is her pet cat.
She enthusiastically describes Dinah's prowess as a hunter, particularly her skill in catching mice and her tendency to eat birds instantly upon seeing them.
This description provokes significant alarm throughout the gathered party.
Some birds immediately hurry away.
An old Magpie begins preparing to leave, citing the unsuitability of the night air for its throat.
A Canary nervously calls its children to come away, stating it's past their bedtime.
Making various excuses, all the remaining members of the party depart, leaving Alice completely alone.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Let this be a lesson to you never to lose your temper!” “Hold your tongue, Ma!” said the young Crab, a little snappishly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: On various pretexts they all moved off, and Alice was soon left alone.

events.text_segment:
Let this be a lesson to you never to lose your temper!” “Hold your tongue, Ma!” said the young Crab, a little snappishly. “You’re enough to try the patience of an oyster!”
“I wish I had our Dinah here, I know I do!” said Alice aloud, addressing nobody in particular. “She’d soon fetch it back!”
“And who is Dinah, if I might venture to ask the question?” said the Lory.
Alice replied eagerly, for she was always ready to talk about her pet: “Dinah’s our cat. And she’s such a capital one for catching mice you can’t think! And oh, I wish you could see her after the birds! Why, she’ll eat a little bird as soon as look at it!”
This speech caused a remarkable sensation among the party. Some of the birds hurried off at once: one old Magpie began wrapping itself up very carefully, remarking, “I really must be getting home; the night-air doesn’t suit my throat!” and a Canary called out in a trembling voice to its children, “Come away, my dears! It’s high time you were all in bed!” On various pretexts they all moved off, and Alice was soon left alone.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Let this be a lesson to you never to lose your temper!”

“Hold your tongue, Ma!” said the young Crab, a little snappishly.

“Lor, how like a real little Crabs!” said the old Lory, with a great many r’s. She had a hoarse, dry voice, and she ate a little crumb out of the tip of her beak as she spoke.

“I wish Dinah was here!” Alice said to herself, not speaking aloud, for fear of惊扰 the party. “She would have caught the Mouse by this time!”

“Who is Dinah, sister?” said the Lory, in a trembling voice.

“Dinah’s my cat,” Alice said, in a hurry; “and she’s such a capital one for catching mice you can’t think! And she’s such a capital one for catching birds too! And she’s—”

But here several of the birds cried out, “You’re telling us about Dinah, not about yourself!”

“—and she’s so very—” Alice went on, more slowly, and getting more and more puzzled, as she saw the Lory drop her voice to a whisper, and say to the young Crab, “I hope you’re not going to begin about Dinah again!”

“—and she’s so very—” Alice repeated, in a faint voice, and then suddenly stopped, and looked round at the party, who were all whispering together, and looking at her with great curiosity.

“Why, what’s the matter?” she said, in a tone of surprise.

“Why, you’ve been telling us about Dinah, not about yourself!” said the Lory, in a very loud voice.

“I beg your pardon,” said Alice, “I didn’t mean to do it.”

“Then don’t do it again,” said the Lory, in a very cross tone.

“I won’t,” said Alice, in a very low voice, and she sat down on the ground, and began to cry again.

“Come, come!” said the old Magpie, “let’s all go home together. It’s getting late, and the night air is not good for my throat.”

“Nor for mine,” said the Canary, “it’s past my children’s bedtime.”

And so, one by one, they all went away, until Alice was left quite alone in the middle of the field.

events.title: Solitude, Regret, and Hopeful Footsteps
detailed_summary: Left alone, Alice expresses regret to herself for having mentioned Dinah, realizing her cat is unpopular in this strange place.
She laments that despite Dinah being the best cat in the world, nobody down here seems to like her.
Alice voices longing for Dinah and wonders with sadness if she will ever see her again.
Feeling very lonely and low-spirited as a result, Alice begins to cry once more.
Shortly after, her crying subsides as she detects the faint sound of approaching footsteps.
She looks up with renewed eagerness, entertaining the hope that the Mouse might have reconsidered and is returning to finish its story.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I wish I hadn’t mentioned Dinah!” she said to herself in a melancholy tone.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In a little while, however, she again heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she looked up eagerly, half hoping that the Mouse had changed his mind, and was coming back to finish his story.

events.text_segment: “I wish I hadn’t mentioned Dinah!” she said to herself in a melancholy tone. “Nobody seems to like her, down here, and I’m sure she’s the best cat in the world! Oh, my dear Dinah! I wonder if I shall ever see you any more!” And here poor Alice began to cry again, for she felt very lonely and low-spirited. In a little while, however, she again heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she looked up eagerly, half hoping that the Mouse had changed his mind, and was coming back to finish his story.

I wish I hadn’t mentioned Dinah!” she said to herself in a melancholy tone. “There’s no one here to care for her, and I know very well what a tiresome cat she is. I wish I hadn’t mentioned Dinah!”

She sat still for a little while, with her chin resting on her hand, and looking very wistful and forlorn. “I wonder if I shall ever see her again?” she murmured. “I hope not. I don’t like her a bit. She’s so proud, and she always thinks she’s better than any one else. I don’t like her a bit!”

But she was very, very tired of crying, and she went on saying to herself, in a more cheerful tone, “I hope the Mouse will come back. I should like to hear the rest of the tale.”

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER IV. The Rabbit Sends in a Little Bill

events.title: The White Rabbit's Return and Mistaken Identity
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit reappeared, moving slowly and searching frantically.
He muttered anxiously about the Duchess, potential execution, and losing items Alice recognized as his fan and gloves.
Alice, observing the changed surroundings where the hall and table had disappeared, kindly started searching for the lost items.
The Rabbit spotted Alice and angrily mistook her for someone named Mary Ann.
He ordered her to go home immediately and bring him gloves and a fan.
Alice, startled and scared by his tone, obeyed instantly and ran in the direction he indicated, without correcting his mistake.
As she ran, Alice realized the Rabbit thought she was his servant.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something; and she heard it muttering to itself “The Duchess! The Duchess!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “He took me for his housemaid,” she said to herself as she ran.

events.text_segment:
It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something; and she heard it muttering to itself “The Duchess! The Duchess! Oh my dear paws! Oh my fur and whiskers! She’ll get me executed, as sure as ferrets are ferrets! Where can I have dropped them, I wonder?” Alice guessed in a moment that it was looking for the fan and the pair of white kid gloves, and she very good-naturedly began hunting about for them, but they were nowhere to be seen—everything seemed to have changed since her swim in the pool, and the great hall, with the glass table and the little door, had vanished completely.
Very soon the Rabbit noticed Alice, as she went hunting about, and called out to her in an angry tone, “Why, Mary Ann, what are you doing out here? Run home this moment, and fetch me a pair of gloves and a fan! Quick, now!” And Alice was so much frightened that she ran off at once in the direction it pointed to, without trying to explain the mistake it had made.
“He took me for his housemaid,” she said to herself as she ran.

The Duchess! Oh my dear, how late I’m going to be!” As it passed close by her, Alice could hear a great deal of talk about a hat and a waistcoat button, and a latchkey, and a piece of cheese. “Oh, I have so much to do!” said the Rabbit, and it hurried on, still muttering to itself, and looking more puzzled than ever. Alice could not help laughing when she saw the Rabbit take a watch out of its waistcoat pocket and look at it with one eye, and then look at his ear, and then look at the watch again with the other eye. “Surely it’s time for tea by this,” said Alice to herself. “I wonder if the Duchess has had her tea yet?” She was just in time to see the Rabbit vanish into a large rose-tree, and she heard it say, as it disappeared, “Oh my ears and whiskers, how late it is!” and she could not help laughing again at such a curious way of keeping time.

events.title: Alice Enters the Rabbit's House and Drinks a Potion
detailed_summary: Alice considered the Rabbit's surprise upon discovering her true identity but resolved to fetch the fan and gloves if possible.
She arrived at a small, tidy house marked with a brass plate reading "W. RABBIT".
She entered without knocking and rushed upstairs, anxious to avoid encountering the actual Mary Ann.
Alice mused on the absurdity of running errands for a rabbit, comparing it to her cat Dinah potentially giving her orders.
She imagined a scenario where Dinah would boss her around, but concluded Dinah wouldn't be allowed to stay if she behaved that way.
Alice located a neat room with a table holding a fan and several pairs of small white kid gloves.
After picking up the fan and one pair of gloves, she noticed an unlabeled bottle near the mirror.
Despite the lack of instructions, she decided to drink from it, anticipating an interesting outcome based on her past experiences with Wonderland food and drinks.
She hoped the drink would restore her to a larger size, expressing weariness with being so small.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “How surprised he’ll be when he finds out who I am! But I’d better take him his fan and gloves—that is, if I can find them.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I do hope it’ll make me grow large again, for really I’m quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!”

events.text_segment:
“How surprised he’ll be when he finds out who I am! But I’d better take him his fan and gloves—that is, if I can find them.” As she said this, she came upon a neat little house, on the door of which was a bright brass plate with the name “W. RABBIT,” engraved upon it. She went in without knocking, and hurried upstairs, in great fear lest she should meet the real Mary Ann, and be turned out of the house before she had found the fan and gloves.
“How queer it seems,” Alice said to herself, “to be going messages for a rabbit! I suppose Dinah’ll be sending me on messages next!” And she began fancying the sort of thing that would happen: “‘Miss Alice! Come here directly, and get ready for your walk!’ ‘Coming in a minute, nurse! But I’ve got to see that the mouse doesn’t get out.’ Only I don’t think,” Alice went on, “that they’d let Dinah stop in the house if it began ordering people about like that!”
By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table in the window, and on it (as she had hoped) a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves: she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves, and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a little bottle that stood near the looking-glass. There was no label this time with the words “DRINK ME,” but nevertheless she uncorked it and put it to her lips. “I know something interesting is sure to happen,” she said to herself, “whenever I eat or drink anything; so I’ll just see what this bottle does. I do hope it’ll make me grow large again, for really I’m quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: How surprised he’ll be when he finds out who I am! But I’d better take him his fan and gloves—that is, if I can find them.” So she left off her lamenting, and tried to look bright, and determined to go in search of them. She thought it would be a good plan to begin at the foot of the garden, and work her way up to the top, where the house was, in case the fan and gloves were to be found anywhere. So she set off at once, and was soon at the foot of the garden, where there was a little, neat house, with a brass plate on the door, which read, “W. RABBIT.” Alice knocked, but no one answered, so she walked in, and up the stairs, as fast as she could go, in case the real Mary Ann should be coming in at the door. “It’s a pity,” she said to herself, “that I can’t get to be a real little girl again, and then I could go and live with Dinah, and not have to run about after rabbits and things. I wonder if Dinah would boss me about like this? I should think she would, if she had the chance!” But then she remembered that Dinah would never be allowed to stay in the house if she behaved that way. So she went on, and soon found a neat little room, with a table in it, and on the table a fan and several pairs of small white kid gloves. “Now, which is to take?” she thought. “I’ll take the fan, and one pair of gloves, and then I’ll go back and give them to the Rabbit.” So she took the fan and one pair of gloves, and was just going out of the room, when she noticed a small bottle near the looking-glass, with a label on it, which said, “DRINK ME.” “Well, I’ll drink it,” said Alice, “and see what happens.” She had never done such a thing before, but she was quite sure that it would be very interesting to drink something that had no instructions on it. She was a little afraid of it, but she was more curious than afraid, and so she took the bottle up, and drank it off in a minute. “I hope it will make me grow larger,” she said, “for I’m tired of being so small.”

IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion invents a sequence where Alice searches the garden before reaching the house, which is not present in the original.
- There is an invented internal reflection about Alice wishing to be a real little girl again and living with Dinah, which does not appear in the original passage.
- The completion adds a decision-making process about which gloves to take, which is not part of the original sequence.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion omits Alice's specific fear of encountering Mary Ann and being turned out before finding the items, which is a key motivator in the original.
- The playful imagined dialogue between Alice and her nurse, as well as the scenario involving Dinah giving orders, is missing or replaced with a less detailed reflection.
- The original's description of the bottle lacking a label and Alice's reasoning about interesting things happening when she eats or drinks is not fully captured.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately describes Alice knocking on the door and waiting for an answer, which does not match the original sequence of events.
- The bottle is described as having a label in the completion, which contradicts the original detail.
- The completion has Alice drinking the bottle "off in a minute," which is not specified in the original.
- The reasoning Alice gives for drinking the bottle is altered, and her expectations and feelings about the outcome are not fully aligned with the original passage.
- The sequence of Alice's actions and thoughts is sometimes rearranged, leading to a different flow than in the original text.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: “How surprised he’ll be when he finds out who I am! But I’d better take him his fan and gloves—that is, if I can find them.” Alice looked all around her, but the room was in such a state of confusion that it was impossible to know where anything was. The furniture was all moving about in the most disorderly fashion, and the walls were covered with maps and pictures that kept changing their places. “I wonder if I shall ever get out of this room?” she said to herself, beginning to feel quite tired of the whole thing. Just then she heard a voice behind her, and turning round, she found that she had come upon a little door which opened into a garden. “How curious!” she said. “I was not aware that there was a door here before.” She tried the handle, but it was locked. “I must have missed it when I came in,” she said. “But how strange that I did not notice it before!” She looked at the door for a moment, and then, as if suddenly remembering something, she took out the key that she had found in the pocket of the white rabbit’s waistcoat. “I wonder if this will open it?” she said, and she tried it. It did not fit. “How very odd!” she said. “I thought it would.” She tried it again, and again it did not fit. “I wonder if it is the right key at all?” she said. “I wonder if I have the right door at all?” She looked at the key and the door for a long time, and then she sat down on the floor and began to cry. “I wish I had never come into this room!” she said. “I wish I had never gone into Wonderland at all!” But she soon stopped crying, for she heard a voice behind her, and turning round, she found that she had come upon a little door which opened into a garden.

events.title: Alice Grows Enormously and Becomes Trapped
detailed_summary: The drink worked rapidly; before finishing half, Alice's head hit the ceiling, forcing her to bend down.
She quickly put the bottle down, realizing she had had enough and hoping not to grow further.
She recognized she was already too large to exit through the door and regretted drinking so much.
Her regret came too late as she continued expanding.
Soon she had to kneel, and shortly after, even kneeling wasn't possible.
She tried lying down, positioning one elbow against the door and curling her other arm around her head.
Still growing, she resorted to putting one arm out the window and one foot up the chimney.
Feeling she could do nothing more, she wondered anxiously about her fate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: What will become of me?”

events.text_segment:
It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken. She hastily put down the bottle, saying to herself “That’s quite enough—I hope I shan’t grow any more—As it is, I can’t get out at the door—I do wish I hadn’t drunk quite so much!”
Alas! it was too late to wish that! She went on growing, and growing, and very soon had to kneel down on the floor: in another minute there was not even room for this, and she tried the effect of lying down with one elbow against the door, and the other arm curled round her head. Still she went on growing, and, as a last resource, she put one arm out of the window, and one foot up the chimney, and said to herself “Now I can do no more, whatever happens. What will become of me?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken. She hastily put the bottle down, and said to herself, 'Well! I shall be out of my grave before long, if something doesn't happen to me!' But then again, she comforted herself, 'I can't be any worse off than this — I can't go on growing any more!' But she was mistaken: she went on growing, and growing, and growing, and soon had to kneel down on the floor, and soon after that began to lie down along the floor, and then, after a few more minutes, she found herself lying on the floor with her head in the corner, and her arms and legs stretched out, and her hair hanging down the walls, and her feet in the air. She felt a little nervous about this, and tried to get up, but she could not, for her head was fast against the ceiling, and her feet were in the air, and she could not move. She was very much frightened, and began to cry, and said to herself, 'What an extraordinary thing it is to be so very large! I wonder if I shall ever be able to get out of this room again!'

She felt a little nervous about this, and tried to get up, but she could not, for her head was fast against the ceiling, and her feet were in the air, and she could not move. She was very much frightened, and began to cry, and said to herself, 'What an extraordinary thing it is to be so very large! I wonder if I shall ever be able to get out of this room again!'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken. She was now just the right size to go through the little door into that lovely garden, only she forgot she had no key. She wildly looked about for the key, but it was nowhere to be found. Suddenly, a small golden key dropped into her lap. She seized it, and, with trembling hands, she turned it first in one lock of the door, and then in another. Nothing happened. She shook it and looked at it, and then suddenly gave a little scream and dropped it. The key had turned into a tiny mouse!

events.title: Alice's Reflections While Trapped
detailed_summary: Fortunately, the bottle's effect ceased, stopping her growth, but her situation remained uncomfortable with no apparent escape, making her feel miserable.
Alice wistfully thought about home, where life was stable, unlike her current state of constant size changes and being bossed around by animals.
She momentarily regretted entering the rabbit-hole but acknowledged the curious nature of her adventures.
She marveled at finding herself within a real-life fairy tale, unlike the ones she read.
Alice felt her experiences were significant enough for a book and resolved to write one when she grew up, immediately realizing sadly that she was already fully grown within the confines of the room.
She contemplated the implications of potentially never aging further – a comfort in avoiding old age, but dreadful due to the prospect of perpetual lessons.
She then debated with herself, dismissing the idea of lessons due to the lack of space for herself, let alone books.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Why, there’s hardly room for you, and no room at all for any lesson-books!”

events.text_segment:
Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy.
“It was much pleasanter at home,” thought poor Alice, “when one wasn’t always growing larger and smaller, and being ordered about by mice and rabbits. I almost wish I hadn’t gone down that rabbit-hole—and yet—and yet—it’s rather curious, you know, this sort of life! I do wonder what can have happened to me! When I used to read fairy-tales, I fancied that kind of thing never happened, and now here I am in the middle of one! There ought to be a book written about me, that there ought! And when I grow up, I’ll write one—but I’m grown up now,” she added in a sorrowful tone; “at least there’s no room to grow up any more here.”
“But then,” thought Alice, “shall I never get any older than I am now? That’ll be a comfort, one way—never to be an old woman—but then—always to have lessons to learn! Oh, I shouldn’t like that!”
“Oh, you foolish Alice!” she answered herself. “How can you learn lessons in here? Why, there’s hardly room for you, and no room at all for any lesson-books!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy. "How curious it seems," said Alice, "to be changed into a sort of--what am I?--I can't even explain it to myself, and that's very puzzling." And she began to cry again. She was a little startled at first when she found that her tears (for she had a good cry) made a pool all round her, but she soon got used to that. After a time she took up the little golden key and unlocked the door that led into the garden. Then she wriggled in, neck and arms, and then the rest of her, slowly shutting the door behind her, and she found herself in a long passage with a low ceiling and rather dark. Through the passage she wandered, wondering if it would ever come to an end, and just as she began to get tired of wandering, she found a little door at the end of it. It was so low and narrow that she had to creep through it on her hands and knees. When she got through, she found herself in a beautiful garden, full of bright flowers and cool shade, and there was a little table set out under a tree, with a glass upon it, and a bottle that said 'DRINK ME,' and a box that said 'EAT ME.'

events.title: The Rabbit Fails to Enter and Summons Pat
detailed_summary: Alice's internal debate was interrupted by a voice outside calling for "Mary Ann" and demanding gloves.
Hearing footsteps on the stairs, Alice identified the Rabbit approaching and trembled, momentarily forgetting her immense size advantage.
The Rabbit reached the door and tried to open it, but failed because it opened inward and Alice's elbow blocked it.
Alice overheard the Rabbit deciding to try entering through the window instead.
Alice silently resolved to prevent this.
Waiting until she thought the Rabbit was beneath the window, she quickly reached her hand out, snatching at the air.
Though she caught nothing, she heard a cry, a fall, and breaking glass, guessing the Rabbit might have fallen into a cucumber-frame.
The Rabbit's angry voice then called for someone named Pat.
Another voice, new to Alice, responded, claiming to be digging for apples.
The Rabbit angrily dismissed this and ordered Pat to help him out, accompanied by more sounds of broken glass.
The Rabbit asked Pat what was visible in the window.
Pat identified it as an arm, despite its unusual size filling the entire window.
The Rabbit, calling Pat a goose, declared the arm had no right to be there and ordered Pat to remove it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside, and stopped to listen.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, it’s got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!”

events.text_segment:
And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside, and stopped to listen.
“Mary Ann! Mary Ann!” said the voice. “Fetch me my gloves this moment!” Then came a little pattering of feet on the stairs. Alice knew it was the Rabbit coming to look for her, and she trembled till she shook the house, quite forgetting that she was now about a thousand times as large as the Rabbit, and had no reason to be afraid of it.
Presently the Rabbit came up to the door, and tried to open it; but, as the door opened inwards, and Alice’s elbow was pressed hard against it, that attempt proved a failure. Alice heard it say to itself “Then I’ll go round and get in at the window.”
“That you won’t!” thought Alice, and, after waiting till she fancied she heard the Rabbit just under the window, she suddenly spread out her hand, and made a snatch in the air. She did not get hold of anything, but she heard a little shriek and a fall, and a crash of broken glass, from which she concluded that it was just possible it had fallen into a cucumber-frame, or something of the sort.
Next came an angry voice—the Rabbit’s—“Pat! Pat! Where are you?” And then a voice she had never heard before, “Sure then I’m here! Digging for apples, yer honour!”
“Digging for apples, indeed!” said the Rabbit angrily. “Here! Come and help me out of this!” (Sounds of more broken glass.)
“Now tell me, Pat, what’s that in the window?”
“Sure, it’s an arm, yer honour!” (He pronounced it “arrum.”)
“An arm, you goose! Who ever saw one that size? Why, it fills the whole window!”
“Sure, it does, yer honour: but it’s an arm for all that.”
“Well, it’s got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!”

And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside, and stopped to listen.

"Mary Ann! Mary Ann!" said the voice, and it was the White Rabbit's voice, and it was calling for Mary Ann, and it was demanding gloves. Alice's heart gave a little thump, for she knew it was the White Rabbit, and she trembled all over, though she was now so much larger than he was.

The Rabbit came up the stairs in a great hurry, muttering to himself as he went, and Alice heard him saying, "Oh, Mary Ann, I shall be too late!" and she thought, "I wonder if I shall be too late too?" But she did not dare to speak, for fear of waking the Rabbit up.

He reached the door, and tried to open it, but it was fastened on the inside. "Mary Ann! Mary Ann!" he cried again, and then he began to run up and down the stairs, and Alice heard him saying, "I shall be too late! I shall be too late!" and she thought, "I wonder if I shall be too late too?" But she did not dare to speak, for fear of waking the Rabbit up.

At last he gave a great sigh, and said, "I shall have to go in at the window," and Alice thought, "I shall have to stop him!" So she waited until she thought he was just beneath the window, and then she put out her hand as far as she could, and caught at the air. She did not catch anything, but she heard a great crash, and a cry of "Oh, my fur and whiskers!" and then a great deal of glass was broken, and she thought, "He's fallen into the cucumber-frame!"

"Would you tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?" she said, turning to the Cheshire Cat, who was sitting on a branch of a tree. "That depends a good deal on where you want to get to," said the Cat. "I don't much care where," said Alice. "Then it doesn't much matter which way you go," said the Cat. "So long as I get somewhere," Alice added as an explanation. "Oh, you're sure to do that," said the Cat, "if you only walk long enough." Alice felt very doubtful about that; but she did not like to contradict him. "But I'm not sure where I want to go yet," she said, after a minute's silence. "Then it doesn't much matter which way you go," the Cat repeated. "I suppose I'll just go on a little farther," said Alice, and she went on at once in the opposite direction to the one she was in before. "You might just as well do that," said the Cat. "It's exactly the same thing." Alice was getting quite tired of following the Cat's advice, but she could not help laughing at his odd way of talking. "I wonder if I've been changed in the night?" she thought. "Let me look at the jury-box again." She looked up at the jury-box, and there was a long line of heads, all turned towards her, and all with their mouths open. "I wish I could shut them up," she said to herself, "but I don't know how." She looked at the Cat again, and he was still sitting on the branch, grinning from ear to ear. "I don't like that sort of grin," said Alice. "It makes me feel nervous." "It's the best kind of grin," said the Cat. "It shows that I'm pleased to see you." "Well, I'm not pleased to see you," said Alice, "and the trial is going to begin, and I don't know what to do with myself." "You might just as well sit down," said the Cat. "It's the most comfortable thing to do." So Alice sat down on the grass, and the Cat jumped down from the tree and sat beside her. "I hope the trial will be over soon," said Alice. "I don't think it will be," said the Cat. "It's going to last all day." "That's very bad," said Alice. "I hope it will be over before night." "It's going to be over when it's over," said the Cat. "That's the way it is." Alice did not like the Cat's way of talking, but she could not help laughing at it. She thought it was very funny, and she began to feel a little better.

events.title: Bill the Lizard's Chimney Descent and Expulsion
detailed_summary: Following a silence punctuated by whispers indicating Pat's reluctance and the Rabbit's insistence, Alice made another snatching motion with her hand.
This resulted in two small shrieks and more glass breaking sounds, leading Alice to wonder about the abundance of cucumber-frames.
She hoped they could pull her out, as she wished to leave the room.
After a period of quiet, Alice heard cartwheels and many voices conferring.
She deciphered fragments of conversation about ladders, ropes, roof stability, falling slates, and assigning blame to someone named Bill.
The discussion concluded with the decision that Bill must go down the chimney.
Alice noted internally that Bill seemed to be assigned all the difficult tasks.
Considering Bill's likely predicament in the narrow fireplace, Alice prepared herself, thinking she could deliver a kick.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then; such as, “Sure, I don’t like it, yer honour, at all, at all!” “Do as I tell you, you coward!” and at last she spread out her hand again, and made another snatch in the air.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think I can kick a little!”

events.text_segment:
There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then; such as, “Sure, I don’t like it, yer honour, at all, at all!” “Do as I tell you, you coward!” and at last she spread out her hand again, and made another snatch in the air. This time there were two little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass. “What a number of cucumber-frames there must be!” thought Alice. “I wonder what they’ll do next! As for pulling me out of the window, I only wish they could! I’m sure I don’t want to stay in here any longer!”
She waited for some time without hearing anything more: at last came a rumbling of little cartwheels, and the sound of a good many voices all talking together: she made out the words: “Where’s the other ladder?—Why, I hadn’t to bring but one; Bill’s got the other—Bill! fetch it here, lad!—Here, put ’em up at this corner—No, tie ’em together first—they don’t reach half high enough yet—Oh! they’ll do well enough; don’t be particular—Here, Bill! catch hold of this rope—Will the roof bear?—Mind that loose slate—Oh, it’s coming down! Heads below!” (a loud crash)—“Now, who did that?—It was Bill, I fancy—Who’s to go down the chimney?—Nay, I shan’t! You do it!—That I won’t, then!—Bill’s to go down—Here, Bill! the master says you’re to go down the chimney!”
“Oh! So Bill’s got to come down the chimney, has he?” said Alice to herself. “Shy, they seem to put everything upon Bill! I wouldn’t be in Bill’s place for a good deal: this fireplace is narrow, to be sure; but I think I can kick a little!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then; such as, 'Sure, I don't like it, yer honour, at all, at all!' 'Do as I tell you, you coward!' and at last she spread out her hand again, and made another snatch in the air. This time next nothing happened: she was too late, as it seemed, in making her snatch; and she had just time to see Bill's face looking at her with a grin, as he was carried out of sight. 'A fine day's work this has been!' said Alice, as she began to cry again. 'I wish I had never come into this wretched place!' And she sobbed so much, that she went on for some time with her eyes shut, and only just knew when she had found her way into another room with walls of glass. 'If I can't get out in a minute,' she said to herself, 'I'll go on crying till I'm fit to die!' Just then her foot slipped, and in came a shower of little pebbles from the roof, and she found herself sitting on the floor of the new room, with her head in the lap of something large and soft, and full of eyes and whiskers. 'It is the White Rabbit!' she thought. 'Oh, it's too bad!' (For the poor creature was still in his waistcoat of white velvet.) 'Only four more to go through, and then I'll be out of it; and I think that's the largest room of all!' So she began to cry again, expecting each moment that she would be drowned in the great pool of tears that was gathering round her, and indeed she was just in the middle of a very fine 'I wish I hadn't cried so much!' when a large pigeon came flying in through the window. 'Why, it's a pigeon!' thought Alice. 'I wonder what it's looking for!' The pigeon looked at her for a minute, and then flew into the room with a loud 'Hoo-hoo!' and began to peck at the glass. 'It's looking for a way out,' said Alice. 'But I don't see any way out for it, unless it goes through the window again.' The pigeon gave a loud 'Hoo-hoo!' and flew out again. 'I wish I could go out too!' said Alice. 'But I don't see any way out for me.' She looked round the room, and saw that it was full of glass, and that the floor was made of glass, and the ceiling was made of glass, and the walls were made of glass, and the furniture was made of glass, and the people were made of glass, and the animals were made of glass, and the trees were made of glass, and the flowers were made of glass, and the sky was made of glass, and the clouds were made of glass, and the sun was made of glass, and the moon was made of glass, and the stars were made of glass, and the whole world was made of glass. 'I wonder if I'm made of glass too?' said Alice. 'I don't feel like it.' She looked at her hands, and they were made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass too!' She looked at her face in the glass, and it was made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass all over!' She looked at her feet, and they were made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass from head to foot!' She looked at her hair, and it was made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass from head to foot, and I don't like it at all!' She began to cry again, and the tears ran down her glass cheeks, and made little glass rivers on the glass floor. 'I wish I was not made of glass!' said Alice. 'I wish I was made of something else!' 'A fine day's work this has been!' said Alice, as she began to cry again. 'I wish I had never come into this wretched place!' And she sobbed so much, that she went on for some time with her eyes shut, and only just knew when she had found her way into another room with walls of glass. 'If I can't get out in a minute,' she said to herself, 'I'll go on crying till I'm fit to die!' Just then her foot slipped, and in came a shower of little pebbles from the roof, and she found herself sitting on the floor of the new room, with her head in the lap of something large and soft, and full of eyes and whiskers. 'It is the White Rabbit!' she thought. 'Oh, it's too bad!' (For the poor creature was still in his waistcoat of white velvet.) 'Only four more to go through, and then I'll be out of it; and I think that's the largest room of all!' So she began to cry again, expecting each moment that she would be drowned in the great pool of tears that was gathering round her, and indeed she was just in the middle of a very fine 'I wish I hadn't cried so much!' when a large pigeon came flying in through the window. 'Why, it's a pigeon!' thought Alice. 'I wonder what it's looking for!' The pigeon looked at her for a minute, and then flew into the room with a loud 'Hoo-hoo!' and began to peck at the glass. 'It's looking for a way out,' said Alice. 'But I don't see any way out for it, unless it goes through the window again.' The pigeon gave a loud 'Hoo-hoo!' and flew out again. 'I wish I could go out too!' said Alice. 'But I don't see any way out for me.' She looked round the room, and saw that it was full of glass, and that the floor was made of glass, and the ceiling was made of glass, and the walls were made of glass, and the furniture was made of glass, and the people were made of glass, and the animals were made of glass, and the trees were made of glass, and the flowers were made of glass, and the sky was made of glass, and the clouds were made of glass, and the sun was made of glass, and the moon was made of glass, and the stars were made of glass, and the whole world was made of glass. 'I wonder if I'm made of glass too?' said Alice. 'I don't feel like it.' She looked at her hands, and they were made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass too!' She looked at her face in the glass, and it was made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass all over!' She looked at her feet, and they were made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass from head to foot!' She looked at her hair, and it was made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass from head to foot, and I don't like it at all!' She began to cry again, and the tears ran down her glass cheeks, and made little glass rivers on the glass floor. 'I wish I was not made of glass!' said Alice. 'I wish I was made of something else!' She looked round the room, and saw that it was full of glass, and that the floor was made of glass, and the ceiling was made of glass, and the walls were made of glass, and the furniture was made of glass, and the people were made of glass, and the animals were made of glass, and the trees were made of glass, and the flowers were made of glass, and the sky was made of glass, and the clouds were made of glass, and the sun was made of glass, and the moon was made of glass, and the stars were made of glass, and the whole world was made of glass. 'I wonder if I'm made of glass too?' said Alice. 'I don't feel like it.' She looked at her hands, and they were made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass too!' She looked at her face in the glass, and it was made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass all over!' She looked at her feet, and they were made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass from head to foot!' She looked at her hair, and it was made of glass. 'Oh dear!' said Alice. 'I'm made of glass from head to foot, and I don't like it at all!' She began to cry again, and the tears ran down her glass cheeks, and made little glass rivers on the glass floor. 'I wish I was not made of glass!' said Alice. 'I wish I was made of something else!'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then; such as, “Sure, I don’t like it, yer honour, at all, at all!” “Do as I tell you, you coward!” and at last she spread out her hand again, and made another snatch in the air. This time next nothing happened. She was rather doubtful whether she had done it right, but she tried again. Still nothing happened. “I’m a deal too far off to look for the help of a fan,” she said to herself, “and as for the sword, you’d better take it!” (she was always ready to take advice), “and perhaps the best thing will be, if I keep this up till I get to the top of the hill, I shall find the creatures I want to speak to.” So she went on, getting a little tired of the exercise, but feeling very pleased at the idea of being of use at last. As she went on, she began to notice that the trees were getting thinner, and the ground drier, and the air more still. “I wonder if I’ve been changed in the night?” she thought; and she jumped up and down in the air a few times to make sure. “I’m a deal too old for this sort of thing,” she said, “and I don’t believe I shall ever be able to get back to my proper size again.” But just at this moment, she heard a voice behind her, and turning round, she saw a little creature, no bigger than a mouse, with a pair of round, black eyes and a long tail, sitting on a stone. “O my fur and whiskers!” cried the mouse, “how she does grow! Why, I do believe she’s grown a whole head taller!”}

events.title: Failed Expulsion, Pebble Attack, and Magical Cakes
detailed_summary: Alice positioned her foot in the chimney and waited.
Hearing a small animal scrambling above, she identified it as Bill and delivered a swift kick.
A collective shout of "There goes Bill!" followed, along with the Rabbit urging others to catch him.
After a silence, confused voices were heard tending to Bill, asking what happened.
A weak, squeaky voice (identified by Alice as Bill's) responded, stating he felt better but too flustered to explain, only knowing something shot him up like a sky-rocket.
The others confirmed his description.
The Rabbit's voice then suggested burning the house down.
Alice loudly threatened to send her cat Dinah after them if they did.
An immediate silence fell; Alice wondered about their next move, thinking removing the roof would be more sensible.
After a pause, movement resumed, and Alice heard the Rabbit order a barrowful of something.
Alice wondered what it could be, but soon a shower of small pebbles rained in through the window, some hitting her face.
She resolved to stop this and shouted a warning, causing another silence.
Alice noticed the pebbles on the floor were transforming into tiny cakes.
This sparked an idea: eating a cake would likely alter her size, and since she couldn't get larger, it must make her smaller.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited till she heard a little animal (she couldn’t guess of what sort it was) scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then, saying to herself “This is Bill,” she gave one sharp kick, and waited to see what would happen next.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “If I eat one of these cakes,” she thought, “it’s sure to make some change in my size; and as it can’t possibly make me larger, it must make me smaller, I suppose.”

events.text_segment:
She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited till she heard a little animal (she couldn’t guess of what sort it was) scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then, saying to herself “This is Bill,” she gave one sharp kick, and waited to see what would happen next.
The first thing she heard was a general chorus of “There goes Bill!” then the Rabbit’s voice along—“Catch him, you by the hedge!” then silence, and then another confusion of voices—“Hold up his head—Brandy now—Don’t choke him—How was it, old fellow? What happened to you? Tell us all about it!”
Last came a little feeble, squeaking voice, (“That’s Bill,” thought Alice,) “Well, I hardly know—No more, thank ye; I’m better now—but I’m a deal too flustered to tell you—all I know is, something comes at me like a Jack-in-the-box, and up I goes like a sky-rocket!”
“So you did, old fellow!” said the others.
“We must burn the house down!” said the Rabbit’s voice; and Alice called out as loud as she could, “If you do, I’ll set Dinah at you!”
There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, “I wonder what they will do next! If they had any sense, they’d take the roof off.” After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and Alice heard the Rabbit say, “A barrowful will do, to begin with.”
“A barrowful of what?” thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt, for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the window, and some of them hit her in the face. “I’ll put a stop to this,” she said to herself, and shouted out, “You’d better not do that again!” which produced another dead silence.
Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her head. “If I eat one of these cakes,” she thought, “it’s sure to make some change in my size; and as it can’t possibly make me larger, it must make me smaller, I suppose.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited till she heard a little animal (she couldn’t guess of what sort it was) scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then, saying to herself “This is Bill,” she gave one sharp kick, and waited to see what would happen next.

There was a general chorus of “There goes Bill!” and the White Rabbit’s voice could be heard in the distance, shouting, “Catch him, catch him!”

After a moment of silence, Alice heard a confused murmur of voices, all tending to Bill, and asking what had happened. A very weak, squeaky voice (which Alice was sure was Bill’s) answered, “I’m feeling better now, but I’m too flustered to explain myself at all clearly—though I believe something like a sky-rocket went off in the air, and I was shot up like a cannon-ball!”

“That’s right!” cried the others. “He was in a passion, and he said he’d burn the house down!”

Alice was so much frightened by this, that she jumped up and cried out, “If you do, I’ll set Dinah on you!”

There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, “Well, I’ve certainly had enough of you all for to-day: one or two of you I think I could put up with; but not all together!”

After a minute or two of silence, she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and then the Rabbit’s voice again: “They’re making a great noise out there, and they’re all talking about burning the house down!”

Alice thought to herself, “What a curious world we live in! I wonder what they’re going to do next?”

Just then she heard the Rabbit’s voice again, saying, “Bring a barrowful of something!”

Alice was very puzzled. “What can they be bringing?” she thought. “It must be something to burn the house down with!”

But before she could make out any more, a shower of little pebbles came rattling in through the window, some of them hitting her in the face. “I must stop this!” she cried, and she put her hand up to her face, and shouted, “If you don’t stop that noise, I’ll—”

But she could not finish, for the moment she had said “I’ll,” a little pebble hit her on the nose, and she sneezed.

Then there was a dead silence again. Alice looked round, and saw that the pebbles which had fallen on the floor were beginning to change into little cakes, all sorts of little cakes: plum-cakes, pineapple-tarts, cinnamon buns, red-velvet cake, and all the others.

“This is a good way of putting an end to it,” thought Alice, “and a very curious thing it is, that this should make me smaller instead of larger!”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited till she heard a little animal (she couldn’t guess of what sort it was) scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then, saying to herself “This is Bill,” she gave one sharp kick, and waited to see what would happen next. The first thing she knew was that the creature had vanished, and that she heard a voice in the chimney saying, “Well! Well! Well! This is a fine muddle!” It was the voice of the Cheshire Cat, and it was speaking in a tone of great surprise and annoyance. “I was just beginning to enjoy myself,” it continued, “and now I’m stuck in a chimney with a girl who thinks I’m a mouse!” Alice, who had never seen the Cheshire Cat before, was quite taken aback. “I’m not a mouse,” she said, “I’m Alice. And you’re not a mouse either, are you?” “No, I’m not,” said the Cat, “but I was pretending to be. It’s much more fun that way.” Alice thought this was a very strange thing to say, but she was too busy trying to get out of the chimney to argue. “If you don’t mind,” she said, “I’d like to get out of here.” “Well, I don’t mind,” said the Cat, “but I don’t know how to get you out. I’m not very good at rescues.” “Then I’ll just have to get out myself,” said Alice. And with that, she began to climb up the chimney as fast as she could. The Cat watched her go, and then said to itself, “I wonder where she’s going to end up now.” And with that, it vanished, leaving only its grin behind. Alice, who was now halfway up the chimney, looked down and saw the grin, and said to herself, “Well, at least I know I’m not alone in this mad world.” And with that, she climbed on, not knowing what strange adventures awaited her next.

events.title: Shrinking, Escape, and a New Plan
detailed_summary: Alice consumed one of the small cakes and was pleased to feel herself shrinking immediately.
Once small enough to fit through the doorway, she dashed out of the house.
Outside, she encountered a crowd of small animals and birds.
Bill the Lizard was present, looking unwell and supported by two guinea-pigs administering something from a bottle.
The assembled creatures rushed towards Alice upon her appearance.
She fled quickly, soon reaching the safety of a dense wood.
Wandering in the wood, Alice decided on a two-part plan: first, regain her normal height, and second, find her way to the beautiful garden she had seen earlier.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she began shrinking directly.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think that will be the best plan.”

events.text_segment:
So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she began shrinking directly. As soon as she was small enough to get through the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little animals and birds waiting outside. The poor little Lizard, Bill, was in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it something out of a bottle. They all made a rush at Alice the moment she appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself safe in a thick wood.
“The first thing I’ve got to do,” said Alice to herself, as she wandered about in the wood, “is to grow to my right size again; and the second thing is to find my way into that lovely garden. I think that will be the best plan.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she began shrinking directly. As soon as she was small enough to get through the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little animals and birds waiting in a row. The first four of them were two guinea-pigs, and two rabbits with pink eyes; after these came a long line of birds, and at last two lizards, and then two more guinea-pigs. A little bill, a lizard, was lying on the ground, quite stiff and rigid, with his eyes shut, and a bottle of something in his hand. The two guinea-pigs were running about, trying to get the bottle away from him, and at last they succeeded in getting it, and then they both began drinking out of it. The whole crowd of animals and birds rushed at Alice the moment she appeared, and she ran off as fast as she could, and soon found herself in a wood. She sat down on a mossy stone, and began to think what to do next, when she remembered that she had not yet tried the other cake. So she ate a little bit of it, and was delighted to find that she began growing larger again. But she was not quite sure whether she was growing to her full size, so she went on eating a little more, and soon found that she was quite as large as she had been before she had eaten the cake. Then she thought she would try to find her way to the beautiful garden she had seen through the glass.
