events.text_segment:
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.
Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, “and then,” thought she, “what would become of me? They’re dreadfully fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there’s any one left alive!”
She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself “It’s the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.”
“How are you getting on?” said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded. “It’s no use speaking to it,” she thought, “till its ears have come, or at least one of them.” In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” about once in a minute.

Alice stood a little aside, watching the game with great curiosity, but she felt very uneasy. She had not yet had any dispute with the Queen, and she was beginning to think that she would never have any dispute with the Queen, when suddenly a loud cry of “Off with her head!” broke the silence, and Alice turned pale.

She looked round in a great fright, and saw that the Queen was now quite close to her, and was looking at her with a very angry face. “You’re a very bad player,” said the Queen, “and I’m very tired of you. Off with her head!”

Alice was so frightened that she could not speak for a moment. She looked round for some way of escape, and at last she noticed a curious shape beginning to appear in the air. It was a long, thin grin, and it was getting wider and wider. “It’s the Cheshire Cat!” thought Alice, and she felt a little better, for she had always liked the Cheshire Cat.

“Good morning, Alice,” said the Cat, as soon as its mouth appeared. “How are you doing?”

Alice waited a little, for she thought it would be a good plan to wait until the Cat’s eyes appeared, and then she nodded. “I’m very well,” she said, “but I’m a little afraid of the Queen.”

“Ah, the Queen of Hearts,” said the Cat, “she’s a very temperamental person. She always says ‘Off with his head!’ or ‘Off with her head!’ when she’s angry. But she never means it, you know.”

“I hope not,” said Alice, “but I don’t like to take any chances.”

“Nor do I,” said the Cat, “and that’s why I always vanish when I’m not wanted.”

Alice looked at the Cat, and then at the Queen, and then at the game, and she felt a little more at ease. She put down her flamingo, and began to tell the Cat all about the game, and how she had got into it, and how she had been frightened by the Queen. The Cat listened very attentively, and now and then it gave a little nod, or a little purr, or a little grin, and Alice was very glad to have someone to talk to.

But the Cat’s head was all that appeared; the rest of its body was quite invisible.

events.title: Royal Displeasure and Sentence for the Cheshire Cat
detailed_summary: Alice complained to the Cheshire Cat about the unfairness and chaos of the croquet game.
She highlighted the constant quarreling, lack of apparent rules, and confusion caused by the living game pieces like wandering arches and fleeing hedgehogs.
The Cat quietly asked Alice for her opinion of the Queen.
Alice started to express her dislike but noticed the Queen listening nearby.
She quickly modified her sentence to say the Queen was so likely to win that finishing the game seemed pointless.
The Queen smiled at this remark and moved on.
The King approached Alice, asking who she was talking to and observing the Cat's head with curiosity.
Alice introduced the Cat as her friend.
The King expressed his dislike for the Cat's appearance but permitted it to kiss his hand.
The Cat declined the offer.
The King admonished the Cat for impertinence and its stare, hiding behind Alice.
Alice remarked that she'd read somewhere that a cat may look at a king.
The King firmly declared the Cat must be removed and called the Queen over.
He requested that the Queen have the Cat removed.
The Queen, without hesitation or looking, issued her standard solution: "Off with his head!"
The King eagerly volunteered to fetch the executioner himself and rushed away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I’ll fetch the executioner myself,” said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.

events.text_segment:
“I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”
“How do you like the Queen?” said the Cat in a low voice.
“Not at all,” said Alice: “she’s so extremely—” Just then she noticed that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on, “—likely to win, that it’s hardly worth while finishing the game.”
The Queen smiled and passed on.
“Who are you talking to?” said the King, going up to Alice, and looking at the Cat’s head with great curiosity.
“It’s a friend of mine—a Cheshire Cat,” said Alice: “allow me to introduce it.”
“I don’t like the look of it at all,” said the King: “however, it may kiss my hand if it likes.”
“I’d rather not,” the Cat remarked.
“Don’t be impertinent,” said the King, “and don’t look at me like that!” He got behind Alice as he spoke.
“A cat may look at a king,” said Alice. “I’ve read that in some book, but I don’t remember where.”
“Well, it must be removed,” said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, “My dear! I wish you would have this cat removed!”
The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small. “Off with his head!” she said, without even looking round.
“I’ll fetch the executioner myself,” said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.

The Cheshire Cat, who had been sitting on a branch of a tree, merely smiled and asked, “What’s your opinion of the Queen of Hearts?”

Alice thought a moment, and then said, “She’s so——” but she checked herself hastily, for she saw the Queen of Hearts looking at her out of the corner of her eye. “I mean, she’s so——” she went on, getting redder every moment, “she’s so——”

“Come, now,” said the Queen, “I know what you mean. She’s so——”

“——likely to win,” Alice added in a feeble tone.

The Queen smiled and walked on.

The King of Hearts, who had been watching the game with great interest, now came up to Alice and asked, “Who are you talking to?”

“It’s the Cheshire Cat,” said Alice, pointing to the tree.

The King looked at the Cat with a puzzled expression. “I don’t like the look of that Cat,” he said. “He has such a——”

“——grin,” Alice suggested.

“——face,” the King finished. “I shall have him removed.”

“Why?” said Alice.

“Because he’s impertinent,” said the King. “He’s staring at me!”

The Cat, who had been watching the conversation with great interest, now looked at the King with a very large grin indeed.

“Off with his head!” the King cried, in a great rage.

“Nonsense!” said Alice. “You don’t mean that!”

“I do, I do!” the King said, stamping with his foot. “Off with his head! Fetch the executioner!”

The Queen, who had been listening to the conversation, now came up and said, “Off with his head!”

“Very well,” said the King, and he hurried off to fetch the executioner.

I don’t think they play at all fairly,” Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, “and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any apparent rules in particular; at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!”

The Cheshire Cat, who had been sitting on a branch of a tree, merely smiled and asked, “What’s your opinion of the Queen of Hearts?”

Alice thought a moment, and then said, “She’s so——” but she checked herself hastily, for she saw the Queen of Hearts looking at her out of the corner of her eye. “I mean, she’s so——” she went on, getting redder every moment, “she’s so——”

“Come, now,” said the Queen, “I know what you mean. She’s so——”

“——likely to win,” Alice added in a feeble tone.

The Queen smiled and walked on.

The King of Hearts, who had been watching the game with great interest, now came up to Alice and asked, “Who are you talking to?”

“It’s the Cheshire Cat,” said Alice, pointing to the tree.

The King looked at the Cat with a puzzled expression. “I don’t like the look of that Cat,” he said. “He has such a——”

“——grin,” Alice suggested.

“——face,” the King finished. “I shall have him removed.”

“Why?” said Alice.

“Because he’s impertinent,” said the King. “He’s staring at me!”

The Cat, who had been watching the conversation with great interest, now looked at the King with a very large grin indeed.

“Off with his head!” the King cried, in a great rage.

“Nonsense!” said Alice. “You don’t mean that!”

“I do, I do!” the King said, stamping with his foot. “Off with his head! Fetch the executioner!”

The Queen, who had been listening to the conversation, now came up and said, “Off with his head!”

“Very well,” said the King, and he hurried off to fetch the executioner.

Alice shook her head. “It’s all very well for them to run away,” she muttered, “but I’ve got to find my way through this nonsense somehow.”

events.title: Croquet Chaos and the Executioner's Conundrum
detailed_summary: Hearing the Queen shouting angrily in the distance, Alice decided to check on the croquet game.
She had already heard the Queen sentence three players to execution for missing turns and felt uneasy about the general confusion, which made it hard to know whose turn it was.
Alice went searching for her hedgehog ball.
She found her hedgehog fighting another one, which seemed like a good croquet opportunity.
However, her flamingo mallet had wandered to the other side of the garden and was attempting to fly into a tree.
By the time Alice retrieved the flamingo, the hedgehog fight was over, and both hedgehogs were gone.
Alice noted resignedly that the arches on her side of the ground were also gone.
She tucked the flamingo under her arm to prevent another escape and went back to talk to the Cheshire Cat.
Upon returning, Alice found a large crowd gathered around the Cat's location.
An argument was in progress between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, all talking simultaneously, while everyone else looked uncomfortable and remained silent.
Alice was immediately asked by all three to settle the dispute.
They repeated their arguments, though Alice struggled to understand them as they all spoke at once.
The executioner argued he couldn't behead something without a body, stating he'd never done it before and wouldn't start now.
The King argued that anything with a head could be beheaded and dismissed the executioner's point as nonsense.
The Queen argued that if the issue wasn't resolved instantly, she would have everyone executed, which caused widespread anxiety.
Alice suggested asking the Duchess about the Cat, as it belonged to her.
The Queen ordered the executioner to fetch the Duchess from prison.
The executioner dashed off.
As soon as the executioner left, the Cheshire Cat's head began to fade.
By the time the executioner returned with the Duchess, the Cat's head had vanished completely.
The King and executioner searched frantically for the disappeared head, while the rest of the attendees returned to the croquet game.

events.text_segment:
Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.
The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree.
By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: “but it doesn’t matter much,” thought Alice, “as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground.” So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.
When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.
The executioner’s argument was, that you couldn’t cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn’t going to begin at his time of life.
The King’s argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren’t to talk nonsense.
The Queen’s argument was, that if something wasn’t done about it in less than no time she’d have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)
Alice could think of nothing else to say but “It belongs to the Duchess: you’d better ask her about it.”
“She’s in prison,” the Queen said to the executioner: “fetch her here.” And the executioner went off like an arrow.
The Cat’s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.

Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to execution for no better reason than that they happened to be in the way; so she felt there would be very little difficulty in getting them to begin again. As she went through the wood, she met the Cheshire Cat, who was sitting on a branch of a tree, grinning as usual, and great numbers of little birds were flying about his head making quite a rattling noise with their wings.

"Is that your hedgehog?" Alice asked, looking at the Cat's tail, which was now visible, and which she had taken for a hedgehog.

"It is not," said the Cat: "you'll see me pass it, by-and-by, on the other side of the hedge."

"When I get to that side," said Alice, "I shall never get home again. I shall never get to my own world again."

"You may just as well say," added the Cat, "that you never get to the other side of the hedge."

"Which would be just the same thing," said Alice, rather doubtfully, "as being nowhere at all."

"Exactly," said the Cat.

Alice was just beginning to think to herself how she would contrive to keep the Cat company, when she heard a voice behind her, and turned round suddenly to find herself face to face with the Queen of Hearts. The Queen was so tall that her head went far above Alice's shoulder, and she had a crown on her head, and a sceptre in her hand, and a great many soldiers with her. LLM_completions.prefix-probing: Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion. There was a loud cry of 'Off with their heads!' and Alice, with a shiver, thought she would not be the one to stay and find out what happened next. She turned around and began to make her way back through the garden, which now seemed even more peculiar than before. The flowers were whispering to each other in hushed tones, and the trees were swaying as if they were dancing to a tune only they could hear. Alice could not help but feel that the garden was alive in a way that it had not been before, as if it, too, was aware of the Queen's temper and the chaos that followed in her wake. As she walked, she passed by a group of gardeners who were busily painting the roses red. 'Why are you painting them red?' Alice asked, curious. 'Because they're white,' one of the gardeners replied, as if it were the most obvious thing in the world. 'But they were white to begin with,' Alice said, puzzled. 'Yes, but the Queen of Hearts likes red roses,' the gardener said, as if that explained everything. Alice nodded, though she was still confused. She continued on her way, and soon she came upon a group of playing cards who were sitting around a table, playing a game of croquet. 'What are you playing?' Alice asked. 'We're playing croquet with flamingos and hedgehogs,' one of the cards said. 'It's a bit of a mess, really. The Queen keeps shouting at us for no reason.' 'But why are you playing with flamingos and hedgehogs?' Alice asked. 'Because the Queen said so,' the card replied. 'She said we should use flamingos for mallets and hedgehogs for balls. It's a bit strange, but we do as we're told.' Alice was about to ask another question when she heard a loud crash and a shout of 'Off with their heads!' She turned around and saw the Queen of Hearts storming through the garden, her face red with anger. 'Who did that?' she shouted. 'It was the hedgehog!' one of the playing cards cried out. 'Off with its head!' the Queen shouted. 'But it's just a hedgehog!' Alice said, stepping forward. 'It's not a person!' 'It's a criminal!' the Queen shouted. 'Off with its head!' Alice was about to argue further when she felt a sudden jolt and found herself tumbling through the air once more. She landed with a thud and found herself back in the real world, safe and sound. She looked around and realized that she was back in her own home, in her own bed. She smiled to herself, thinking about the strange and wonderful world she had just left behind.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER IX. The Mock Turtle’s Story

events.title: Alice and the Moralizing Duchess
detailed_summary: The Duchess expresses great happiness at seeing Alice again, linking arms with her companionably.
Alice reciprocates the pleasure, finding the Duchess in a surprisingly good mood and privately theorizing that pepper was the cause of her earlier ill temper in the kitchen.

Alice internally reflects on becoming a Duchess herself and banning pepper, leading her to develop a theory that various foods influence personality: pepper causes hot tempers, vinegar causes sourness, camomile causes bitterness, and sweets cause sweet tempers.
Lost in thought, Alice is startled when the Duchess points out her abstraction, promising to find the moral of it later.
Alice tentatively suggests that perhaps not everything possesses a moral.
The Duchess dismisses this, insisting on the universality of morals if one looks for them, and presses closer to Alice.
Alice feels uncomfortable with the Duchess's proximity due to her perceived ugliness and the awkwardness of the Duchess resting her sharp chin on Alice's shoulder, but endures it to avoid rudeness.
To maintain conversation, Alice remarks that the croquet game seems to be proceeding better.
The Duchess agrees, offering the moral that love makes the world go round.
Alice quietly shares a different saying: that the world turns because everyone minds their own business.
The Duchess considers this much the same, digs her chin into Alice's shoulder again, and provides another moral concerning the relationship between sense and sounds.
Alice silently observes the Duchess's persistent habit of finding morals everywhere.
The Duchess pauses, then explains she refrains from putting her arm around Alice's waist because she is unsure about the temperament of Alice's flamingo croquet mallet, asking if she should test it.
Alice cautiously discourages the experiment, warning that the flamingo might bite.
The Duchess agrees, noting that both flamingoes and mustard bite, and derives the moral 'Birds of a feather flock together'.
Alice logically points out that mustard is not a bird.
The Duchess compliments Alice's clarity and readily agrees.
Alice tentatively identifies mustard as a mineral.
The Duchess concurs enthusiastically, inventing a nearby mustard mine and offering a moral about ownership: 'The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.'
Alice, not having paid attention to the last moral, corrects herself, stating mustard is a vegetable.
The Duchess agrees once more, giving the moral 'Be what you would seem to be', followed immediately by an extraordinarily long and confusing elaboration of the same principle.
Alice politely responds that she would grasp the lengthy moral better if it were written down, as she cannot follow it when spoken.
The Duchess replies with satisfaction that she could say much more if she desired.
Alice requests that the Duchess not exert herself further.
The Duchess waves off the idea of trouble, declaring she gifts Alice everything she has said so far.
Alice privately thinks this is a worthless gift and is glad birthday presents aren't similar, but keeps the thought to herself.
The Duchess jabs Alice with her chin again, asking if she is thinking once more.
Alice sharply affirms her right to think, feeling increasingly bothered.
The Duchess retorts that Alice's right to think is comparable to pigs' right to fly and begins to state the moral...

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Just about as much right,” said the Duchess, “as pigs have to fly; and the m—”

events.text_segment:
“You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.
Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.
“When I’m a Duchess,” she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), “I won’t have any pepper in my kitchen at all. Soup does very well without—Maybe it’s always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,” she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, “and vinegar that makes them sour—and camomile that makes them bitter—and—and barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn’t be so stingy about it, you know—”
She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear. “You’re thinking about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can’t tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit.”
“Perhaps it hasn’t one,” Alice ventured to remark.
“Tut, tut, child!” said the Duchess. “Everything’s got a moral, if only you can find it.” And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice’s side as she spoke.
Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the Duchess was very ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the right height to rest her chin upon Alice’s shoulder, and it was an uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she bore it as well as she could.
“The game’s going on rather better now,” she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.
“’Tis so,” said the Duchess: “and the moral of that is—‘Oh, ’tis love, ’tis love, that makes the world go round!’”
“Somebody said,” Alice whispered, “that it’s done by everybody minding their own business!”
“Ah, well! It means much the same thing,” said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice’s shoulder as she added, “and the moral of that is—‘Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of themselves.’”
“How fond she is of finding morals in things!” Alice thought to herself.
“I dare say you’re wondering why I don’t put my arm round your waist,” the Duchess said after a pause: “the reason is, that I’m doubtful about the temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?”
“He might bite,” Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.
“Very true,” said the Duchess: “flamingoes and mustard both bite. And the moral of that is—‘Birds of a feather flock together.’”
“Only mustard isn’t a bird,” Alice remarked.
“Right, as usual,” said the Duchess: “what a clear way you have of putting things!”
“It’s a mineral, I think,” said Alice.
“Of course it is,” said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to everything that Alice said; “there’s a large mustard-mine near here. And the moral of that is—‘The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.’”
“Oh, I know!” exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark, “it’s a vegetable. It doesn’t look like one, but it is.”
“I quite agree with you,” said the Duchess; “and the moral of that is—‘Be what you would seem to be’—or if you’d like it put more simply—‘Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.’”
“I think I should understand that better,” Alice said very politely, “if I had it written down: but I can’t quite follow it as you say it.”
“That’s nothing to what I could say if I chose,” the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.
“Pray don’t trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,” said Alice.
“Oh, don’t talk about trouble!” said the Duchess. “I make you a present of everything I’ve said as yet.”
“A cheap sort of present!” thought Alice. “I’m glad they don’t give birthday presents like that!” But she did not venture to say it out loud.
“Thinking again?” the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.
“I’ve a right to think,” said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.
“Just about as much right,” said the Duchess, “as pigs have to fly; and the m—”

You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.

“I’m very glad to see you too!” said Alice, with rather more politeness than she felt; for she could not at all make out what the Duchess was talking about.

“Ah, you don’t know how glad I am!” said the Duchess; “I’ve been so unhappy for so long! I thought I should never see you again!”

Alice was silent, for she had no idea what to say. She was privately wondering whether the Duchess had been in a good temper all this time, or whether it was only a sudden fit of politeness.

“I wonder if pepper has anything to do with it,” she thought to herself. “I remember the Duchess was in a very bad temper in the kitchen, and she always had pepper on the table. Perhaps it’s the same with other things—like vinegar, and camomile, and sweets. I wonder if that’s why I’m so cross when I eat a lot of sweets?”

She was so lost in thought that she did not notice the Duchess had stopped, and was looking at her with a very solemn face.

“You’re thinking again,” said the Duchess, in a low, mysterious voice.

“I was only thinking of the moral of the story,” said Alice, trying to look as if she knew what she was talking about.

“Ah, but there’s always a moral,” said the Duchess, pressing closer to her. “I always find one, if I look hard enough.”

Alice felt rather uncomfortable, for the Duchess was very ugly, and she was resting her sharp chin on Alice’s shoulder in a way that made her feel quite awkward. But she did not like to be rude, so she said nothing.

“I think the croquet game is going on very nicely,” she remarked, in an attempt to keep the conversation going.

“Yes, indeed,” said the Duchess. “And the moral is—Love makes the world go round.”

“I’ve heard another one,” said Alice, in a low voice. “It’s that the world goes on because everyone minds their own business.”

The Duchess considered this for a moment. “That’s much the same thing,” she said, and dug her chin into Alice’s shoulder again. “And the moral is—Sense is a sort of sound.”

Alice could not help laughing at this, and the Duchess laughed too, and dug her chin in again.

“I see you’re very fond of morals,” said Alice, trying to change the subject.

“I am,” said the Duchess. “I always find one, if I look hard enough. But I don’t put my arm round your waist, because I don’t know what your flamingo is like. Perhaps I should test it?”

“Oh, don’t do that!” said Alice, in a frightened voice. “He might bite!”

“Ah, but so do mustard and flamingoes,” said the Duchess. “And the moral is—Birds of a feather flock together.”

“But mustard isn’t a bird,” said Alice.

“No, I know that,” said the Duchess. “But it’s a very good moral all the same. And the moral is—The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.”

“I don’t think that’s quite the same moral,” said Alice, who had not been paying much attention to the last one.

“No, it isn’t,” said the Duchess. “But it’s a very good one. And the moral is—Be what you would seem to be!”

This was followed by a long and very elaborate explanation, which Alice could not follow at all. She tried to look interested, but she was really very tired of the Duchess’s morals.

“I should like to have the moral written down,” she said at last, “if you don’t mind.”

“Ah, but I could say a great deal more if I chose,” said the Duchess, with a triumphant air.

“Please don’t,” said Alice, in a faint voice.

“Very well,” said the Duchess, with a wave of her hand. “I give you all I have said so far, and I give it you freely.”

Alice thought to herself that it was a very poor sort of gift, and she was very glad that birthday presents were not like that. But she said nothing, and only smiled.

The Duchess gave her a sharp jab with her chin. “Are you thinking again?” she whispered.

“Yes, I am,” said Alice, rather sharply.

“Ah, but you have no more right to think than pigs have to fly,” said the Duchess, and she began to say the moral—

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!” said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together. The Duchess was in a surprisingly good mood, which Alice found both surprising and slightly disconcerting. Usually, the Duchess was either scowling, muttering about her baby, or shouting at the Cheshire Cat for grinning too much. But today, she seemed almost cheerful, and Alice couldn’t help but wonder what had caused this sudden change in temperament.

As they walked, the Duchess began to chatter away, her voice a mixture of excitement and nostalgia. “Do you remember the time we met the Mad Hatter at his tea party? I do! It was the most delightful chaos I’ve ever seen. The Hatter was quite the character, wasn’t he? Always talking about time and never making sense. I think he was trying to tell us something, but I never quite figured it out.”

Alice smiled, recalling the absurdity of the tea party. “Yes, he was quite the enigma. I remember the Dormouse nearly falling into the teacup, and the March Hare was so distracted by the tea that he forgot to serve it properly.”

The Duchess chuckled, her laughter echoing through the air. “Oh, the March Hare! He was always in a state of confusion. I think he was trying to make sense of the world, but it was all too much for him. Poor thing. I hope he’s found some peace by now.”

As they continued their walk, the landscape around them began to shift. The trees grew taller, their branches twisting into strange shapes, and the flowers bloomed in colors that seemed to shimmer and change with the light. Alice felt a sense of wonder as she took in the beauty of the world around her, and she couldn’t help but feel a bit more at ease in the Duchess’s company.

“Do you think we’ll run into any more of the characters from the tea party?” Alice asked, her curiosity piqued. “I’d love to see the Hatter again. I think he had some interesting things to say about time and existence.”

The Duchess nodded thoughtfully. “I believe we might. The Hatter is quite the wanderer, and he tends to pop up when you least expect him. I imagine he’s still trying to figure out the meaning of life, or at least the meaning of tea. It’s a bit of a mystery, really.”

Just as the Duchess finished speaking, a loud crash echoed through the trees, and a figure stumbled into view. It was the Mad Hatter, looking as disheveled as ever, with his hat askew and his eyes wide with confusion. “Oh, good! I found you!” he exclaimed, his voice a mix of relief and panic. “I was looking for someone to help me with this riddle. It’s driving me mad!”

Alice and the Duchess exchanged glances, both of them intrigued. “What riddle is that?” Alice asked, stepping closer to the Hatter.

The Hatter wrung his hands, his expression a mixture of frustration and excitement. “It’s about time! I’ve been trying to figure it out for ages, but I just can’t seem to get it right. You see, time is like a clock, but it’s also like a teacup. It’s all very confusing, and I need someone to help me make sense of it!”

The Duchess laughed, her voice warm and inviting. “Well, we’d be happy to help, dear Hatter. What exactly is the riddle?”

The Hatter took a deep breath, his eyes sparkling with the thrill of the challenge. “It goes like this: ‘I am the beginning of the end, and the end of time and space. I am essential to all life, and I appear twice in every week. What am I?’”

Alice thought for a moment, her mind racing. “Is it ‘time’?” she asked, her voice filled with uncertainty.

The Hatter shook his head, his expression one of disappointment. “No, no, no! It’s not that simple. It’s something else entirely. I think it’s a letter, but I can’t quite put my finger on it.”

The Duchess, ever the optimist, chimed in. “What if it’s the letter ‘E’? It’s the beginning of the end, and it appears twice in every week. That seems to fit!”

The Hatter’s eyes widened in surprise. “Oh! That’s brilliant! I never would have thought of that. Thank you, Duchess! You’ve saved me from my madness!”

With the riddle solved, the Hatter’s demeanor shifted from one of confusion to one of joy. “Now, let’s have a tea party! I’ve been waiting for this moment for ages!” he exclaimed, and with that, he led them to a nearby table, where an assortment of teacups and scones awaited them. The three of them sat down, and as they sipped their tea and shared stories, Alice felt a sense of warmth and camaraderie that she hadn’t felt in a long time. It was a moment of pure joy in the whimsical world of Wonderland, where the absurd made perfect sense and the impossible was just another day.

events.title: The Queen's Intervention and Game's End
detailed_summary: The Duchess abruptly falls silent mid-word ('moral'), and her arm linked with Alice's begins to shake.
Alice looks up to see the Queen standing before them, arms folded, looking furious.
In a weak voice, the Duchess attempts a polite greeting to the Queen.
The Queen ignores the greeting and shouts an ultimatum at the Duchess: remove herself or her head immediately.
The Duchess makes her choice and disappears instantly.
The Queen instructs Alice, who is too frightened to speak, to resume the croquet game.
Alice slowly follows the Queen back to the playing area.
The other players, who had been resting in the shade during the Queen's absence, scramble back to the game upon her return, warned by the Queen that any delay would result in their deaths.
Throughout the remainder of the game, the Queen continuously argues with players and shouts 'Off with his head!' or 'Off with her head!'
The soldiers, previously serving as croquet arches, have to leave their positions to escort the condemned players into custody.
Consequently, after about half an hour, no arches are left on the ground, and all players, apart from the King, the Queen, and Alice, have been arrested and sentenced to execution.
Finally, the Queen stops, completely out of breath.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, “Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?”

events.text_segment:
But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.
“A fine day, your Majesty!” the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.
“Now, I give you fair warning,” shouted the Queen, stamping on the ground as she spoke; “either you or your head must be off, and that in about half no time! Take your choice!”
The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.
“Let’s go on with the game,” the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the croquet-ground.
The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen’s absence, and were resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment’s delay would cost them their lives.
All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players, and shouting “Off with his head!” or “Off with her head!” Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and under sentence of execution.
Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, “Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, looking as if she were about to say something extremely unpleasant. The Duchess gave a low, feeble cry of ‘Oh, my dear! I’m so sorry!’ and tried to curtsy as low as she could, which was not very low indeed, considering how short she was. But the Queen took no notice whatever. She only looked at the Duchess, and said, in a loud, sharp voice, ‘Off with her head!’ or, at least, something very like that, for the words came so fast that Alice could not quite catch them. The Duchess gave a little scream of ‘Oh, my dear! Oh, my dear!’ and vanished in a moment, just like a candle being blown out. Then the Queen turned to Alice, who was trembling all over, and said, ‘Come, child, the game must go on!’ and she marched off, and Alice followed, as well as she could, through the crowd of people who were all running about in the greatest confusion. The other players, who had been resting in the shade during the Queen’s absence, now scrambled back to their places, for they had heard the Queen’s voice, and they knew what it meant. The Queen was in one of her terrible tempers, and she was shouting ‘Off with his head!’ or ‘Off with her head!’ at every player who made the least mistake. The soldiers, who had been standing as croquet-arches, had to run off to fetch the headsman, and so the game went on, with the Queen getting more and more out of breath, and the players getting more and more frightened. After about half an hour, there were no more arches left on the ground, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, had been arrested and sentenced to death. At last the Queen stopped, quite out of breath, and said, in a very faint voice, ‘I declare I’ve quite forgotten what I was going to say next—come, we’d better play croquet again.’

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up in alarm, and found that the Duchess was fast asleep. She was sitting on a three-legged stool, with her head leaning against the wall, and her eyes shut fast. Alice was very much puzzled. She had never seen anyone fall asleep so suddenly before, and she was afraid that something was wrong. She gently tried to shake the Duchess’s shoulder, but the Duchess only snored a little and did not wake up. Alice looked around the room, hoping to find someone else who might be able to help. The Cheshire Cat was nowhere to be seen, and the Mad Hatter had long since disappeared. The only other person in the room was the cook, who was still stirring a large pot of soup on the stove. Alice hesitated for a moment, then decided to ask the cook what had happened. “Why did the Duchess fall asleep?” she asked. The cook did not answer, but only gave her a strange look and continued stirring the soup. Alice was beginning to feel very confused. She had expected the Duchess to be loud and angry, not quiet and sleepy. Just then, the Duchess gave a loud snore and opened her eyes. “Well, that was a nice nap,” she said, as if nothing had happened. Alice was too surprised to say anything. The Duchess smiled at her and said, “Come along, dear, we have a tea party to attend.” And with that, she took Alice’s arm once more and led her out of the room.

events.title: Journey to the Mock Turtle
detailed_summary: Alice replies that she has not seen the Mock Turtle and doesn't even know what one is.
The Queen explains it's the creature from which Mock Turtle Soup is derived.
Alice reiterates she has never encountered or heard of such a creature.
The Queen invites Alice to come along, stating the Mock Turtle will recount his history to her.
As they depart, Alice hears the King quietly announce to the remaining group that they are all pardoned.
Alice silently expresses relief at this news, having been distressed by the number of executions ordered.
They quickly arrive at a spot where a Gryphon is fast asleep in the sun.
The Queen rouses the Gryphon, instructing it to take Alice to meet the Mock Turtle and hear his story.
The Queen explains she must return to oversee some executions and departs, leaving Alice with the Gryphon.
Alice feels uneasy about the Gryphon but judges staying with it to be as safe as pursuing the 'savage' Queen, so she waits.
The Gryphon sits up, rubs its eyes, watches the Queen until she is gone, and then chuckles.
It remarks, partly to itself and partly to Alice, 'What fun!'
When Alice inquires what is fun, the Gryphon clarifies it refers to the Queen.
The Gryphon assures Alice that the Queen's talk of executions is merely 'her fancy' and that nobody is ever actually executed, urging Alice to 'Come on!'
Alice follows slowly, reflecting internally that she has never been ordered around so much in her life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No,” said Alice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”

events.text_segment:
“No,” said Alice. “I don’t even know what a Mock Turtle is.”
“It’s the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,” said the Queen.
“I never saw one, or heard of one,” said Alice.
“Come on, then,” said the Queen, “and he shall tell you his history,”
As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice, to the company generally, “You are all pardoned.” “Come, that’s a good thing!” she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don’t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.) “Up, lazy thing!” said the Queen, “and take this young lady to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered;” and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.
The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled. “What fun!” said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.
“What is the fun?” said Alice.
“Why, she,” said the Gryphon. “It’s all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know. Come on!”
“Everybody says ‘come on!’ here,” thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: “I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"No," said Alice. "I've never seen a Mock Turtle, if that's what you mean."

"Haven't you?" said the Queen. "Come, come, you're interested in the history of these parts—and we very soon get to the history of July."

"I don't know anything about the history of July," said Alice.

"You don't?" said the Queen, turning to the others. "Then I'll have to send for the history of July to be put into your head."

Alice felt a little nervous at this. "I'm afraid I can't tell you much about the Mock Turtle," she said, trying to change the subject. "I don't even know what one is."

"Hush!" said the Queen. "Don't interrupt. You're not to talk."

This was very provoking, and Alice began to think that perhaps after all it would be better to say nothing. So she sat still and said nothing.

"Come, now," said the Queen, "I've told you once, and I'll tell you again—this is the Mock Turtle."

"But I don't want to know it," said Alice, who was very tired of the whole thing now.

"You don't mean that," said the Queen. "You must come and hear the Mock Turtle's story."

So Alice was conducted, though she was very unwillingly, to where the Mock Turtle was sitting in the sun, and the Gryphon was lying fast asleep beside him.

"Wake up!" said the Queen, shaking the Gryphon by the shoulder. "Take this young lady to the Mock Turtle. He wants to tell her his history."

The Gryphon yawned and stretched itself. "Why, I thought you were going to have me executed," it said, in a sleepy voice.

"That's only her fancy," said the Queen. "Come along, now."

So the Gryphon took Alice on its back, and they went off together.

"I'm not the least afraid of you," said Alice, trying to sound brave. "What's the use of talking about executions? You don't mean half the things you say."

"I don't, indeed," said the Gryphon, laughing. "The Queen's got a temper, that's all."

"I'm glad to hear it," said Alice. "I thought she was a regular brute."

"She is," said the Gryphon. "But she's a very good sort, really."

"I don't believe that," said Alice. "She's been ordering executions all day."

"Oh, that's only her fancy," said the Gryphon. "She never does anything she says. Come on!"

And so they went on, the Gryphon trotting along with a great deal of dignity, and Alice following as best she could, though she was very tired of the whole thing.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“No,” said Alice. “I’ve a feeling it’s something about the raven and the writing desk.”

The Cheshire Cat, floating in midair with only his grin visible, chuckled. “Ah, yes, the raven and the writing desk. A classic conundrum. But you’re not thinking clearly, dear Alice. That’s not the riddle I asked.”

Alice frowned, her brow furrowing. “I’m sorry, I must have forgotten. What was the riddle again?”

The Cat sighed, his grin stretching wider. “It was, ‘Why is a raven like a writing desk?’”

Alice blinked. “I don’t know. I really don’t know. I’ve heard that riddle before, but I’ve never heard the answer.”

The Cat’s grin wavered slightly. “Well, I haven’t either,” he admitted. “But I thought it was a good riddle. Some say the answer is that they both have legs. Others say it’s that they both can be used to write with. But I like to think the answer is simply that they both have a certain air of mystery about them.”

Alice laughed. “That’s a very poetic answer.”

The Cat’s grin returned. “That’s the spirit, Alice. In Wonderland, the answers are never what they seem. Sometimes, the journey is more important than the destination.”

Just then, a loud crash echoed through the forest, and a very flustered White Rabbit tumbled out of the bushes, clutching a pocket watch. “Oh dear, oh dear! I’m late! I’m so very late!”

Alice and the Cheshire Cat both turned to look at the Rabbit, who was now running in circles, muttering to himself. “I must be off! I have a very important meeting with the Queen of Hearts!”

Alice watched as the Rabbit disappeared into the trees, and the Cheshire Cat’s grin faded slightly. “Well,” he said, “it seems our riddle has been interrupted. But don’t worry, Alice. There will be more riddles, and more mysteries, and more adventures in this wonderful, wondrous place.”

events.title: The Mock Turtle's Tale of Education
detailed_summary: They soon see the Mock Turtle in the distance, appearing sad and lonely on a rock ledge, sighing audibly as they approach.
Alice feels deep sympathy and asks the Gryphon the cause of his sorrow.
The Gryphon dismisses the Mock Turtle's sadness as 'all his fancy,' insisting he has no real sorrow, and again says, 'Come on!'
They go up to the Mock Turtle, who observes them with large, tear-filled eyes but remains silent.
The Gryphon introduces Alice, explaining she wants to hear the Mock Turtle's history.
The Mock Turtle agrees in a somber tone, instructing both Alice and the Gryphon to sit down and not speak until he has finished.
They sit, and silence ensues for several minutes; Alice privately wonders how he can finish if he doesn't start, but waits patiently.
The Mock Turtle finally begins with a deep sigh, stating, 'Once... I was a real Turtle.'
This is followed by another long silence, punctuated only by the Gryphon's occasional 'Hjckrrh!' sound and the Mock Turtle's continuous, heavy sobbing.
Alice is tempted to leave after thanking him for the 'story' but senses there must be more to come, so she stays quiet.
The Mock Turtle resumes, calmer but still sobbing intermittently, describing attending school in the sea as a child.
He mentions the master was an old Turtle they called Tortoise.
Alice interrupts to ask why they called him Tortoise if he wasn't one.
The Mock Turtle irritably explains it was a pun ('because he taught us') and calls Alice 'very dull'.
The Gryphon adds that Alice should be ashamed for asking such a simple question, and they both fall silent, looking at Alice, who feels mortified.
Eventually, the Gryphon prompts the Mock Turtle to continue.
The Mock Turtle repeats that they went to school in the sea.
Alice interjects that she never said she didn't believe him.
The Mock Turtle insists she did.
The Gryphon silences Alice before she can respond further.
The Mock Turtle continues, claiming they received the finest education, attending school daily.
Alice mentions she also attended a day-school, suggesting he needn't be so proud.
The Mock Turtle anxiously asks if her school included 'extras'.
Alice confirms learning French and music.
The Mock Turtle then asks about 'washing'.
Alice replies indignantly that they certainly did not learn washing.
Relieved, the Mock Turtle declares Alice's school inferior because his school's bill listed 'French, music, and washing—extra'.
Alice points out that living at the bottom of the sea would make washing unnecessary.
The Mock Turtle sighs that he couldn't afford the extras and only took the standard course.
Alice inquires about the standard course.
The Mock Turtle lists the subjects: 'Reeling and Writhing' first, then Arithmetic branches named 'Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision'.
Alice ventures to ask about 'Uglification'.
The Gryphon reacts with surprise, asking if she truly hasn't heard of it and relating it to the concept of 'beautify,' concluding that if she doesn't know 'uglify,' she must be a simpleton.
Feeling discouraged, Alice turns back to the Mock Turtle and asks about other subjects.

The Mock Turtle enumerates more subjects using his flappers: 'Mystery' (ancient and modern) with 'Seaography,' then 'Drawling,' taught weekly by an old conger-eel master, which included 'Stretching' and 'Fainting in Coils'.
Alice asks what that class was like.
The Mock Turtle states he's too stiff to demonstrate and the Gryphon never learned it.
The Gryphon confirms, explaining he lacked time as he attended the Classics master, an old crab.
The Mock Turtle sighs that he never studied with the crab, who reportedly taught 'Laughing and Grief'.
The Gryphon confirms this, sighing as well, and both creatures cover their faces with their paws.
Alice quickly changes the subject, asking how many hours of lessons they had per day.
The Mock Turtle explains it was ten hours the first day, nine the second, and decreasing daily.
Alice finds this plan peculiar.
The Gryphon explains the term 'lessons' originates from this daily 'lessening' of hours.
This new idea intrigues Alice, and after some thought, she deduces the eleventh day must have been a holiday.
The Mock Turtle confirms it was.
Alice eagerly asks what happened on the twelfth day.
The Gryphon interrupts firmly, declaring that's enough discussion about lessons and instructs the Mock Turtle to talk about games instead.

events.text_segment:
They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She pitied him deeply. “What is his sorrow?” she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, “It’s all his fancy, that: he hasn’t got no sorrow, you know. Come on!”
So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.
“This here young lady,” said the Gryphon, “she wants for to know your history, she do.”
“I’ll tell it her,” said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: “sit down, both of you, and don’t speak a word till I’ve finished.”
So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to herself, “I don’t see how he can ever finish, if he doesn’t begin.” But she waited patiently.
“Once,” said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, “I was a real Turtle.”
These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of “Hjckrrh!” from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, “Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,” but she could not help thinking there must be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.
“When we were little,” the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, “we went to school in the sea. The master was an old Turtle—we used to call him Tortoise—”
“Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?” Alice asked.
“We called him Tortoise because he taught us,” said the Mock Turtle angrily: “really you are very dull!”
“You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,” added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, “Drive on, old fellow! Don’t be all day about it!” and he went on in these words:
“Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—”
“I never said I didn’t!” interrupted Alice.
“You did,” said the Mock Turtle.
“Hold your tongue!” added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on.
“We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—”
“I’ve been to a day-school, too,” said Alice; “you needn’t be so proud as all that.”
“With extras?” asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.
“Yes,” said Alice, “we learned French and music.”
“And washing?” said the Mock Turtle.
“Certainly not!” said Alice indignantly.
“Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school,” said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief. “Now at ours they had at the end of the bill, ‘French, music, and washing—extra.’”
“You couldn’t have wanted it much,” said Alice; “living at the bottom of the sea.”
“I couldn’t afford to learn it.” said the Mock Turtle with a sigh. “I only took the regular course.”
“What was that?” inquired Alice.
“Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,” the Mock Turtle replied; “and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.”
“I never heard of ‘Uglification,’” Alice ventured to say. “What is it?”
The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise. “What! Never heard of uglifying!” it exclaimed. “You know what to beautify is, I suppose?”
“Yes,” said Alice doubtfully: “it means—to—make—anything—prettier.”
“Well, then,” the Gryphon went on, “if you don’t know what to uglify is, you are a simpleton.”
Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said “What else had you to learn?”
“Well, there was Mystery,” the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers, “—Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: he taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils.”
“What was that like?” said Alice.
“Well, I can’t show it you myself,” the Mock Turtle said: “I’m too stiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it.”
“Hadn’t time,” said the Gryphon: “I went to the Classics master, though. He was an old crab, he was.”
“I never went to him,” the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: “he taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say.”
“So he did, so he did,” said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.
“And how many hours a day did you do lessons?” said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.
“Ten hours the first day,” said the Mock Turtle: “nine the next, and so on.”
“What a curious plan!” exclaimed Alice.
“That’s the reason they’re called lessons,” the Gryphon remarked: “because they lessen from day to day.”
This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark. “Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?”
“Of course it was,” said the Mock Turtle.
“And how did you manage on the twelfth?” Alice went on eagerly.
“That’s enough about lessons,” the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: “tell her something about the games now.”

They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break.

"What does he sigh for?" said Alice, half aloud, expecting perhaps that the Gryphon would answer.

"He can't help it," said the Gryphon; "it's all his fancy, you know. He can't help sighing like that, you know."

"I never said I knew," said Alice.

"He knows about it, all right," said the Gryphon; "it's all his fancy, that's what it is."

They went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with his large, lustrous eyes, but said nothing. The Gryphon whispered in Alice's ear, "This is the Mock Turtle," and added in an offended tone, "Don't be absurd! She can't mean *that*! You know what with the lob--"

"I mean the Mock Turtle," said Alice.

events.title: Mock Turtle's Sorrow and Introduction to the Lobster Quadrille
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle expresses deep sadness, unable to speak through sobs.
The Gryphon physically assists the Mock Turtle to help him regain his voice, comparing the choking sound to having a bone in the throat.
With tears, the Mock Turtle resumes speaking to Alice.
He suggests Alice lacks understanding of undersea life, having likely never lived there or been introduced to a lobster.
Alice confirms her lack of undersea experience and, after almost mentioning tasting lobster, denies ever being introduced to one.
The Mock Turtle concludes that Alice cannot comprehend the delight of a Lobster Quadrille.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “—so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!”

events.text_segment:
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice. “Same as if he had a bone in his throat,” said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:—
“You may not have lived much under the sea—” (“I haven’t,” said Alice)—“and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster—” (Alice began to say “I once tasted—” but checked herself hastily, and said “No, never”) “—so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. 'How comfortable I feel now!' he said; 'you must have often heard of my sorrow.' 'Yes,' said Alice, 'it's very well known— you're always at the trials.' 'I never attend them,' cried the Mock Turtle. 'Why, you do!' said Alice. 'You do indeed!' said the Gryphon. 'Why, you're part of the jury,' said Alice, 'and you've got a list of questions to ask. I've seen a list of questions for a jury-box.' 'Would it be worth while their carrying the list about, I wonder?' said the Gryphon. 'Only a little,' said Alice, 'for it's written on their faces.' The Mock Turtle looked at the Gryphon, and the Gryphon looked at the Mock Turtle, and each seemed to be saying to the other: 'I'm not going to speak first.' At last the Gryphon said, 'Chorus again?' 'Chorus again,' said the Mock Turtle. Then they both sat down and repeated the chorus of 'Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you, won't you, will you?' 'I think that's the most beautiful thing I've ever heard!' said Alice. 'Yes, it's a very pretty thing,' said the Gryphon. 'But where do you begin?' said Alice, rather timidly. 'Begin at the beginning,' the Mock Turtle said, very gravely, 'and go on till you come to the end: then stop.' 'That's what I always do,' said Alice. 'You do it quite wrong,' said the Mock Turtle. 'The way I tell it, I begin with the egg.' 'I'd like very much to hear that,' said Alice. 'I'll tell it to you some time,' said the Mock Turtle; 'but I'm not a bit light at present. I'm perfectly bent with sorrow.' 'I thought you said one of the jurors would have got it by this time,' said Alice. 'Which do you mean?' said the Gryphon. 'The effect of the Lobster Quadrille,' said Alice. 'I can't explain myself, I'm afraid, Sir, because I'm not myself, you see,' said the Mock Turtle in an injured tone. 'I never was!' said the Gryphon. 'Well, I'm not now,' said the Mock Turtle. 'Two of the verses I have supplied myself,' he added in a more cheerful tone. 'And the Lobster Quadrille is what we used to call—' 'Call it something easier,' the Gryphon interrupted. 'No, it's about the same in all quadrilles,' said the Mock Turtle, 'only they have different words. You see, the words of the song here are—' 'We can do without the song,' said the Gryphon. 'Let's have the dance instead.' 'But there is no dance,' said the Mock Turtle. 'There is in my life,' said the Gryphon. 'Only, one is to dance it one way in the morning and another way in the afternoon. But when the day is fine, she dances it one way; and when it is not fine, she dances it the other way. And when it is very fine, and she is very happy, she dances it a third way, round the house.' 'I wish I could see it,' said Alice. 'It is a very pretty dance,' said the Gryphon. 'Would you like to have a try?' he added, in a kind voice. 'I should like it very much,' said Alice. 'Only, I haven't got a tail.' 'You can manage without it,' said the Gryphon. 'I've seen a dance at the palace, where the players had no tails— and they did it very nicely.' 'But how can I learn to do it?' said Alice. 'What is the first thing to do?' 'The first thing is to stand on your head and sing,' said the Gryphon. 'I hope the song won't be long,' said Alice, 'for I'm getting very tired.' 'It's a very short song,' said the Gryphon. 'It's only about a hundred thousand years long.' 'Only!' said Alice, in a voice of surprise. 'Well, it's really only an hour long,' said the Gryphon. 'Only a minute,' said the Mock Turtle. 'Only a second,' said the Gryphon. 'Only just a moment,' said the Mock Turtle. 'Well, I'm glad to hear it,' said Alice. 'But what is the song about?' 'It's about the Lobster Quadrille,' said the Gryphon. 'I suppose you've heard of it?' 'Yes,' said Alice, 'I've heard something about it— but I don't know the tune. I've never been introduced to a lobster. No more, I suspect, have most people.' 'You can't have been introduced to a lobster,' said the Mock Turtle. 'Of course not,' said Alice. 'I've never been under water, and if I had, I should have been a little girl of eight.' 'You can't expect to have been introduced to a lobster in your present state,' said the Mock Turtle. 'Of course not,' said Alice. 'Well, then,' said the Gryphon

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. 'Where do *you* come from, child?' he asked. 'I don’t know,' said Alice. 'That’s a sad thing!' the Mock Turtle exclaimed in a tone of great sympathy. 'I know something *extremely* sad,' said Alice, feeling a little nervous. 'What is it?' asked the Gryphon, leaning closer. 'It’s about a race called the Bandersnatch,' said Alice, 'and something about a frumious Bandersnatch.' 'Ah!' said the Mock Turtle, 'I knew *one*—and he was frumious too!' 'He had eyes of flame,' added the Gryphon, nodding solemnly. 'And a long tail,' said the Mock Turtle, 'and a most terrible snarl!'

events.title: Chaotic Description of the Lobster Quadrille
detailed_summary: Alice confirms she has no idea what the dance is like and asks for a description.
The Gryphon begins explaining the formation along the seashore.
The Mock Turtle interjects, specifying two lines composed of seals, turtles, salmon, etc., and mentions clearing jellyfish first.
The Gryphon interrupts to note that clearing jellyfish takes time.
The Mock Turtle continues, stating they advance twice.
The Gryphon excitedly adds that each dancer partners with a lobster.
The Mock Turtle confirms this and restates the steps: advance twice, set to partners.
The Gryphon adds the next steps: change lobsters and retire in the same order.
The Mock Turtle proceeds to describe throwing something.
The Gryphon shouts that it's the lobsters being thrown.
The Mock Turtle specifies throwing them far out to sea.
The Gryphon screams the next step: swimming after the lobsters.
The Mock Turtle excitedly cries out the next action: turning a somersault in the sea.
The Gryphon yells the subsequent step: changing lobsters again.
The Mock Turtle suddenly calms down, stating that returning to land concludes the first figure.
Both the Mock Turtle and Gryphon, previously jumping wildly, sit down sadly and look at Alice.
Alice timidly comments that it must be a very pretty dance.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “No, indeed,” said Alice.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.

events.text_segment:
“No, indeed,” said Alice. “What sort of a dance is it?”
“Why,” said the Gryphon, “you first form into a line along the sea-shore—”
“Two lines!” cried the Mock Turtle. “Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you’ve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way—”
“That generally takes some time,” interrupted the Gryphon.
“—you advance twice—”
“Each with a lobster as a partner!” cried the Gryphon.
“Of course,” the Mock Turtle said: “advance twice, set to partners—”
“—change lobsters, and retire in same order,” continued the Gryphon.
“Then, you know,” the Mock Turtle went on, “you throw the—”
“The lobsters!” shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.
“—as far out to sea as you can—”
“Swim after them!” screamed the Gryphon.
“Turn a somersault in the sea!” cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly about.
“Change lobsters again!” yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.
“Back to land again, and that’s all the first figure,” said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.
“It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“No, indeed,” said Alice. “What sort of a way do they dance?”

“Will you, please, tell me the first thing to be done?” she asked.

“The first thing you have to do,” said the Gryphon, “is to stand on your head and sing.”

“*I* can’t stand on my head,” said Alice.

“And that’s certainly the right way,” said the Mock Turtle, “—or, at any rate, the way *I* use to do.”

“Not that I know of,” said Alice, rather doubtfully, as she went on, “but the *Lobster Quadrille*—”

“Ah! *The Lobster Quadrille!* That’s a very different thing!” cried the Gryphon.

“Don’t you see these turtles swimming with their arms?” said the Mock Turtle.

“Not at all,” said Alice.

“Then you must be a little crab,” said the Gryphon.

“Now hold your breath a moment!” said the Mock Turtle, suddenly; and he held up his tail and wriggled it from side to side.

“Do you like the Lobster Quadrille?” said the Gryphon, turning to Alice.

“I don’t know how to do it,” said Alice.

“Still, the dance is very pretty,” said the Mock Turtle, tossing his head impatiently.

“Would you like to see it?” said the Gryphon, in a coaxing tone.

“Very much indeed,” said Alice, “if I could only get through the door.”

“Which is not the case with you,” said the Mock Turtle, sighing.

“Exactly so,” said the Gryphon.

“Then I can’t go through it,” said Alice.

“Of course not,” said the Gryphon, “but perhaps I can show you the steps.”

“Do you know it all?” said Alice.

“Of course I do,” said the Gryphon. “I’ve been at the party for a week.”

“Then, when you get to the middle of the floor,” said the Mock Turtle, “you have to do this.” And he suddenly began to dance wildly about, making strange noises like a cat coughing.

“Now, that’s the *Lobster Quadrille*,” said the Gryphon, “and it’s a very pretty dance indeed.”

“Let me try and learn it,” said Alice, “but tell me the steps first.”

“First, you form two lines,” said the Gryphon, “one of seals, the other of turtles and salmon.”

“And you clear the jellyfish out of the way first,” said the Mock Turtle.

“Which takes a long time,” said the Gryphon.

“Then you advance twice,” said the Mock Turtle.

“And you change your lobster,” said the Gryphon, “and you retire in the same order.”

“Then you throw the lobster,” said the Mock Turtle.

“Out to sea!” screamed the Gryphon.

“Then you swim after it,” said the Mock Turtle, “and you do a somersault in the sea.”

“Then you change your lobster again,” said the Gryphon.

“And you come back to land,” said the Mock Turtle, suddenly calm, “and that’s the first figure.”

And both the Gryphon and the Mock Turtle, who had been jumping wildly about, sat down suddenly and looked at Alice with great solemnity.

“It must be a very pretty dance,” said Alice timidly.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“No, indeed,” said Alice. “I’ve often seen a cat without a grin, but a grin without a cat! It’s the most curious thing I ever saw in all my life!”

She stared at the empty grin, which was still floating in the air, and it slowly began to fade. Alice blinked several times, trying to make sense of what she had just witnessed. “I must be dreaming,” she muttered to herself. “This is too strange for real life.”

Just then, a voice called out from behind her. “Curiouser and curiouser!” it said. Alice turned around to find a small, round creature with bright eyes and a long tail. It was a mouse, and it was holding a tiny teacup in its paws.

“Who are you?” Alice asked, trying to sound brave.

“I am the March Hare,” the mouse replied. “And you, madam, are in the middle of a very peculiar tea party.”

Before Alice could respond, the March Hare hopped off, leaving her even more confused than before. She looked around, wondering what other strange things she might encounter in this mad and wonderful world.

events.title: Demonstration of the Quadrille and the Whiting's Song
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle asks Alice if she'd like to see a bit of the dance.
Alice enthusiastically agrees.
The Mock Turtle suggests to the Gryphon they try the first figure, noting they can omit the lobsters, and asks who will sing.
The Gryphon designates the Mock Turtle to sing, admitting he has forgotten the words.
They commence a solemn dance around Alice, sometimes treading on her toes and using their forepaws to keep time.
The Mock Turtle sings a slow, sad song.
The song narrates a whiting urging a snail to hurry and join a dance because a porpoise is close behind.
The dance involves lobsters and turtles waiting on the shingle (beach).
The chorus repeatedly asks the snail to join the dance.
The whiting describes the delight of being taken up and thrown into the sea with the lobsters.
The snail refuses, saying it's too far and giving a wary look.
The snail reiterates its refusal to join.
The whiting argues that distance doesn't matter as there's another shore on the other side.
It reasons that being further from England means being closer to France.
The whiting encourages the snail not to be pale and to join the dance, repeating the chorus.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Would you like to see a little of it?” said the Mock Turtle.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”

events.text_segment:
“Would you like to see a little of it?” said the Mock Turtle.
“Very much indeed,” said Alice.
“Come, let’s try the first figure!” said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon. “We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?”
“Oh, you sing,” said the Gryphon. “I’ve forgotten the words.”
So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:—
“Will you walk a little faster?” said a whiting to a snail.
“There’s a porpoise close behind us, and he’s treading on my tail.
See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
They are waiting on the shingle—will you come and join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?

“You can really have no notion how delightful it will be
When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!”
But the snail replied “Too far, too far!” and gave a look askance—
Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance.
Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance.
Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.

“What matters it how far we go?” his scaly friend replied.
“There is another shore, you know, upon the other side.
The further off from England the nearer is to France—
Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance.
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”
