events.title: Discussion about Whitings, Wordplay, and Alice's Adventures
detailed_summary: Alice expresses relief that the dance is over, calling it interesting and saying she likes the song about the whiting.
The Mock Turtle asks Alice if she has seen whitings before.
Alice confirms, almost mentioning seeing them served at dinner ('dinn—'), but stops herself.
The Mock Turtle misunderstands 'Dinn' as a place but assumes Alice knows what whitings look like.
Alice thoughtfully replies that she thinks they have tails in their mouths and are covered in crumbs.
The Mock Turtle corrects her about the crumbs, stating they'd wash off in the sea, but confirms the tails-in-mouths detail.
Becoming sleepy, the Mock Turtle asks the Gryphon to explain the reason for the tails.
The Gryphon explains the whitings insisted on joining the lobsters' dance, got thrown out to sea, fell a long way, got their tails stuck fast in their mouths, and couldn't get them out.
Alice finds this interesting, noting she never knew so much about whitings.
The Gryphon offers more information, asking if Alice knows why it's called a 'whiting'.
Alice admits she never thought about it and asks why.
The Gryphon solemnly explains 'It does the boots and shoes,' a pun on shoe polish (whiting).
Alice is thoroughly confused by this statement.
The Gryphon asks what her shoes are shined with.
Alice examines her shoes and suggests they are shined with 'blacking'.
The Gryphon explains that undersea boots and shoes are 'done with a whiting'.
Alice curiously asks what undersea shoes are made of.
The Gryphon impatiently replies they are made of 'soles and eels', another pun.
Alice, still thinking of the song, says if she were the whiting, she'd tell the porpoise to stay away.
The Mock Turtle insists the porpoise was necessary, stating no wise fish travels without one.
Alice expresses surprise.
The Mock Turtle confirms, making a pun by saying if a fish mentioned a journey, he'd ask 'With what porpoise?'
Alice asks if he means 'purpose'.
The Mock Turtle replies, offended, that he means exactly what he said.
The Gryphon interjects, asking to hear Alice's adventures.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the Gryphon added “Come, let’s hear some of your adventures.”

events.text_segment:
“Thank you, it’s a very interesting dance to watch,” said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: “and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!”
“Oh, as to the whiting,” said the Mock Turtle, “they—you’ve seen them, of course?”
“Yes,” said Alice, “I’ve often seen them at dinn—” she checked herself hastily.
“I don’t know where Dinn may be,” said the Mock Turtle, “but if you’ve seen them so often, of course you know what they’re like.”
“I believe so,” Alice replied thoughtfully. “They have their tails in their mouths—and they’re all over crumbs.”
“You’re wrong about the crumbs,” said the Mock Turtle: “crumbs would all wash off in the sea. But they have their tails in their mouths; and the reason is—” here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.—“Tell her about the reason and all that,” he said to the Gryphon.
“The reason is,” said the Gryphon, “that they would go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn’t get them out again. That’s all.”
“Thank you,” said Alice, “it’s very interesting. I never knew so much about a whiting before.”
“I can tell you more than that, if you like,” said the Gryphon. “Do you know why it’s called a whiting?”
“I never thought about it,” said Alice. “Why?”
“It does the boots and shoes,” the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
Alice was thoroughly puzzled. “Does the boots and shoes!” she repeated in a wondering tone.
“Why, what are your shoes done with?” said the Gryphon. “I mean, what makes them so shiny?”
Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer. “They’re done with blacking, I believe.”
“Boots and shoes under the sea,” the Gryphon went on in a deep voice, “are done with a whiting. Now you know.”
“And what are they made of?” Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
“Soles and eels, of course,” the Gryphon replied rather impatiently: “any shrimp could have told you that.”
“If I’d been the whiting,” said Alice, whose thoughts were still running on the song, “I’d have said to the porpoise, ‘Keep back, please: we don’t want you with us!’”
“They were obliged to have him with them,” the Mock Turtle said: “no wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.”
“Wouldn’t it really?” said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
“Of course not,” said the Mock Turtle: “why, if a fish came to me, and told me he was going a journey, I should say ‘With what porpoise?’”
“Don’t you mean ‘purpose’?” said Alice.
“I mean what I say,” the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And the Gryphon added “Come, let’s hear some of your adventures.”

> “Thank you, it’s a very interesting dance to watch,” said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: “and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!”  
>  
> “Have you seen whitings before?” asked the Mock Turtle, his voice a mix of curiosity and melancholy, as if the very mention of the creature stirred a deep, unspoken sorrow.  
>  
> “Yes,” said Alice, pausing for a moment as if to recall. “I believe I have—dinn—” She caught herself, her cheeks flushing slightly.  
>  
> “Dinn!” echoed the Mock Turtle, his eyes widening. “Is that a place? I’ve never heard of it. But I suppose you know what whitings look like?”  
>  
> “Well,” said Alice, tapping her chin thoughtfully, “I think they have their tails in their mouths and are covered in crumbs.”  
>  
> “Ah, the crumbs,” said the Mock Turtle, shaking his head. “They’d wash off in the sea, of course. But yes, the tails in the mouths—that is quite right.” He yawned, his long, melancholic eyelids drooping. “But I’m afraid I’m too sleepy to explain further. Gryphon, would you?”  
>  
> The Gryphon, who had been sitting cross-legged and watching the exchange with a bemused expression, leaned forward. “Well, you see,” he began, “the whitings insisted on joining the lobsters’ dance. They were quite insistent, in fact. But the lobsters, being very particular about their quadrille, threw them out to sea. They fell a long way, and their tails got stuck fast in their mouths. And there they remain.”  
>  
> “How interesting,” said Alice, her eyes wide with wonder. “I never knew so much about whitings.”  
>  
> “Ah,” said the Gryphon, “but there is more. Do you know why it’s called a *whiting*?”  
>  
> “No,” said Alice, shaking her head. “I never thought about it.”  
>  
> “It does the boots and shoes,” said the Gryphon solemnly.  
>  
> Alice blinked. “I beg your pardon?”  
>  
> “It does the boots and shoes,” he repeated, as if it were the most obvious thing in the world.  
>  
> “What are your shoes shined with?” he asked.  
>  
> Alice looked down at her feet. “I suppose they’re shined with blacking,” she said.  
>  
> “Ah, but undersea boots and shoes,” said the Gryphon, “are done with a whiting.”  
>  
> “And what,” asked Alice, her curiosity piqued, “are undersea shoes made of?”  
>  
> The Gryphon sighed, as if he had been asked this question a thousand times before. “Soles and eels,” he said impatiently.  
>  
> Alice, still thinking of the song, said thoughtfully, “If I were the whiting, I’d tell the porpoise to stay away.”  
>  
> “Ah, but the porpoise is necessary,” said the Mock Turtle, his voice suddenly firm. “No wise fish would travel without one.”  
>  
> “Indeed?” said Alice, surprised.  
>  
> “Indeed,” said the Mock Turtle, his eyes gleaming. “If a fish were to mention a journey, I’d ask, *With what porpoise?*”  
>  
> “Do you mean *purpose*?” asked Alice.  
>  
> The Mock Turtle looked offended. “Of course I mean *porpoise*,” he said.  
>  
> “Well, then,” said Alice, “I suppose I’d better ask you about your adventures next.”  
>  
> The Gryphon perked up at this. “Oh, do tell us about your adventures!” he said eagerly. “We’ve been waiting to hear them all along.”  

---

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Thank you, it’s a very interesting dance to watch,” said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: “and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!”

The Queen of Hearts, who had been sitting on a throne of playing cards, clapped her hands and said, “Off with their heads!” But before anyone could react, the Cheshire Cat appeared, floating in mid-air with his usual grin. “You know, I think it’s time for a change of scenery,” he said, his voice echoing slightly. “Perhaps a nice walk through the garden?”

Alice looked around, and to her surprise, the garden was now filled with flowers that were talking to each other. “I always thought roses were the most beautiful,” said a daisy. “But I suppose that’s just my opinion.”

“Indeed,” replied a tulip, “beauty is in the eye of the beholder, or in this case, the beholder of the eye.”

Alice giggled, finding the conversation between the flowers both amusing and confusing. Just then, a small creature with a long tail and a crown of thorns approached her. “Hello, Alice,” it said. “I am the King of the Thorns. I have a riddle for you.”

“Very well,” said Alice, “I love riddles.”

“What is it that you can see, but never touch, and yet it can touch you?” asked the King of the Thorns.

Alice thought for a moment. “Is it a shadow?” she asked.

“Correct!” said the King, bowing low. “You are quite clever, Alice.”

As they continued their walk, Alice noticed that the garden was changing. The flowers were now dancing in a circle, and the trees were swaying to an invisible tune. “This is the most magical garden I have ever seen,” said Alice, her eyes wide with wonder.

Suddenly, a loud crash echoed through the garden, and a giant rabbit with a pocket watch in his paw appeared. “Oh dear, oh dear, I’m late!” he cried, hopping around in a panic. “I must be at the tea party in five minutes!”

“Wait, the tea party?” asked Alice, her heart racing with excitement. “Is it the Mad Hatter’s tea party?”

“Yes, yes, that’s the one!” said the rabbit, nodding his head. “Come along, come along, we don’t have much time!”

With that, the rabbit led Alice through a maze of hedges and over a small brook, until they arrived at a long table set with an endless array of tea things. The Mad Hatter, the March Hare, and the Dormouse were already there, engaged in a heated debate about the meaning of time.

“Ah, Alice!” said the Mad Hatter, pouring her a cup of tea. “You’re just in time for the next riddle!”

Alice smiled, ready for whatever madness awaited her next. She had no idea what the riddle would be, but she was certain it would be as strange and wonderful as everything else in Wonderland.

events.title: Alice Recounts Adventures and Recites a Poem Incorrectly
detailed_summary: Alice timidly offers to share her adventures starting from that morning, explaining that recounting yesterday is pointless as she was a different person.
The Mock Turtle asks for an explanation of that.
The Gryphon impatiently interrupts, demanding the adventures first because explanations take too long.
Alice begins recounting her adventures from seeing the White Rabbit.
She is initially nervous due to the creatures' proximity and intense staring but gains confidence.
Her listeners remain quiet until she describes reciting 'You are old, Father William' incorrectly for the Caterpillar.
The Mock Turtle remarks that this is very curious.
The Gryphon agrees, stating it's as curious as can be.
The Mock Turtle thoughtfully repeats that the words came out differently and expresses a wish to hear Alice try reciting something now, asking the Gryphon to tell her to begin.
The Gryphon, seemingly having authority, instructs Alice to stand and recite ''Tis the voice of the sluggard.'
Alice privately reflects on how the creatures order her around like school lessons.
She stands up to recite, but her mind is preoccupied with the Lobster Quadrille.
The words come out strangely, beginning ''Tis the voice of the Lobster' who complains of being over-baked and needing to sugar his hair.
The recited poem continues nonsensically about the Lobster trimming his belt and buttons with his nose like a duck with its eyelids.

events.text_segment:
“I could tell you my adventures—beginning from this morning,” said Alice a little timidly: “but it’s no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then.”
“Explain all that,” said the Mock Turtle.
“No, no! The adventures first,” said the Gryphon in an impatient tone: “explanations take such a dreadful time.”
So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so very wide, but she gained courage as she went on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating “You are old, Father William,” to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said “That’s very curious.”
“It’s all about as curious as it can be,” said the Gryphon.
“It all came different!” the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully. “I should like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to begin.” He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.
“Stand up and repeat ‘’Tis the voice of the sluggard,’” said the Gryphon.
“How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!” thought Alice; “I might as well be at school at once.” However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:—
“’Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
“You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.”
As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"I could tell you my adventures—beginning from this morning," said Alice a little timidly: "but it’s no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then."

"You don’t say so!" exclaimed the Mock Turtle, chequered countenance suddenly brightening. "Why, I was afraid you might have forgotten them!"

"I can’t remember them," Alice replied very politely, "and that’s the queer thing."

The Gryphon interrupted suddenly: "You can’t remember things, you know. The best way is to tell them."

"I’ll try," said Alice, and she crossed her legs for comfort, and began. "I began with—where was I?—oh, I began with the White Rabbit. He was running so fast that I had to run after him, and I was so frightened I could hardly breathe—"

"Why did you run after him?" asked the Gryphon.

"Because he called out, 'Oh my ears and whiskers, how late I’m getting!' and he looked so anxious, you know," said Alice, getting more and more interested as she went on.

"That’s curious," said the Mock Turtle, deep in thought. "I wonder what he was in such a hurry for?"

"I don’t know," said Alice, "but I ran after him, and I ran and ran until I came to a house in a wood, and the house was all made of glass."

"That’s curious, too," said the Gryphon. "But it’s as curious as can be, I should think."

"It was, indeed," said Alice. "And when I got there, I found a Caterpillar sitting on a mushroom, and he was smoking a hookah, and he asked me questions, and I answered them, and I said—"

"What did you say?" asked the Mock Turtle.

"I said, 'You are old, Father William,' and I recited the whole poem, but I got it all wrong."

"That’s very curious," said the Mock Turtle, with a sigh.

"It is, indeed," said the Gryphon. "As curious as can be."

"I thought so too," said Alice. "And the Caterpillar said, 'Well! Well! Well! I’ve often seen a cat without a grin, but a grin without a cat! It’s the most curious thing I ever saw in all my life!'

"I wish you would recite something now," said the Mock Turtle, turning to the Gryphon. "Tell her to begin."

The Gryphon repeated, "You are to begin again, I wish you would begin again."

Alice looked at them both, and said, "But I don’t know any poetry to recite."

"Then recite 'Tis the voice of the sluggard,'" said the Gryphon.

"How dreary to be a slave to custom!" said Alice. "But let me try."

She got up, and began to recite, but her mind was full of the Lobster Quadrille, and the words came out all wrong. She began:—

"'Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
'You have baked me too long, I wish I were bare!'

And then the words went on in a very curious way:—

'For if you'll cook me, I'll never come down,
I'll sugar my hair, and I'll sugar my nose;
And I'll sugar my nose, and I'll sugar my nose,
And I'll sugar my nose until I'm a nose!'

'Oh, do go on!' cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle cried, 'I like that best of all!'

'And then the Lobster said—' continued Alice, but she could not remember the rest of the poem, and she sat down in confusion.

“I could tell you my adventures—beginning from this morning,” said Alice a little timidly: “but it’s no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then.”

“Explain, if you can,” said the Caterpillar.

This was such a new way of talking that Alice liked it very much. “Please, then,” she said, “why may not I speak?”

“Hold your tongue,” said the Caterpillar.

“I’ve plenty to say,” said Alice.

“Then say it quickly,” said the Caterpillar.

That’s all I wanted,” said Alice, “but I’m not a bit inclined to be silent when I have anything to say to—”

“To whom?” said the Caterpillar.

“Well, to you,” said Alice, rather shyly.

“To me!” cried the Caterpillar, stretching itself suddenly to its full size, so that it was nearly three feet long.

“And who are you?” said Alice, rather offended, for she didn’t like being ordered about so much.

“I’m the Caterpillar,” said the Caterpillar.

“Well, I’ve heard of Caterpillars,” said Alice, “but I didn’t know you were one; I thought you were a serpent; a boa-constrictor, or something of that kind.”

“Ah! you don’t sound like a serpent,” said the Caterpillar, lifting up its head angrily.

“I’m not,” said Alice, “and I don’t think you are either. For first, you’d be too large for a serpent, and secondly, you’d have a lot of legs.”

The Caterpillar seemed to think this a very good reply if Alice would have let it speak. It drew itself up like a Chinese pointer in a shop window, and addressed her in a very solemn tone.

“Who are you?”

“Who am I?” said Alice, puzzled. “I—oh, I’m a little lost, I think.”

“Do you know,” said the Caterpillar, after some time, “that I’ve seen a rabbit wear spectacles?”

“Then you’ve seen a strange rabbit,” said Alice. “And what was the colour of the spectacles?”

“Lenses,” said the Caterpillar, “lenses and all. One eye was too large, and the other too small.”

“And the colour?”

“Blue.”

“Blue eyes are the best, in my opinion,” said Alice.

“And so are green,” said the Caterpillar. “But the best of all are those that are both blue and green.”

Alice was very much surprised at this, but she did not like to contradict it. “Have you always been a caterpillar?” she asked, as politely as she could.

“Not always,” said the Caterpillar.

“Where did you come from?”

“Out of a caterpillar.”

“Where did the caterpillar come from?”

“Out of an egg.”

“What kind of egg?”

“Turk’s egg,” said the Caterpillar.

“Not a Turk’s egg!” said Alice in a tone of great surprise.

“I don’t like Turk’s eggs,” said the Caterpillar.

events.title: Reactions to Recitation and Further Incorrect Poem
detailed_summary: The Gryphon observes that Alice's recitation differs from the version he knew as a child.
The Mock Turtle, having never heard it before, declares it sounds like 'uncommon nonsense'.
Alice remains silent, sitting down and covering her face, wondering if reality will ever return.
The Mock Turtle expresses a desire for an explanation.
The Gryphon hastily states that Alice cannot explain it and urges her to continue with the next verse.
The Mock Turtle persists, questioning how the lobster in the poem could turn its toes out using its nose.
Alice suggests it's the 'first position in dancing' but feels confused and wishes to change the topic.
The Gryphon impatiently repeats the instruction to proceed with the next verse, prompting her with the first line 'I passed by his garden.'
Feeling she cannot disobey but certain it will also come out wrong, Alice continues in a trembling voice.
She recites another altered verse about passing a garden and seeing an Owl and a Panther sharing a pie.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”

events.text_segment:
That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon.
“Well, I never heard it before,” said the Mock Turtle; “but it sounds uncommon nonsense.”
Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would ever happen in a natural way again.
“I should like to have it explained,” said the Mock Turtle.
“She can’t explain it,” said the Gryphon hastily. “Go on with the next verse.”
“But about his toes?” the Mock Turtle persisted. “How could he turn them out with his nose, you know?”
“It’s the first position in dancing.” Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
“Go on with the next verse,” the Gryphon repeated impatiently: “it begins ‘I passed by his garden.’”
Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:—
“I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,” said the Gryphon. “When I was a child, I always said, 'I am the best at everything!' But now I say, 'I am the best at being me!'”

Alice giggled. “That sounds much nicer,” she said.

The Gryphon nodded. “Yes, it is. You see, when you grow up, you learn that being the best at everything is impossible. But being the best at being yourself is the most important thing of all.”

Alice thought about this for a moment. “I think I understand,” she said. “It’s not about being better than others, but about being true to yourself.”

The Gryphon smiled. “Exactly! And that is a very wise thing to say for someone your size.”

Alice blushed. “Thank you,” she said. “I think I’m learning a lot from you.”

The Gryphon chuckled. “Well, then, let’s keep going. There’s more to see and learn in Wonderland!”

events.title: Mock Turtle Sings 'Turtle Soup' Before Abrupt Departure
detailed_summary: The Mock Turtle interrupts Alice's recitation again, questioning the point of repeating confusing material without explaining it.
He declares it the most confusing thing he has ever heard.
The Gryphon suggests Alice should stop reciting, and Alice is relieved to comply.
The Gryphon proposes either trying another figure of the Lobster Quadrille or having the Mock Turtle sing a song.
Alice eagerly requests a song, if the Mock Turtle is willing.
Her eagerness slightly offends the Gryphon, who comments on tastes and asks the Mock Turtle to sing 'Turtle Soup'.
The Mock Turtle sighs deeply and begins singing, his voice occasionally choked with sobs.
The song praises 'Beautiful Soup', describing it as rich, green, and waiting in a hot tureen.
It questions who wouldn't desire such dainties and celebrates 'Soup of the evening'.
The song continues, asking who cares for other dishes like fish or game when compared to Beautiful Soup.
It suggests giving up everything else for just a small amount of the soup.
The song repeats phrases and sounds emphasizing 'Beautiful Soup'.
The Gryphon calls for the chorus to be sung again.
Just as the Mock Turtle begins repeating the chorus, a distant cry announces 'The trial's beginning!'
The Gryphon exclaims 'Come on!', takes Alice by the hand, and rushes away without waiting for the song to finish.
As they run, Alice breathlessly asks what trial it is.
The Gryphon only replies 'Come on!' and runs faster.
The sad words of the Mock Turtle's song fade away on the breeze behind them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

events.text_segment:
“What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on? It’s by far the most confusing thing I ever heard!”
“Yes, I think you’d better leave off,” said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.
“Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?” the Gryphon went on. “Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?”
“Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,” Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone, “Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her ‘Turtle Soup,’ will you, old fellow?”
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:—
“Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Waiting in a hot tureen!
Who for such dainties would not stoop?
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
“Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish,
Game, or any other dish?
Who would not give all else for two p
ennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
    Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
    Beautiful, beauti—FUL SOUP!”
“Chorus again!” cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of “The trial’s beginning!” was heard in the distance.
“Come on!” cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
“What trial is it?” Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered “Come on!” and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:—
“Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
Beautiful, beautiful Soup!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: "What is the use of repeating all that stuff," the Mock Turtle interrupted, "if you don't explain it as you go on?" "Exactly," said the Gryphon. "You'd better not try to explain, but be done with it," and he went on with the dance in another part of the figure. Now Alice had got so much into the way of this, that a minute or two passed before she noticed they had left off repeating the first part of the dance, and were now doing the second. Suddenly the Mock Turtle cried out, "The time has come," and they both hurried away. Alice ran after them, but she was terribly confused by the sudden change, and before she could get out of the way, the Gryphon had seized her by the hand and was dragging her off, exclaiming, "Come on, come on!" "Where to?" cried Alice. "Where it will be safest," said the Gryphon, and they ran on for a time in silence. At last the Gryphon let out a long, low howl, and Alice knew it meant that they had reached their destination. "Now!" he said. "Now!" cried the Mock Turtle, and they both sat down suddenly on the ground. Alice looked round her in great perplexity, trying to make out where she was, and whether this was not the beginning of another of those uncomfortable ceremonies she had gone through before. But the Gryphon only said, "Come on!" and they all set off again, running as fast as they could. "What trial is it?" panted Alice. "Come on!" repeated the Gryphon, and ran faster than ever. The Mock Turtle, who had been sobbing all the time, now began to sing in a very melancholy tone— 'Beautiful Soup! Who loves it not? How can it be so very good? How very very choicely good! LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“What is the use of repeating all that stuff,” the Mock Turtle interrupted, “if you don’t explain it as you go on?”

The Mock Turtle’s question hung in the air like a riddle, and Alice, who had been listening with growing confusion, felt a flicker of hope. Perhaps someone else shared her bewilderment. She turned to the Gryphon, who was perched nearby, and asked, “Would you mind explaining it to me, please?”

The Gryphon gave a long sigh and began, “Well, it’s all very confusing, I grant you. But it’s the way things are in this place. You see, we have lessons here, just like in schools, only they’re called ‘Recess’ and ‘Playtime.’ The first lesson is called ‘Reciting,’ and it’s when we repeat things over and over without understanding them. The second is ‘Cracking,’ which is when we try to solve riddles that don’t make sense. And the third is ‘Singing,’ which is when we sing songs that have no tune.”

Alice blinked. “But why do you do it if it doesn’t make sense?”

The Mock Turtle sniffled and wiped his eyes with a handkerchief embroidered with the words “I’m a Mock Turtle.” “Oh, it’s all very sad,” he said. “We used to have proper lessons, but the Lizard Board of Education decided that everything should be nonsense. They said it would make us more creative.”

Alice couldn’t help but laugh. “That doesn’t sound very helpful.”

The Gryphon nodded. “No, it doesn’t. But it’s the way things are in Wonderland. The more nonsense, the more fun.”

Alice thought about this for a moment. “I suppose it’s different from where I come from,” she said. “But I do like riddles and puzzles, even if they’re confusing.”

The Mock Turtle brightened. “Oh, then you’ll love our next lesson. It’s called ‘Snark Hunting.’”

Alice’s eyes widened. “What’s a Snark?”

The Gryphon and the Mock Turtle exchanged a glance, and with a chorus of “Beware the Jabberwock, my son!” they began to sing a strange and wonderful song about creatures that bite, and things that bite back, and the joy of chasing what you can’t catch.

chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XI. Who Stole the Tarts?

events.title: Arrival at the Trial and Initial Observations
detailed_summary: Alice enters the scene to find the King and Queen of Hearts presiding over a trial from their throne.
A diverse crowd of small animals, birds, and the entire deck of cards surrounds them.
The Knave of Hearts stands accused, bound in chains and guarded by soldiers.
The White Rabbit is present in the role of a court herald, equipped with a trumpet and a parchment scroll.
A table displaying a large dish of tarts captures Alice's attention, making her hungry and wish for the trial to conclude quickly so refreshments could be served.
Recognizing the improbability of immediate refreshments, Alice decides to observe the proceedings to occupy her time.
Although new to a real court of justice, Alice's reading allows her to identify various elements.
She correctly identifies the King as the judge, noting his large wig worn awkwardly beneath his crown.
Alice also identifies the jury-box and its twelve occupants, a mix of animals and birds, whom she proudly labels "jurors," reflecting on the advanced vocabulary for her age.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.

events.text_segment:
The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them—“I wish they’d get the trial done,” she thought, “and hand round the refreshments!” But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there. “That’s the judge,” she said to herself, “because of his great wig.”
The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
“And that’s the jury-box,” thought Alice, “and those twelve creatures,” (she was obliged to say “creatures,” you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) “I suppose they are the jurors.” She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all. However, “jury-men” would have done just as well.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. Alice had just time to see that the Queen was making a short speech, before the Rabbit blew a loud trumpet, and cried out, 'Silence!' and the whole assembly sat down in great confusion. The trial was for the theft of the Queen’s tarts, and the accused was the Knave of Hearts. The Queen’s voice was quite shrill and excited as she addressed the jury, who were a mixture of animals and birds, all looking very solemn in their jury-box. Alice, though she had never been in a real court of justice before, had read about them in books, and she was quite proud of herself for knowing the names of all the parts of the court. She noticed the King, who was the judge, and his large wig, which looked as if it had been put on in a great hurry. She also noticed the twelve jurors, and she thought to herself, 'How clever I am to know that they are called jurors!' But she was more interested in the large dish of tarts that was placed on a table near the Queen, and she wished very much that the trial would end so that she could have one. However, she knew that this was not likely, so she decided to watch the proceedings and see what would happen next.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. Alice could hardly see what was going on, as the crowd was so dense, but she noticed that the Queen was looking extremely angry, and the King had a very nervous expression on his face. The White Rabbit was shouting, 'Order, order!' and blowing the trumpet at intervals, while the soldiers kept shifting from foot to foot, looking very uncomfortable. The Queen turned to the King and said, 'Sentence first—verdict afterwards,' in a sharp, imperious tone. The King looked startled and stammered, 'But, O Queen, the rules of court are clear—first the trial, then the sentence.' 'Stuff and nonsense!' the Queen snapped. 'Off with his head!' she cried, and the crowd immediately echoed, 'Off with his head!' Alice, who had been trying to make her way closer, suddenly found herself swept along by the excited crowd. She looked up at the King and Queen, who were now arguing loudly, and thought to herself, 'This is the most absurd trial I have ever seen!' Just then, the Cheshire Cat appeared, grinning from ear to ear, and said, 'You're having a very strange time, aren't you?' Alice turned to look at him, and the Cat vanished, leaving only his grin behind, which slowly faded into the air.

events.title: The Jury's Premature Actions
detailed_summary: Alice observes the twelve jurors busily writing on slates.
She curiously whispers to the Gryphon, asking what they could possibly be writing before the trial has even started.
The Gryphon explains in a whisper that the jurors are writing down their own names, fearing they might forget them before the trial concludes.
Alice begins to voice her indignation loudly, calling them "Stupid things!", but quickly falls silent as the White Rabbit demands order in the court.
Simultaneously, the King puts on his spectacles and scans the room, trying to identify the source of the interruption.
Alice can clearly see the jurors' slates, confirming they are indeed writing "stupid things!".
She notices one juror struggling to spell "stupid" and needing assistance from a neighbor.
Alice inwardly remarks on the chaotic state the jurors' notes will likely be in by the end of the trial.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.

events.text_segment:
The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. “What are they doing?” Alice whispered to the Gryphon. “They can’t have anything to put down yet, before the trial’s begun.”
“They’re putting down their names,” the Gryphon whispered in reply, “for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.”
“Stupid things!” Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, “Silence in the court!” and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.
Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down “stupid things!” on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn’t know how to spell “stupid,” and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him. “A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!” thought Alice.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates. "What are they doing?" Alice whispered to the Gryphon: "and why have they got slates?" "They're writing down all the evidence," said the Gryphon, in a very decided tone, "for fear they should forget it before the trial's over." "I shouldn't know what to put down," Alice said, "if I were in their places." "They're all stupid things!" she added in a loud, indignant voice, which she immediately regretted, for the White Rabbit cried out, "Silence in court!" and the King, with a very solemn air, put on his spectacles and looked about the room. Alice could see, as well as if she were looking at the original, that all the jurors had written "stupid things!" on their slates, and one of them was trying to spell it out to his neighbor, who seemed to have forgotten how. "I wonder," thought Alice, "if they'll ever get through the trial at this rate?"

events.title: Alice's Intervention and the Formal Accusation
detailed_summary: One juror possesses a pencil that emits a disruptive squeaking sound.
Finding the noise intolerable, Alice moves around the court until she is behind the juror.
She deftly seizes an opportunity to snatch the pencil away unnoticed.
The juror, identified as Bill the Lizard, is completely baffled by the pencil's sudden disappearance.
After a futile search, Bill resorts to writing with his finger for the remainder of the day, which proves ineffective as it leaves no marks on the slate.
The King then instructs the Herald (White Rabbit) to formally read the charges.
Following the King's command, the White Rabbit produces three blasts from his trumpet.
He then unrolls the parchment scroll and recites the accusation: a nursery rhyme detailing how the Knave of Hearts allegedly stole the Queen's tarts.
Immediately upon hearing the charges, the King instructs the jury to deliberate and reach their verdict.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.

events.text_segment:
One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
“Herald, read the accusation!” said the King.
On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:—
“The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
    All on a summer day:
The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
    And took them quite away!”
“Consider your verdict,” the King said to the jury.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course offended the King, who never allowed any noise in his court, and he looked up in a very angry way at the Lizard in the crown; but Bill the Lizard only smiled and made a little mouth at him, and didn't even try to hide his pencil. Alice thought this must be a very rude way of behaving, and she was quite pleased to see the King so angry about it. She moved on further, and came behind the Lizard, and soon found out that he had a great deal of difficulty in keeping the pencil quite still, and that he was squeaking most of the time. She waited until he had a little pause, and then suddenly snatched the pencil out of his hand. Bill the Lizard looked quite astonished, and for a moment or two could not make out where he had put it, and then he suddenly saw it was gone, and he was so frightened that he let out a loud cry, and fell over backwards off his seat. The King looked at him in great disgust, and said he was to be removed, and the Queen of Hearts, who was sitting on the other side of the court, said she would have nothing more to do with him. So Bill the Lizard was taken away, and the King said he would not allow any more noise in the court. Then the White Rabbit, who was the Herald, came forward and blew three blasts on his trumpet, and then unrolled a scroll of parchment and read out the charges. 'Four times five is twelve,' he said, 'and four times six is thirteen, and four times seven is--oh dear! I shall never get to twenty at that rate!' The King looked very grave, and said, 'Order, order!' and the Queen of Hearts said, 'Sentence first--verdict afterwards--' and the whole court echoed, 'Sentence first--verdict afterwards!'

Poor Alice felt quite frightened at this; she had never been in a court of justice before, and she didn't know which way to look, or what to do. All the other jurors used to have pencils and pads, but this one's pencil made a most horrid noise, like a squeaky door. The King, who was sitting on the throne, looked very angry and said, 'Order, order!' But the squeaking went on and on, and Alice thought to herself, 'I wish the Queen of Hearts was here; she'd put an end to it in a moment.' The Queen was not there, but the King was, and he looked very cross. 'Silence!' he shouted, but the squeaking continued. Alice, being very polite, tried to whisper to the juror, 'Please stop that pencil, it's very loud.' But the juror didn't hear her, or if he did, he chose to ignore her. Poor Alice was very confused and quite upset. She didn't know what to do next, and she wished very much to be at home again.

events.title: The Hatter's Arrival and Confusing Testimony
detailed_summary: The White Rabbit quickly intervenes, telling the King it's too early for a verdict as much evidence is yet to be presented.
The King concedes and requests the first witness.
The White Rabbit blows his trumpet again and summons the "First witness!"
The Hatter enters, still holding his teacup and a piece of bread-and-butter.
He apologizes to the King for bringing his tea things, explaining he was summoned before finishing.
The King retorts that he should have finished and inquires when he started his tea.
The Hatter looks towards the March Hare, who has entered with the Dormouse, and guesses the date was March 14th.
The March Hare corrects him, stating it was the 15th; the Dormouse adds it was the 16th.
The King instructs the jury to write down all three dates, which they do eagerly, before attempting to convert the dates into monetary values.
The King then orders the Hatter to remove his hat.
The Hatter replies that the hat is not his.
The King immediately concludes the hat must be "Stolen!" and directs the jury to record this, which they do instantly.
The Hatter clarifies that he is a hatter by trade and keeps hats for sale, possessing none of his own.
At this point, the Queen puts on her spectacles and begins to stare intently at the Hatter, making him turn pale and fidget nervously.
The King demands the Hatter give his evidence, warning him not to be nervous under threat of immediate execution.
This threat fails to calm the Hatter; he shifts anxiously from foot to foot, glancing worriedly at the Queen, and in his disarray, bites a chunk out of his teacup instead of his bread-and-butter.
Simultaneously, Alice becomes aware of a peculiar physical sensation and realizes she has begun to grow taller again; considering leaving, she ultimately decides to stay as long as space permits.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

events.text_segment:
“Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a great deal to come before that!”
“Call the first witness,” said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, “First witness!”
The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. “I beg pardon, your Majesty,” he began, “for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished my tea when I was sent for.”
“You ought to have finished,” said the King. “When did you begin?”
The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse. “Fourteenth of March, I think it was,” he said.
“Fifteenth,” said the March Hare.
“Sixteenth,” added the Dormouse.
“Write that down,” the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
“Take off your hat,” the King said to the Hatter.
“It isn’t mine,” said the Hatter.
“Stolen!” the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.
“I keep them to sell,” the Hatter added as an explanation; “I’ve none of my own. I’m a hatter.”
Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.
“Give your evidence,” said the King; “and don’t be nervous, or I’ll have you executed on the spot.”
This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

“Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a great deal of evidence to come yet.” And he turned to Alice, with a grave look in his eyes. “You’ll be asked several questions, I should think,” he said, “before this trial’s over.”

The King glanced at the White Rabbit, and said, “Call the first witness.”

The White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and shouted, “First witness!”

The Hatter appeared. He had a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other. “I’m a poor man,” he began, with a melancholy look, “I haven’t brought any tea-things with me—”

“Why not?” said the King, looking at him through his crown.

“Because I was in such a hurry of getting here,” said the Hatter, “that I had not time to finish my tea.”

“Did you begin the day with lemonade?” the King asked.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Not yet, not yet!” the Rabbit hastily interrupted. “There’s a meeting at the Queen’s croquet ground. We’re to play croquet with flamingos and hedgehogs. Hurry up, now!”

Alice followed the White Rabbit down a long corridor of hedges, which twisted and turned in the most bewildering way. The air was thick with the scent of roses and the sound of distant laughter. She stumbled over roots and branches, her dress catching on thorns, but the Rabbit never stopped, only glanced back once or twice to make sure she was still following.

At last, they reached a vast, open field where the Queen of Hearts was already seated on a throne of thorns, her crown gleaming in the bright, unnatural light. Around her, a crowd of creatures had gathered—knights in mismatched armor, card soldiers with painted faces, and a chorus of giggling Cheshire Cats who appeared and disappeared at will.

“Off with her head!” the Queen cried before Alice had even taken a step forward.

“Why, what did she do?” Alice asked, startled.

“She didn’t say ‘Your Majesty’!” the Queen snapped.

“Oh, I’m very sorry,” Alice said quickly, curtsying. “Your Majesty.”

The Queen’s face softened slightly. “That’s better. Now, come and play croquet. You’ll be on the Red Team.”

Alice was handed a flamingo mallet and a hedgehog ball. The game was chaotic—players shouted orders at one another, the hedgehogs rolled away on their own, and the flamingos flapped their wings and flew off. Alice tried to keep up, but it was impossible. She was laughing so hard she could barely hold the mallet.

“Off with her head!” the Queen cried again, but this time it was in jest, and the crowd roared with laughter.

Alice, still laughing, tripped over a root and tumbled into a patch of daisies. When she opened her eyes, she was back in the forest, the Queen and the croquet ground gone, as if they had never been. Only the White Rabbit remained, still in a great hurry, and Alice, for once, was not in the least surprised.

events.title: Alice's Growth Spurt Causes Conflict
detailed_summary: The Dormouse, positioned next to the rapidly growing Alice, complains about being squeezed and unable to breathe properly.
Alice responds meekly, stating she cannot control her growth.
The Dormouse counters that she has no entitlement to grow specifically within the confines of the court.
Alice dismisses this argument more assertively, pointing out that the Dormouse is also subject to growth.
The Dormouse insists its own growth occurs at a 'reasonable pace,' unlike Alice's 'ridiculous fashion'.
Visibly annoyed, the Dormouse gets up and moves to the other side of the courtroom.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.” said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.

events.text_segment:
“I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.” said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her. “I can hardly breathe.”
“I can’t help it,” said Alice very meekly: “I’m growing.”
“You’ve no right to grow here,” said the Dormouse.
“Don’t talk nonsense,” said Alice more boldly: “you know you’re growing too.”
“Yes, but I grow at a reasonable pace,” said the Dormouse: “not in that ridiculous fashion.” And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.

events.title: Hatter's Testimony Continues Amidst Threats and Chaos
detailed_summary: Throughout Alice's growth incident, the Queen maintains her intense stare at the Hatter.
As the Dormouse relocates, the Queen instructs a court officer to fetch the list of singers from the last concert.
This request causes the Hatter extreme distress; he trembles so severely that both his shoes fall off.
The King angrily reiterates his demand for evidence, threatening execution again, irrespective of the Hatter's nervousness.
The Hatter begins a shaky, incoherent testimony, mentioning poverty, unfinished tea, thin bread-and-butter, and the 'twinkling' of the tea.
The King interrupts, questioning the concept of 'twinkling tea,' leading to a nonsensical debate about the letter 'T'.
The Hatter resumes, claiming 'most things twinkled' and attempting to attribute a statement to the March Hare.
The March Hare immediately denies it; the Hatter insists, but the King rules to disregard that part of the testimony.
The Hatter then tries to quote the Dormouse, looking around nervously, but the Dormouse offers no denial, being deeply asleep.
He mentions cutting more bread-and-butter.
A juror asks what the Dormouse said.
The Hatter admits he cannot recall.
The King declares the Hatter must remember or face execution.
Overwhelmed, the Hatter drops his teacup and bread-and-butter, falling to one knee and pleading poverty.
The King dismisses him as a 'very poor speaker.'
One of the guinea-pig observers cheers and is immediately 'suppressed' by court officers stuffing it into a canvas bag and sitting on it.
Alice mentally notes this clarifies the meaning of 'suppression' she'd read about.
The King tells the Hatter he may 'stand down,' assuming this concludes his testimony.
The Hatter, still kneeling, replies he cannot go any lower.
The King corrects himself, telling the Hatter he may 'sit down.'
The other guinea-pig cheers and is similarly suppressed.
Alice thinks the guinea-pig interruptions are over, hoping for progress.
The Hatter expresses a desire to finish his tea, looking anxiously at the Queen, who is preoccupied with the singers' list.
The King permits the Hatter to leave.

events.text_segment:
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!” on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.
“Give your evidence,” the King repeated angrily, “or I’ll have you executed, whether you’re nervous or not.”
“I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, “—and I hadn’t begun my tea—not above a week or so—and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin—and the twinkling of the tea—”
“The twinkling of the what?” said the King.
“It began with the tea,” the Hatter replied.
“Of course twinkling begins with a T!” said the King sharply. “Do you take me for a dunce? Go on!”
“I’m a poor man,” the Hatter went on, “and most things twinkled after that—only the March Hare said—”
“I didn’t!” the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.
“You did!” said the Hatter.
“I deny it!” said the March Hare.
“He denies it,” said the King: “leave out that part.”
“Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said—” the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.
“After that,” continued the Hatter, “I cut some more bread-and-butter—”
“But what did the Dormouse say?” one of the jury asked.
“That I can’t remember,” said the Hatter.
“You must remember,” remarked the King, “or I’ll have you executed.”
The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee. “I’m a poor man, your Majesty,” he began.
“You’re a very poor speaker,” said the King.
Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)
“I’m glad I’ve seen that done,” thought Alice. “I’ve so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials, “There was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court,” and I never understood what it meant till now.”
“If that’s all you know about it, you may stand down,” continued the King.
“I can’t go no lower,” said the Hatter: “I’m on the floor, as it is.”
“Then you may sit down,” the King replied.
Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
“Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!” thought Alice. “Now we shall get on better.”
“I’d rather finish my tea,” said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.
“You may go,” said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.
“—and just take his head off outside,” the Queen added to one of the officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.

This was like what she had read once somewhere about three men—“Who all went to sea in a little boat,”—but in this case the crew were rather more than three, and not all in a little boat: and when the officer had taken his list away, the Hatter sat shivering before the Queen, and would not answer a single question she put to him; indeed, his eye went wandering up and down the court from side to side, and once he tried to whisper something to the March Hare, but the King would not allow of that.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, “Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!” on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.

“Why, look at the Hatter!” said Alice, “he’s trembling like a leaf!”

“Order, order!” cried the King, who had just been reading out an important sentence from a book, and was quite surprised at the interruption. “What do you mean by that remark?” he said, turning to Alice.

“I didn’t mean to interrupt,” said Alice, “but the Hatter—”

“Silence!” roared the King, and the court attendants immediately closed their mouths and looked very grave.

The Hatter was still trembling, and his eyes were fixed on the Queen. “I—I—I—” he began, but his voice failed him.

“Come, now,” said the King, “you must try to speak. Who stole the tarts?”

“I—I—” stammered the Hatter, and then he suddenly burst into a long, rambling speech about poverty, unfinished tea, and thin bread-and-butter. “I’ve been poor all my life,” he said, “and I’ve never had a proper meal. The tea was always cold, and the bread-and-butter was always thin. And the tea—it twinkled!”

“Twinkled?” said the King, frowning. “What do you mean by that?”

“I mean,” said the Hatter, “that it—er—twinkled. Like the letter T.”

“Ah!” said the King, “I see. You mean the letter T. But what has that to do with the tarts?”

“I don’t know,” said the Hatter, “but the March Hare said—”

“Who said what?” asked the King, turning to the March Hare.

“I didn’t say anything!” said the March Hare, looking very much surprised.

“I said you did,” said the Hatter, “and I’m not a liar!”

“Order, order!” cried the King. “The Hatter is not to be believed. He is too nervous to be trusted.”

The Hatter looked around the court, and then tried to quote the Dormouse. “The Dormouse said—” he began, but the Dormouse was fast asleep, and gave no sign of having heard him.

“What did the Dormouse say?” asked one of the jurors.

“I—I don’t remember,” said the Hatter, in a trembling voice.

“Then you must remember!” said the King, in a very angry tone. “If you don’t, you’ll be executed!”

The Hatter gave a great shudder, and dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter. He fell to one knee, and looked up at the Queen with a very frightened expression. “I’m poor!” he cried. “I’m poor!”

“Order, order!” cried the King. “The Hatter is a very poor speaker, indeed!”

One of the guinea-pigs in the audience gave a loud cheer, and was immediately “suppressed” by the court attendants, who stuffed it into a canvas bag and sat upon it. Alice thought this was a very clear way of explaining what “suppression” meant.

“Now, Hatter,” said the King, “you may stand down.”

The Hatter, who was still on one knee, looked up in surprise. “I can’t go any lower,” he said.

“Then you may sit down,” said the King.

The Hatter sat down, and another guinea-pig gave a cheer, and was also “suppressed.”

Alice thought the guinea-pigs were very tiresome, and hoped they would not interrupt again.

The Hatter looked up at the Queen, who was still busy with the list of singers. “I wish I had finished my tea,” he said, in a very low voice.

“Then you may go,” said the King, “and finish it.”

The Hatter rose, and hurried out of the court, leaving his shoes behind him. The Queen, who had been looking at the list of singers, suddenly turned to the officer beside her. “Order!” she cried. “Have the Hatter beheaded!”

“Beheaded!” cried the officer, in a very frightened voice.

“Beheaded!” repeated the Queen, in a very loud voice.

“Beheaded!” cried the officer, and ran out of the court as fast as he could.

But the Hatter was already gone.

1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces invented scenes and dialogue early on, such as Alice stopping her tears and reflecting on a story about three men in a boat, which are not present in the original passage.
- The sequence of courtroom questioning and the Hatter's testimony is replaced with repetitive and invented exchanges about tarts, which do not occur in the original.
- The completion omits major sections from the original, including the detailed back-and-forth between the Hatter, King, March Hare, and Dormouse, as well as the unique courtroom events involving the guinea-pigs and Alice's internal observations.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The original contains a series of specific exchanges between the Hatter, King, March Hare, and Dormouse, including interruptions and denials, which are missing from the completion.
- The completion lacks the original's depiction of the guinea-pigs' reactions and their subsequent suppression by the officers, as well as Alice's internal commentary on this event.
- The progression of the Hatter's nervousness, his dropping of items, and the King's remarks about his speaking ability are not present.
- The conclusion of the scene, including the Queen's order regarding the Hatter and his hurried exit, is omitted.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately attributes actions and thoughts to Alice that do not occur in the original at this point in the passage.
- The sequence of events is altered, with the Hatter's testimony being replaced by a repetitive and incorrect exchange about tarts, which does not reflect the original structure or content.
- The completion misrepresents the King's role and the nature of the questioning, focusing on the theft of tarts rather than the actual testimony and courtroom dynamics present in the original.
- The completion repeats the same lines multiple times, which does not match the progression or variety of dialogue in the original passage.

events.title: The Cook's Brief Appearance and the Dormouse's Ejection
detailed_summary: The King calls for the next witness.
The Duchess's cook enters, carrying her pepper-box.
Alice immediately recognizes her, partly because people near the entrance begin sneezing uncontrollably.
The King requests her evidence.
The cook bluntly refuses, stating, "Shan't."
The King looks uncertainly at the White Rabbit, who quietly advises that His Majesty must cross-examine this witness.
Resignedly, the King accepts, folds his arms, frowns deeply at the cook, and asks in a solemn voice what tarts are composed of.
The cook replies, "Pepper, mostly."
A sleepy voice from behind the cook (the Dormouse) contradicts, suggesting "Treacle."
The Queen erupts in fury, ordering the Dormouse to be captured, beheaded, thrown out of court, suppressed, pinched, and have its whiskers removed.
A chaotic period ensues as court officers attempt to carry out the Queen's contradictory orders regarding the Dormouse.
By the time the confusion subsides and the Dormouse has been ejected, the cook has discreetly disappeared.
The King expresses considerable relief at the cook's departure and promptly calls for the next witness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Call the next witness!” said the King.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Never mind!” said the King, with an air of great relief. “Call the next witness.”

events.text_segment:
“Call the next witness!” said the King.
The next witness was the Duchess’s cook. She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
“Give your evidence,” said the King.
“Shan’t,” said the cook.
The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice, “Your Majesty must cross-examine this witness.”
“Well, if I must, I must,” the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, “What are tarts made of?”
“Pepper, mostly,” said the cook.
“Treacle,” said a sleepy voice behind her.
“Collar that Dormouse,” the Queen shrieked out. “Behead that Dormouse! Turn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his whiskers!”
For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.
“Never mind!” said the King, with an air of great relief. “Call the next witness.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Call the next witness!” said the King.

The Duchess’s cook entered, carrying her pepper-box. Alice immediately recognized her, partly because people near the entrance began sneezing uncontrollably.

“Where’s the evidence?” said the King.

“Shan’t,” said the cook, bluntly.

The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who whispered something in his ear, and then the King turned to the cook, and said in a solemn voice, “What are tarts made of?”

“Pepper, mostly,” said the cook.

A sleepy voice from behind the cook said, “Treacle.”

The Queen turned crimson with fury, and shouted, “Off with her head!”

“Nonsense!” said Alice. “She’s a Dormouse, not a cook!”

“Off with her head!” repeated the Queen.

The court officers hurried out of the court, and a great many of them came back with their arms full of sticks and stones, and they began to beat the Dormouse, who was fast asleep, and would not wake up.

“Off with her head!” cried the Queen again.

“Nonsense!” said Alice. “She’s a Dormouse, not a cook!”

“Off with her head!” repeated the Queen.

The court officers tried to carry the Dormouse out of the court, but she was so fast asleep that they could not wake her up, and they had to carry her out of the court in a blanket.

By the time they had got her out of the court, the cook had disappeared.

“Who’s next?” said the King, looking round with a kind of feeble hopefulness, as if he thought there might be some more witnesses left.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Call the next witness!” said the King.

The White Rabbit hurried in with a trumpet, and a scroll of parchment, and read out from the scroll: “There’s more evidence! The Queen of Hearts has been seen sneaking around the garden with a pocketful of tarts!”

The Queen of Hearts turned red with anger. “Off with his head!” she shouted.

“Wait a moment,” said Alice, standing up. “You can’t just execute people for sneaking around with tarts!”

The King looked surprised. “Who is this? She’s not a card!”

“She’s a human,” said the Queen. “Off with her head too!”

Alice crossed her arms. “That’s not fair! You can’t just say ‘off with their heads’ whenever you’re angry!”

The Mad Hatter clapped his hands. “I like this one! She’s got spirit!”

The King scratched his head. “Well, I suppose we can’t just execute people for no reason. Let’s have a trial!”

And so, the trial continued, with more and more absurd evidence being presented, until finally, the Queen stormed out in a huff, and the whole court dissolved into chaos.

events.title: Alice Called as the Next Witness
detailed_summary: The King speaks quietly to the Queen, suggesting she should handle the cross-examination of the upcoming witness, complaining that the effort is giving him a headache.
Alice watches the White Rabbit consult his list, feeling curious about who the next witness might be.
She internally reflects on the lack of substantial evidence presented thus far in the trial.
To Alice's utter astonishment, the White Rabbit, in his high-pitched voice, reads out her own name: "Alice!"

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And he added in an undertone to the Queen, “Really, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name “Alice!”

events.text_segment:
And he added in an undertone to the Queen, “Really, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!”
Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very curious to see what the next witness would be like, “—for they haven’t got much evidence yet,” she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name “Alice!”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
And he added in an undertone to the Queen, “Really, my dear, you must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my forehead ache!”

Alice watched the White Rabbit as he turned over the pages of his notes, and then read out in a very high, shrill voice, “The next witness—” he paused for a moment, and then added, “Alice!”

Alice gave a little scream of surprise. She had not the least idea what this could mean; and, as she sat perfectly still, she felt quite frightened all over.

The Queen turned her eyes on Alice, for she was a very proud queen, and she said, “Have you anything to say?”

Alice did not know what to say, but she thought it would be a good plan to say something, so she said, “I—I don’t know what I’m doing here at all. I was just sitting on the bank, and then I fell into the water, and then I came here, and now I’m here, and I don’t know how I got here at all.”

The King looked at her with a very puzzled expression, and the Queen said, “That is not an answer. You must either say you stole the tarts, or you must say you didn’t.”

“I don’t know what you mean by ‘stole the tarts,’” said Alice.

The Queen said, “You must mean something, or else you wouldn’t have said it.”

“I didn’t say that,” said Alice.

“You did,” said the Queen.

“I didn’t,” said Alice.

“You did,” said the Queen.

“I didn’t,” said Alice.

“You did,” said the Queen.

And so they went on for some time, in a very tiresome way, until Alice began to feel quite cross.

events.title: Alice Disrupts the Court and Upsets the Jury
detailed_summary: Forgetting her recent growth spurt in the heat of the moment, Alice jumps up and accidentally knocks over the jury box with her skirt.
The jurymen tumble out onto the crowd below, reminding Alice of goldfish she once spilled.
Feeling dismayed, Alice quickly starts picking up the jurymen, worried they might perish if not returned to the box immediately, like the goldfish.
The King solemnly declares the trial cannot continue until every juryman is back in their correct place, emphasizing the point while looking pointedly at Alice.
Alice notices she put the Lizard back upside down in her haste; it waves its tail helplessly.
She rights the Lizard, though she privately muses that its orientation likely makes no difference to its usefulness in the trial.
Once the jury recovers and gets their slates and pencils back, they diligently begin writing an account of the disruption.
The Lizard, however, seems too stunned to do anything but sit with its mouth open, staring at the ceiling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.

events.text_segment:
“Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
“Oh, I beg your pardon!” she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.
“The trial cannot proceed,” said the King in a very grave voice, “until all the jurymen are back in their proper places—all,” he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said so.
Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got it out again, and put it right; “not that it signifies much,” she said to herself; “I should think it would be quite as much use in the trial one way up as the other.”
As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “Here!” cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before. Feeling quite dismayed, Alice knelt down and began picking them up as quickly as she could, for she was rather alarmed at finding it was not a dream, after all, but only a visit to a Wonderland of her own creation. “Oh, I wish I hadn’t put my hand in at all!” she said to herself, and began to cry again. The King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, at last stopped, looked up, and said, “We must have some rule in the trial, or else everybody will argue for ever.” “The rule is, that whenever I say ‘sentence,’ the parties must begin to leave the court,” said the King, looking at Alice as he spoke. “I’ll have no more of your impertinent interruptions!” Alice was just about to ask how the rule could ever be carried out, when she noticed that she had put the Lizard back upside down, and this was such an absurd thing to do, that Alice could not help laughing, in spite of her tears. “It’s the first time I’ve ever seen a Lizard with such a long tail,” she said, as she turned it the right way. “I suppose it’s to help it balance itself when it’s sitting on a jury-box.” The Lizard only stared at the ceiling, with its mouth open, and did not seem to notice what was being said. Once the jury had all been returned to their places, and had got their slates and pencils, they set to work very diligently, writing down all that had happened, from the moment Alice had first appeared, to the present time. The Lizard, however, still sat quite still, with its mouth open, and its eyes fixed on the ceiling, as if it were trying to solve some great mystery of the universe.”}
